status_message:
Jeremy Corbyn's letter to all Momentum members:

Dear friend,

Momentum grew out of our first campaign for a new kind of politics, to channel its drive and optimism into a movement that can help Labour win power and transform our society. That enthusiasm is already changing our movement and the country's political debate on crucial issues like austerity.

As 2016 draws to a close, I wanted to share some thoughts about how that could be developed further and ask you to share yours.

'The World Transformed' at Labour Party Conference and new techniques to increase participation in Labour, such as the Grassroots Now phone-canvassing website, are exactly the participatory activities Momentum can organise to help secure a Labour government that will rebuild and transform Britain. Let's do it together; Labour's next big campaigning day is on 21 January. I hope you'll join us for it.

This moment in our history is too important for us not to seize it. We must not let internal debate distract from our work that has to be done to help Labour win elections.

Momentum needs to be an organisation fit for purpose - not copying the failed models of the past but bringing fresh ideas to campaigning and organising in communities, helping members be active in the Labour Party and helping secure a Labour government to rebuild and transform Britain.

That's why the Momentum team has drawn up a survey to give every member a direct say in its future.

We are all part of this historic movement. Let's seize this moment together.

Thank you for all that you have done in 2016. I wish you a Merry Christmas, a peaceful holiday period and a happy new year.

In solidarity,

Jeremy Corbyn

---

Check your emails to answer the survey now. The subject line is "A letter from Jeremy Corbyn to all Momentum members". And if you haven't already, become a member today: join.peoplesmomentum.com

Don't miss your chance to have your say in Momentum's future.

status_message: Watch Jeremy Corbyn's #CarefortheNHS rally LIVE now!

Tomorrow Jeremy Corbyn and Labour's Women and Equalities Shadow Minister Sarah Champion MP will be in Parliament and pushing for the ratification of the Istanbul Convention, which the Conservatives have refused to do.

The Istanbul Convention is a historic international treaty that requires states to take comprehensive action, set out minimum standards and create legally binding measures to tackle and prevent violence against women and girls.

The Government must set a date to ratify and implement the Istanbul Convention without further delay. The Government signed the Convention in 2012, but until they ratify it, the Convention remains just a piece of paper.

That's why Jeremy and Sarah Champion will be voting for a Private Members Bill tomorrow which will by-pass the Conservative's failure to act. Make sure your MP is attending by emailing them or calling their office. Find your MP's contact details here: www.theyworkforyou.com

status_message:
**REMINDER - VOTING CLOSES AT 12PM**

Voting in elections for the additional representatives to Momentum's National Committee, for liberation groups and areas not covered by local groups, closes today at 12 noon. The results of the elections will be announced on Wednesday 30th November.

Online ballot papers were sent out last Tuesday to those eligible to vote. The subject line of the email was "YOUR BALLOT FOR MOMENTUM NATIONAL COMMITTEE REPRESENTATIVES" - if you haven't already, please check the email before noon and vote, or email digitial@peoplesmomentum.com with the subject title "AGAIN" to get a reissue.

A One Member One Vote (OMOV) election was agreed by the Steering Committee, as a temporary measure, to ensure all members of liberation groups have a say in choosing their representatives. Only members who self-identified as belonging to one of the liberation groups (BAME, LGBT+, Disability and Women) when joining Momentum are able to participate in the elections.

There are also OMOV elections in 6 regions where there are a significant number of members without verified local groups and who are therefore not represented in regional network meetings. These regions are within the North West, West Midlands, Yorkshire and Humber, London, South West and South East. Each region can elect one representative for members in that region that do not live in an area covered by a verified local group.

This structure is interim until Momentum's February National Conference, after which all members will vote to decide Momentum's democratic structures going forward.

Theresa May said precisely the opposite to the Confederation of British Industry just last week. If Brexit is to be done properly, then a clear plan is needed that will benefit everyone in Britain.

status_message:
In 1959, the Cuban people, led by Fidel Castro, overthrew a corrupt dictator and began a process of enormous improvements in their lives, especially in education and healthcare. Despite international isolation and US aggression, Cuba has remained resolutely internationalist, contributing greatly to the struggles for freedom in Southern Africa and throughout the world. 

This proud internationalist legacy lives on with Cuban health workers playing a significant role in combatting the Ebola outbreak in Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea.

Cuban society - and the system of government instituted under Fidel Castro - are far from perfect but the Cuban people's struggle for a free and just world continues and is an inspiration to many. 

RIP Fidel Castro; Viva the Cuban people.

Become a supporter of The World Transformed from just ¬£1 per month: theworldtransformed.org/support. 

The World Transformed is about more than just one event. We're about pushing a positive vision for the future, talking about big ideas and creating new, exciting political experiences. We want to build a narrative of hope in a time of increasing pessimism and fear.

But we need your help.

We don't accept any corporate sponsorship and we're committed to keeping our events free to attend. As you can imagine -- this makes funding difficult. Our solution? The World Transformed Supporters Network. For as little as ¬£1 a month you can support TWT.

However, we're not just asking for money -- we're also giving back.

You'll receive:

50% off a subscription to The Jacobin Magazine;
30% off "The Candidate: Jeremy Corbyn's Improbable Path to Power" by Alex Nunns;
20% off a special collection by THTC Clothing;
First chance to buy tickets to our special events such as our exclusive screenings of 'I, Daniel Blake'.

Now more than ever we need positive, inspiring political vision. We need big ideas and a focus on the future. We need to tell a story of hope.

Become a Supporter. Join the Network. Help us Transform the World. 

theworldtransformed.org/support

status_message:
MxV - Help shape Momentum's future

Momentum has launched MxV, an innovative digital democracy platform to enable Momentum members to shape the organisation's purpose, ethics and structures. On Thursday evening, all members received an email from Momentum Digital with details of how to log into MxV to read, submit, comment on, amend, support and composite proposals to be debated at our first National Conference in February and voted on by members.  

Your proposals should seek to answer these questions:

Purpose: Why does Momentum exist?
Ethics: How should we behave?
Structures: How should we make decisions?

Guidelines on the types of proposals that can be submitted can be found here (https://mxv.peoplesmomentum.com/guidelines). Please remember that this is a platform to decide the purpose, ethics and structures of Momentum - not what we believe should be Government policy.

Any member can comment on proposals and indicate their support. The deadline for proposals to be uploaded is 1 January 2017. 

If any Momentum member hasn't received their login details, they should email digital@peoplesmomentum.com.

MxV allows all members of Momentum to participate in the conversation about Momentum's future - from the parent with childcare responsibilities who can't get to political meetings, to the shift-worker who works anti-social hours. Everyone's ideas are valued and should contribute to the debate. 

Whilst this is an online forum, the process of generating ideas and discussion should extend offline. Local Momentum Groups are encouraged to spend some time at their meetings discussing the sort of organisation Momentum needs to be to meet the challenges of world and how we should build it. 

If you're not a member, join now to help shape Momentum as it grows: http://join.peoplesmomentum.com

https://mxv.peoplesmomentum.com

status_message:
**Information About Current Momentum National Committee Elections**

The Steering Committee agreed to take steps to ensure all Momentum members are represented fairly on the National Committee.

Previously liberation representatives were elected by small working groups and the 2 seats reserved for women's representatives were vacant. An OMOV election was agreed by the Steering Committee to ensure all members of liberation groups have a say in choosing their representatives.

The National Committee was set up prior to Momentum becoming a membership organisation, and a mapping exercise of our members showed there to be a significant number of members living in areas not covered by a verified local group.

To ensure fair representation of all members on the NC, there are currently OMOV elections in 6 regions for representatives for members that do not live in an area covered by a verified local group.

The National Committee will only be growing by 6 additional seats, which will be filled by the newly elected regional representatives. The election of representatives for each liberation strand (LGBT+/BAME/Women/Disability) is to democratically fill existing seats, which were previously agreed and ratified by the National Committee. 

This structure is interim until Momentum's February National Conference, after which all members will vote to decide Momentum's democratic structures going forward.

Members will only have received an e-ballot if a) when joining Momentum they indicated that they self-identify into one of the liberation strands, or b) live in an area not covered by a verified local group. 

Online voting will close at 12 noon on Tuesday 29 November 2016.

status_message:
A country that works for everyone

The Prime Minister used her speech at the Confederation of British Industry's conference this morning to repeat her claim that the Conservative Government is building a country that works for everyone.

On the steps of Downing Street in July, Theresa May promised to stand up for 'just about managing' families, and pledged to protect the interests of workers by allowing them representation on company boards. Today, reports indicated that these families will be made ¬£2500 a year worse off under the Conservative Government by 2020, and the General Secretary of the Trade Union Congress, Frances O'Grady, accused the Prime Minister of failing to make good on her promise to deliver for ordinary people as she watered down her policy for workers' representation on company boards. 

Britain's future is uncertain, and despite the Prime Minister's words, it is clear the Government does not have the answers to the issues faced by the majority of British people. With their plans to further cut corporation tax and refusal to commit to stopping the welfare cuts that risk plunging thousands into poverty, the Tories continue to reinforce the rigged system that benefits their billionaire friends at the expense of ordinary people.

Labour is truly ambitious for Britain ‚Äì with a plan to rebuild and transform Britain by investing in infrastructure, balancing the needs of businesses and workers and delivering a Brexit that protects jobs, living standards and the economy.

"At a time when the NHS is struggling to cope with excessive sums being spent on agency staff it beggars belief that Jeremy Hunt is going to give the keys to the NHS's own staffing agency to a private company. Michael Moore's Morning After To-Do List:

1. Take over the Democratic Party and return it to the people. They have failed us miserably. 

2. Fire all pundits, predictors, pollsters and anyone else in the media who had a narrative they wouldn't let go of and refused to listen to or acknowledge what was really going on. Those same bloviators will now tell us we must "heal the divide" and "come together." They will pull more hooey like that out of their ass in the days to come. Turn them off. 

3. Any Democratic member of Congress who didn't wake up this morning ready to fight, resist and obstruct in the way Republicans did against President Obama every day for eight full years must step out of the way and let those of us who know the score lead the way in stopping the meanness and the madness that's about to begin. 

4. Everyone must stop saying they are "stunned" and "shocked". What you mean to say is that you were in a bubble and weren't paying attention to your fellow Americans and their despair. YEARS of being neglected by both parties, the anger and the need for revenge against the system only grew. Along came a TV star they liked whose plan was to destroy both parties and tell them all "You're fired!" Trump's victory is no surprise. He was never a joke. Treating him as one only strengthened him. He is both a creature and a creation of the media and the media will never own that. 

5. You must say this sentence to everyone you meet today: "HILLARY CLINTON WON THE POPULAR VOTE!" The MAJORITY of our fellow Americans preferred Hillary Clinton over Donald Trump. Period. Fact. If you woke up this morning thinking you live in an effed-up country, you don't. The majority of your fellow Americans wanted Hillary, not Trump. The only reason he's president is because of an arcane, insane 18th-century idea called the Electoral College. Until we change that, we'll continue to have presidents we didn't elect and didn't want. You live in a country where a majority of its citizens have said they believe there's climate change, they believe women should be paid the same as men, they want a debt-free college education, they don't want us invading countries, they want a raise in the minimum wage and they want a single-payer true universal health care system. None of that has changed. We live in a country where the majority agree with the "liberal" position. We just lack the liberal leadership to make that happen (see: #1 above).

Let's try to get this all done by noon today. 

-- Michael Moore

www.facebook.com/mmflint/posts/10153913074756857

status_message:
MOMENTUM STATEMENT ON THE US ELECTION

A racist, misogynist demagogue has been elected President of the United States.

We extend our solidarity to the American people, in particular to women, people of colour, ethnic and religious minorities, migrants and LGBT+ people feeling afraid and abandoned today.

In our current system, wealth and power travels upwards, from the working and middle classes to the elite few at the top. Despite the hard work of many, the same few at the top reap all the rewards. Since the 2008 financial crisis the situation has worsened - inequality has sharply increased, living standards have fallen or stagnated, and many have been plunged into poverty and deprivation.

Trump has capitalised on this hardship and suffering, campaigning on a promise to create an economy that works for everyone. But Trump will not deliver this change. Neoliberal policies are responsible for the system that has benefited the few rather than the many, not the migrants, refugees and ethnic minorities who he has sought to scapegoat. 

Political parties have failed to address a system that has left the majority of people behind, and have failed to respond to cries against the status quo, creating a void which is increasingly being filled by the far-right in many countries. 

Progressives in the US, the UK and around the world must come together to stem this rising tide of fascism. We must condemn hate, division and discrimination. We must build support for a new economic programme, with fairness and environmental sustainability at its core, and social and foreign policies based on equality, justice and respect for human rights.

We must work together and organise in our communities to build support for an agenda for progressive change.

Today we have mourned. Now it's time to organise.

‚ûù www.peoplesmomentum.com/join

status_message:
UNANIMOUS STATEMENT FROM MOMENTUM STEERING COMMITTEE

The Steering Committee recognises and regrets the discontent and frustration felt by Momentum members in recent days. Momentum's democratic structures were always intended to develop. Unfortunately, this summer's leadership election delayed that development, with all our energy being diverted into ensuring Jeremy Corbyn's reelection.

The Committee recognises the need for a greater level of accountability and transparency from the leadership and administration of the organisation and will work to deliver that over the coming weeks.

Our path to democratisation, through our first National Conference in the new year, has not been sufficiently effectively communicated, leading, at times, to a breakdown in trust between different sections of our movement. There was not enough consultation and discussion with the diverse political and organisational traditions that exist in our movement. Pluralism is our strength, and all views must be properly engaged with.

After further discussion, the Steering Committee has agreed unanimously the following path for Momentum's democratisation, which places unity, pluralism and member-control at its heart.

The National Committee, postponed from this Saturday, will take place on 3 December. We will ensure that this meeting is properly representative, including new elections for our liberation strands where necessary. A plan for ensuring this will be submitted and approved by the Steering Committee at the latest by 11 November.

A further National Committee meeting will be held in January before our Conference in February. Our Conference, involving all members of Momentum, groups and affiliated organisations, will decide our organisation's long-term structure.

Taking into account the strong views on both sides of the OMOV (one member, one vote) vs. delegate for Conference votes, the Steering Committee has agreed on a recommendation to the National Committee of a suitable format. There will be both a physical delegates conference to thoroughly debate proposals submitted from the membership, and then OMOV voting on the proposals in the period after the conference. The details of this procedure will be determined over the coming weeks. 

We know all levels of Momentum are committed to a truly inclusive and democratic structure and will make it succeed over the next few months.

Great to see this huge display of solidarity with #NODAPL and members of the over 90 Native American nations which are protesting against the Dakota Access oil pipeline at Standing Rock in North Dakota, which will harm water resources and desecrate sacred land, in violation of the 1851 Treaty with the Sioux nation of Standing Rock. 

Yesterday 1 million people checked in on Facebook to the Standing Rock Indian reservation to help protect activists from police surveillance, and many more are checking in today. 

Today at 5.30pm in London there will also be a demonstration outside the U.S. Embassy in solidarity with the Standing Rock Sioux and allies fighting for their land rights against the Dakota Access Pipeline.
www.facebook.com/events/1099845556751616/

status_message:
Incredibly important piece by Aditya Chakrobarti:

"From next Monday 88,000 families across Britain will have their housing benefit slashed. They will no longer have the cash to pay their rent. Among all those whose lives will be turned upside down will be a quarter of a million children. That's enough kids to fill 350 primary schools, all facing homelessness.

These cuts will do something Thatcher never managed: they break once and for all the link between the needs of benefits claimants and their entitlements. Children will be punished for the "sins" of their parents: the sins of being poor and of having too large a family in the eyes of Osborne and Iain Duncan Smith. David Cameron's Tories once legislated to "eliminate child poverty": Theresa May's Tories are re-creating it for a new generation."
link_name: Creating child poverty for a whole new generation. Take a bow, Theresa May | Aditya Chakrabortty

status_message:
Poet, artist and activist Akala speaks about what it really means to be British. British history is often distorted and whitewashed, and British 'values' defined around the monarchy, aristocracy and empire.

This narrow perspective ignores and erases the people's history, including the political struggles that won us the freedoms we enjoy today: from the miners' strike, the Suffragettes and the Chartists, to campaigns to end the slave trade and child labour, and movements fighting for equality and social justice up to the present day. 

Akala asks "which is of the traditions of the people of this island will you be drawing on and identifying with? The one that promotes and reinforces race and class oppression and explains away the genocide of empire as a civilising mission, or the one of relentless activism that secured for us the very fragile freedoms that we have today?"

The London Evening Standard seems to have got it right here.

"Mr Corbyn is right.

Yesterday the leader of the Opposition, Jeremy Corbyn, brought a motion before the Commons to support a UN investigation into the war in Yemen and questioned the sales of British arms to Saudi Arabia, which he claims may be used to bomb civilians. He also criticised the Government's apparent support for Saudi to be admitted to the UN Human Rights Council. His motion was defeated as his MPs didn't back it. But on this, Mr Corbyn was right; his critics wrong.

The war in Yemen, the poorest country in the Middle East, rivals that in Syria for its catastrophic effect on civilians. Yet Britain, while indignant about Russian action in Aleppo, is happy to sell arms to the Saudi coalition besieging the city of Hodeida, where children are dying of hunger. This is an iniquitous double standard. Mr Corbyn is the conscience of Parliament on Yemen."

"I spent a year travelling through 10 countries, was sent to jail, had my face burnt with chemicals and almost died in the Mediterranean.

Three weeks after all this was finally over, I found myself in front of five strangers who were tasked with assessing my age".  

After the US invaded Afghanistan, Gulwali Passarlay's home became a war zone, forcing him to run for his life to avoid being forcibly recruited to the Taliban. When he finally reached safety in the UK, Gulwali was told by officials that they did not believe he was 13, and declared that he was 16 and a half. He was placed in an independent living centre with adult asylum seekers and told that when he turned 18 (which, according to them, was in a year and a half) he would be deported back to Afghanistan.

This week unaccompanied children and teenage refugees brought to the UK from Calais have been accused of lying about their age, and have been dehumanised and derided in the right-wing press. We should be welcoming these vulnerable young people to a place of sanctuary and treating them with compassion and solidarity, not with hate, fear and abuse. As Gulwali says, "we should be proud that we are reuniting young people with their families".
link_name: 'When I fled to the UK, no one believed I was 13. Ten years on, nothing's changed'

Hate crime against Jewish people has increased in the UK by nearly a third since 2010. There was an 11% rise in antisemitic incidents in the first half of 2016, compared to 2015. This is shocking and unacceptable. 

The comments on this Channel 4 News clip show what a long way we have to go, with too many believing antisemitic prejudices are a thing of the past. 

They are not. Antisemitism is widespread and increasing in Britain and across Europe. Different strands of racism and bigotry feed off and fuel each other. It is vital that we come together across communities and backgrounds to stand in solidarity with Jewish communities, stamp out prejudice, and resist attempts from any quarter to embed hate and division in our society.

Why is Ken Loach's new film so emotional?

Because it's so close to home. I, Daniel Blake portrays the reality of the draconian benefits system we have today, where harsh work capability assessments overturn the opinion of doctors and send those who are clearly unfit to take on work out to look for jobs they cannot take or don't exist. 

Between 2011 and 2014, 2,380 disabled people died, 90 people a month, after being declared 'fit for work' and having their benefits cut. Last month the Government announced it will scrap re-testing but has done nothing to address the test itself, and plans to further cut disability benefits by ¬£30 a week.

In Ashton, Greater Manchester, the Guardian looks into the lives of the real Daniel Blakes and those who, as in Loach's film, have begun to fight back against this cruel system which dehumanises, degrades and abandons vulnerable people. 

#WeAreAllDanielBlake

status_message:
50 years ago today, a coal waste tip collapsed in Aberfan, South Wales over a school and houses.

144 people died - 116 of them children - in one of the worst peacetime tragedies of the century. Despite the National Coal Board being found guilty of extreme negligence, no-one was ever properly held to account, and most of the compensation received was spent on making major repairs to the village. 

Aberfan still bears the scars. Join us for a minute's silence at 0915 to remember the disaster and hope that such tragic carelessness is never allowed to happen again.
link_name: Survivors mark 50 years since Aberfan disaster

status_message:
Solidarity with postal workers in Luton and Leagrave, on strike yesterday over issues including suspensions and workload. LIKE, LOVE and SHARE this post to show your support.

Neal Kidwell, branch secretary for CWU's Eastern No 6 branch explains:

"Postal workers in Luton are at breaking point. There have been at least six serious cases at the delivery office in recent weeks, including staff being suspended, and things can't go on. Postal workers are in fear of their jobs and many are routinely doing unpaid overtime to cope with unmanageable workloads because they fear management will not listen to their concerns.

The union has serious concerns that Royal Mail has misapplied the company's own agreed Conduct Code in the way that is dealing with employees.

We realise that strike action will cause disruption to the public, however the CWU believe we have made every reasonable attempt to avoid industrial action through negotiations with the business without success. We will consider further strike action if genuine talks are not offered by management."

status_message: "The situation in Yemen is already catastrophic and largely out of view. Since the conflict began 18 months ago, more than 6,800 people have been killed. Almost 14.4 million people are now "food insecure", according to the UN's World Food Program, and 2.8 million people have been displaced. In 2015, there were 101 attacks on schools and hospitals. After two Doctors Without Borders hospitals were bombed resulting in 20 deaths ‚Äì one in Taiz on 2 December 2015 and the other in Abs on 15 August this year ‚Äì the humanitarian group was forced to withdraw from its six hospitals in northern Yemen. And the latest news is a cholera outbreak."

status_message:
The Calais camp is due to be demolished, and its residents evicted, by French authorities by 31 October. According to Help Refugee's latest census, there are 1,022 unaccompanied minors in the camp, sleeping rough, living in tents with strangers, begging for food and hiding from traffickers. When French authorities evicted part of the camp earlier this year, over 100 children went missing. 

Although the Dubs Amendment was passed by Parliament in March 2016, committing us to taking our fair share of the refugee children in Europe who have fled persecution, very few children have safely arrived in the UK. 387 children have been identified who have the right to reside in the UK. The Home Office has been given their details, yet these children remain in Calais. 

While the Government announced yesterday that they will facilitate the transfer of some unaccompanied children in Calais to the UK in the next week, they have not said how many children will be given refuge. It is vital that we keep up the pressure to ensure that our Government urgently fulfills its obligations to protect vulnerable refugee children. 

A demonstration has been called by a number of organisations including Help4Refugee Children and Help Refugees Worldwide which Momentum will be attending. Please come along and call on the Government to take in unaccompanied refugee children, who will be at even greater risk of abuse and exploitation once the closing of the camp commences.
link_name: Momentum Bloc at Enact Lord Dubs Amendment Now Rally

status_message:
As part of the Labour Party Conference fringe, Momentum has just hosted four days of politics, art, music and culture - called 'The World Transformed', at the Black-E - more than 150 hours of workshops, gigs, talks, spoken word acts, film screenings, comedy and children's activities. The event provided spaces for inclusive and respectful debate, where attendees had the opportunity to contribute to a radical, positive vision for the 21st century.

The Black-E was launched in 1968 as the UK's first community arts project ‚Äì a combination of a community centre and contemporary arts centre. Its history of a wide-ranging delivery of creative, political, developmental and educational activities and opportunities - in partnership with a wide range of organisations - means that the Black-E continues to be a national role model of both continuity and innovation.

Central to The Black-E has always been supporting communities and community organisations. The building's proximity to Britain's oldest established African Caribbean community, and to Europe's oldest Chinatown, means that cultural diversity is a root driver of the Black-E's raison d'etre. There is a wealth of evidence regarding the diversity of our users and partners, and the way in which the Black-E acts as a talent development hub for disengaged community members from disadvantaged communities across Liverpool. Within the Black E's programme last year, there were 19% disability focused elements, and 58% BME focused. What we offer young people especially, includes 'what they want, what they need, and what they have never dreamt of'.

Some the main projects currently include: providing a regular space for disadvantaged women to come together for social, health, cultural, and educational benefits ‚Äì groups include asylum seekers and refugees, migrants, isolated older women, abused women in refuges, and women with mental health issues. Another, pioneering, innovative and creative project is with young people under 13 with neurodevelopmental conditions ‚Äì the project offers a holistic approach with our partners also working with parents and carers. We provide the children, in the words of the Last Poets, with - 'affection, protection and direction'.

The Black-E has continued to open 5-days a week, be available for use on the other two days, form new partnerships, and develop existing and new projects. This has been against the backdrop of a significant 35% Arts Council cut a year and a half ago.

Support The Black-E now, so that we can continue with our work.

Every donation, no matter how small, will be helping us to support others who use or want to use our community building.

https://www.crowdpac.co.uk/campaigns/176/the-black-e

They did not pass!

Our project is a rocket booster for Labour and for politics that includes and empowers people ‚Äì the only people that should feel threatened by us are Theresa May and her brutal but brittle government.

We welcome Labour's Shadow Cabinet appointments. It's a Shadow Cabinet that looks like Britain.

It's great to see Labour's most diverse Shadow Cabinet ever, with 16 women shadow ministers, making up half of the great offices of state, 6 shadow ministers from black, asian and minority ethnic backgrounds, and working class shadow ministers from across Britain.

Some of the Shadow Ministers appointed today have extensive experience on the shadow front bench and in government. Many of those who will continue in Shadow Cabinet roles stepped up to serve this summer and provided a highly effective opposition to the government in the wake of Brexit, and in the face of government attacks on junior doctors and attempts to re-introduce segregation into our education system. 

This diverse, broad-based shadow cabinet represents the breadth of opinion within our Party, and the variety of backgrounds and widespread experience and skills necessary to form a formidable opposition. 

The new Shadow Cabinet will lead a strong, united Labour Party, rejecting the nasty, regressive policies of the Tories and putting forward Labour's ambitious plan to rebuild and transform Britain.

status_message:
Tory Conference has shown that Theresa May's party is small, nasty and backwards-looking. They are running down our country - stagnant wages, rising debt, fewer homeowners, smaller homes, creaking infrastructure, and services cut to the bone. But the few - the bankers who crashed the economy, landlords receiving billions per year in housing benefit, Sports Direct's Mike Ashley ripping off workers, Philip Green gutting BHS workers' pensions, and the tax avoiders not paying their fair share - continue to get away with it. 

The people of Britain can't afford to be treated like this anymore. That's why a movement is rising, right across the country. It's a movement that's ambitious for Britain. 

We won't blame those at the margins for failures at the top. We are confident in our country's talents to face the future, and build a strong, high-tech economy that rewards those who create the wealth - that means all of us. We refuse to believe that the young can't have a better life than their parents. We have the talent, the ingenuity and the will to build a better world: affordable housing for all, a national education system, a renationalised NHS, job security for everyone, an equal society, safeguarding the environment, and peace, security and justice. We do that by empowering people and communities to take control of their futures.

We won't accept second best. Things can, and they will, change. That's why we're Momentum. That's why we're Labour. That's why we're the future.

It's time. Join our Movement and work for a Labour government with the ambition to transform Britain for all of us.

Charles Kasule. 37 yrs. Learning Technologist
 
IT'S TIME for technology to be used better and for the benefit of everyone.
 
Having lived in London for 15 years, I have seen many changes take place. The lack of equal opportunities is dividing our communities. Nowhere is this disparity as stark as in education. Where you study and how you learn are some of the most defining factors in our lives. For the disfranchised a bad start can create lock in. As a technologist working in higher education, we aim to break this cycle by using digital technologies to create better, more accessible learning experiences. In the absence of adequate funding we are starting to see schools where there is hardly any digital literacy or teaching of computer skills. Not surprisingly, these are often in lower-income neighbourhoods with more ethnic minorities and immigrants. This propagates even more social inequality as these students are doubly discriminated against
 
I'm joining Labour because it's time for education to be accessible for all. I want to see real commitment to helping every student reach their potential, not just a privileged few.
 
#JoinLabour #ItsTime

status_message:
A statement from Momentum's Steering Committee 

Momentum's Steering Committee has voted, seven to three, to remove Jackie Walker as its Vice Chair, a position it elected her to. She remains a member of Momentum and its Steering Committee.

Jackie's actions at Labour Conference, in her subsequent Channel 4 interview, and by not understanding concern caused by her statements, have led the Steering Committee to view her behaviour as irresponsible and lose confidence in her as Vice Chair.

Having read reports of what Jackie Walker is alleged to have said, listened to the leaked video, and heard Jackie's version of events, the Committee does not regard any of the comments she appears to have made, taken individually, to be antisemitic. However, the Committee does consider her remarks on Holocaust Memorial Day and on security of Jewish schools to be ill-informed, ill-judged and offensive. In such circumstances, the Committee feels that Jackie should have done more to explain herself to mitigate the upset caused and should have been careful about statements on this and related subjects, whatever her record as an anti-racist, which the Committee applauds. 

Momentum is concerned that footage of a training session was leaked to the press. The leak is unacceptable and undermines much needed political education. Momentum also calls on Labour to apply the principles laid down in the Chakrabarti report in its investigation of Jackie. On the basis of the evidence the Committee has seen, Jackie should not be expelled from the Labour Party.

status_message:
Leigh Drennan of Northwest Young Labour giving a passionate speech in favour of democracy at Labour Conference today.

On an important vote on how to consider constitutional changes, including new NEC positions for Scottish and Welsh Labour - but chosen by their leaders, not their members - the chair has refused to allow a "card vote", where all entitled to vote hold up their cards and are counted. Instead, the chair simply ruled on the basis of a show of hands, which can be very misleading and arbitrary. And this was just one of many undemocratic moves recently.

It's unfortunate that when we are putting on The World Transformed, a festival of participatory and inclusive events, we're seeing some of the usual undemocratic politics just ten minutes away. These kind of moves only work for so long, though. Our movement is transforming British politics, and that's not something that can be held back.

"In South Sudan, in Libya, in Yemen ‚Äì even in Syria, however faraway it seems now ‚Äì peace is not impossible. But it will never be achieved by dropping bombs from 30,000 feet."

Share if you agree.

Yesterday Momentum activists at The World Transformed ran through a scenario in which a "snap general election" had been called. They split into seven groups to come up with a Labour manifesto covering every policy area, which was then announced by each group in a mock press conference.

It's exactly this kind of creative and participatory organising which can bring people into politics and give them the confidence to take part in political life. Contrary to our portrayal in parts of the press, Momentum isn't about rigid ideas, dogmas or denouncing others. We're about inclusion, participation and dialogue.

If you haven't already, It's Time to join Momentum, join Labour, and help build our movement:
join.peoplesmomentum.com
join.labour.org.uk

Today, Labour members, affiliates and supporters re-elected Jeremy Corbyn as the leader of the Labour Party with an even bigger mandate than last year. This success was achieved by a movement powered by people ‚Äì supporters and activists, from all walks of life, right across Britain, active and engaged in their communities, workplaces and online.

But none of this is enough on its own. We've all made Jeremy the leader of the Labour Party ‚Äì now we need to get into government so that we can rebuild and transform Britain.

That task won't be easy. We will need every scrap of creativity, every bit of energy, and all the hard graft that we can muster. But we know that it is possible ‚Äì because, together, we are changing British politics.

It's time.

If you haven't already, there is one simple thing that you can to do today: join the Labour Party.

Or, if you're already a member of Labour, encourage your friends, family, neighbours and co-workers that want to build a better society to join the Labour Party.

It's time to demand the future ‚Äì and to make it happen.

If not you, then who? And if not now, when?

Labour and Momentum - why did people get involved?

Are we parasites, or a bunch of sinister, Machiavellian, far left extremists who invented internet trolling and want to nationalise your mum? We've invited Labour leadership candidate Owen Smith to meet our members to clear up any confusion, and hopefully end the smears of the tens of thousands of Momentum members and supporters who campaign tirelessly for the Labour Party. We're confident that, like Owen Jones, he'll find that such smears aren't warranted.

"The sad truth is we are more likely to be infiltrated by journalists than Trotskyists. If someone had said a year ago that campaigning for Jeremy Corbyn would lead me to be secretly filmed through a handbag by someone pretending to be another enthusiastic volunteer, we wouldn't have believed them. But it's happened twice already now ‚Äì and many of the young people who volunteer with Momentum now feel hurt and manipulated. We've had our words twisted out of context, our loyalties to our party questioned and our trust breached. And this behaviour from public institutions should worry people across Labour, including those who disagree with us on policy."
link_name: Dispatches won't stop Momentum inspiring young people - we're here to stay

status_message:
A #Dispatches documentary about Momentum is about to air and we thought our members and supporters deserve an explanation in advance. 

An undercover journalist posed as an enthusiastic volunteer and dishonestly gained employment on the Jeremy for Labour campaign. She manipulated our welcoming environment and goodwill to secretly film people over several months, which has left many activists distraught. 

She found nothing she couldn't have got by asking, but Dispatches may have cut and collaged footage to imply that we conduct ourselves in an underhand way. 

The whole affair raises questions about the impartiality of the broadcaster and the production company who made the programme, and since this is the second time it's happened, shows we're more likely to be infiltrated by journalists than Trotskyists. 

Undercover journalism has helped highlight real abuses of power and wealth, but this is shallow and not worth worrying about. As ever, we shouldn't let ourselves get angry and defensive over these situations, but keep on having an open and welcoming approach to politics - that's how we change things.

It's really disappointing that Channel 4 #Dispatches chose to exploit some of our greatest assets - our enthusiastic and young activists and our open, welcoming approach. Here, activists who knew and worked with Dispatches' undercover reporter explain how her violation of their trust has impacted them.

All this for a mixture of information on the public record or openly available, and some slurs or matters of opinion which raise more concerns about the impartiality of the broadcaster than anything else.

Record numbers of people were Calling for Corbyn during Super Saturday, and now the campaign has announced... Super Tuesday! This is the absolutely final push of Jeremy's campaign, to contact people who haven't voted before voting ends 12pm Wednesday. There will be special guests at the phonebanks, and special surprises for those using the website to call from home (both today and tomorrow).

Join us for this final push of Jeremy's campaign, and invite your friends!

We believe in positive campaigning, focusing on the enthusiasm, energy and democratic and participatory culture that Momentum activists bring, and the great policy ideas coming out of the Jeremy for Labour campaign. Aggression and abuse - much of it online, much of it misogynist and racist - is never acceptable. But this applies to all abuse, including the large amounts of abuse publicly directed at supporters of Momentum and Jeremy Corbyn, and, as revealed in this article, the bullying and pressure on MPs who have stuck with Jeremy in the last few months.

Solidarity to all affected by abuse, regardless of who it comes from - and here's hoping that people will start debating our ideas, rather than calling us all names.
link_name: Jeremy Corbyn is almost certain to be re-elected and Labour must stop bullying

Share if you oppose the latest round of slurs against us.

The story: Through an undercover reporter, Channel 4 Dispatches exploited two of the strongest attributes of Momentum and the Jeremy for Labour campaign: their enthusiastic and young activists and their open, welcoming approach.

The undercover reporter, who volunteered for Momentum and then worked on volunteer mobilisation, was considered a friend by many. Her dishonest actions have disappointed and hurt a number of people, but most especially many of the young volunteers she worked so closely with, and covertly filmed.

The result is a mix of information on the public record or openly available, as well as various "allegations" that, properly analysed, are slurs or matters of opinion which will raise more concerns about the impartiality of the broadcaster than anything else.
link_name: Momentum Rejects 'Slurs' It Claims Channel 4 Makes In Dispatches Undercover Investigation

In 2011, just 13 MPs voted against Cameron's proposed intervention in Libya. Those 13 included Jeremy Corbyn and John McDonnell.

Today's report by The Foreign Affairs Select Committee confirms that they were absolutely right to take a "cautious" approach to jumping into foreign conflicts: there was no coherent strategy, and intervention lead to the spread of arms throughout the region and the rise in ISIS. And this was absolutely clear from information available at the time.

Corbyn has consistently called it right on foreign policy, where others in the Labour Party and the media have got it disastrously wrong.

We're incredibly excited to announce that the first UK screening of 'I, Daniel Blake' - Ken Loach's new Palm D'Or winning film - will take place at The World Transformed, followed by a live Q+A with Ken Loach and the film's writer, Paul Laverty.

The film follows Daniel, an out of work joiner, and Katie, a single mother, who are both caught up in the barbed-wire of welfare bureaucracy, battling not to be caught up in the rhetoric of 'strivers and skivers'.

The screening will take place on Saturday 24th. Tickets will go on sale TODAY at 1pm, starting at ¬£10. We have also held back a number of free tickets for those currently unemployed, which will be distributed through local union partners.

Speaking on his decision to hold a special preview of the film as part of The World Transformed, Loach said, "This festival is such a good idea that you wonder why it hasn't happened before. Political ideas can spring from songs, literature, film, pictures- all the many ways in which we imagine the world, how we live together, the possibilities and danger we face, all these are explored through art. But it is no accident that the festival is being organised as part of the movement that has seen Jeremy Corbyn and his allies re-invigorate the Labour Party."

Tickets: https://www.picturehouses.com/cinema/Picturehouse_At_Fact

"If the patronising complaint hurled at millennials is that they are too young to remember the bad days of the old left, my generation does remember.

First, we remember that "left" is not synonymous with "bad" and that left politics do have popular support (just check the figures in support of renationalisation of utilities, for example, or fairer taxation).

Meanwhile, we also recall Corbyn speaking out against apartheid at a time when the current party of government was calling Nelson Mandela a terrorist and doing business with an internationally boycotted South Africa.

And like Sanders, Corbyn was opposed to the Iraq war at the time, foreseeing its devastating consequences for the Iraqi people.

At a time when trust in Westminster is so eroded, a politician who has repeatedly, Google-verifiably kept to the same principles is going to appeal across generations."
link_name: Jeremy Corbyn shows it's not just the young who still want change | Rachel Shabi

Please share far and wide - here's what to do if you still haven't received your Labour ballot ‚Üì

Eligible members should receive a ballot by both email and post. Registered supporters and affiliated supporters should receive their ballot by email. If the Labour Party do not hold an email address for affiliated supporters, they will supply their ballot by post.

If you're unsure if you're eligible for a vote, then check your voting eligibility here: www.labour.org.uk/index.php/leadership/info#eligible

If you are eligible, please first search your inbox and junk folder for an email from labourelections@electoralreform.co.uk with the subject line "VOTE NOW: Labour Leadership Election".

If your ballot hasn't arrived, the quickest way to get one is through the website www.labour.org.uk/ballotqueries. You should expect a response within three working days. If this doesn't work, call Labour on 0345 092 2299, Monday - Friday 9am - 5pm. But please note that the Labour Party is receiving a very high volume of calls, so it may be hard to get through.

Your ballot will typically take 10 days to arrive, but as long as you request it by 5pm Monday 19 September you will, if you're eligible to vote, receive this ballot in time to vote by the deadline.

Please do not contact Electoral Reform Services (ERS) as they are redirecting people back to the Labour Party. 

Let Jeremy for Labour know when you have voted at www.jeremyforlabour.com/voted

Have you been unfairly denied a vote in Labour's leadership election? Barrister and Labour member Liz Davies is offering free help here ‚Üí

And if you are supposed to have a vote but haven't received an e-mail with your ballot, you can request it by visiting www.labour.org.uk/re-issue. This is the fastest way to get a ballot, which should come to you within 3 working days. If this doesn't work, you can call Labour on 0345 092 2299, Monday - Friday 9am - 5pm, though with the high volume of calls they are receiving it may be hard to get through.

status_message:
"Something that should have been obvious about Smith has finally emerged. He doesn't seem to believe in anything.

Sure, he has "policies". But they are, in general, whatever Jeremy says only less. And he's a patriot. And he has a "normal family".

Smith's conversion to Jeremy Lite socialism is so shallow and recent that there is no backstory to it. With Tony Benn you understood how he moved from the centre to the left; the same with Ed Miliband, who had to be dissuaded by his minders from visiting the student occupation of UCL in 2010.

With Owen Smith it is never clear where, on the road from BBC Wales, via Pfizer, via the years as a special adviser in Belfast surrounded by all those nice members of MI5, via losing Blaenau Gwent to an independent because he was too identified with Blair‚Ä¶ at what point did Owen become converted to Jeremy Lite left radical socialism?"

- Paul Mason, journalist and broadcaster

David Owen, who split from Labour in the 1980s to found the right-wing Social Democratic Party (SDP), has welcomed Jeremy Corbyn's latest proposals to re-nationalise the NHS:

"For the first time in 14 years we have the leader of the Labour Party today unequivocally committing the party to reversing the legislation which has created in England a broken down, market-based healthcare system: one which is unrecognisable from that which was introduced in 1948 and which still exists in the rest of the UK.

Surely now the whole Labour movement can combine together, left, right and centre to make this official party policy at this year's autumn conference."

status_message:
Owen Smith knows that Jeremy Corbyn supported Remain - they campaigned for it together. As he tweeted on 3 June, for example: "Fantastic crowd to hear Jeremy Corbyn and a supporting cast make the case for LabourIn at Cardiff City Hall".

The "Jeremy secretly voted Leave" story was so flimsy that even the tabloid press barely ran with it. As Jeremy said at the hustings last night, it's disappointing that this is the level the debate has been brought down to.

Owen and tonight's #LabourHustings audience agree: let's stick with Jeremy Corbyn.

5 - 0
It's good to see that Jeremy has won Owen round on so many different policy areas. After all, if bankers caused the crash, why should working people pay for it? #LabourLeadership

"The decision by Labour party officials to suspend the Bakers' Union
leader, Ronnie Draper, from the party and deny him a vote in Labour's leadership election over unidentified social media posts is shocking, and appears to be part of a clear pattern of double standards.

While Ronnie, a supporter of Jeremy Corbyn, has been denied his say in Labour's election, no action is being taken over the Labour peer, Lord Sainsbury, who has given more than ¬£2m to support the Liberal Democrats.

And no action has been taken against Michael Foster, the Labour party member who abused Jeremy Corbyn's supporters and staff as Nazi stormtroopers in the Daily Mail.

Both will, as things stand, be able to vote in this election. Meanwhile, thousands of other members and registered supporters are reported to have been denied a vote without being given an explanation or opportunity to challenge the decision or process.

Labour party members will not accept what appears to be a rigged purge of Jeremy Corbyn supporters. The conduct of this election must be fair and even-handed.

I am writing to Labour's general secretary Iain McNicol to demand that members and supporters who are suspended or lose their voting rights are given clear information about why action has been taken and a timely opportunity to challenge the decision.

In particular, the specification of particular terms of abuse to exclude Labour party members from voting should not be applied retrospectively."

- John McDonnell, Shadow Chancellor

"Richard Branson didn't launch his twitter attack on Jeremy because he had another idle moment on his Necker Island or because he could need the publicity. He did it because his ¬£5.5 billion Virgin Group, the whole privatised corporate world he represents, is under huge threat from the set of public-centred ideas that Jeremy Corbyn stands for."

Today's "scandal" - and no, it's not zero hours contracts or the gender pay gap. It's #TrainGate. Photos and video footage clearly show that the train was crowded, and many passengers, including Jeremy, were having to sit on the floor. As explained by Jeremy for Labour:

"When Jeremy boarded the train he was unable to find unreserved seats, so he sat with other passengers in the corridor who were also unable to find a seat. 

Later in the journey, seats became available after a family were upgraded to first class, and Jeremy and the team he was travelling with were offered the seats by a very helpful member of staff.

Passengers across Britain will have been in similar situations on overcrowded, expensive trains. That is why our policy to bring the trains back into public ownership, as part of a plan to rebuild and transform Britain, is so popular with passengers and rail workers."

"For the SNP to have become Scotland's left-wing party, Labour had to become incredibly toxic. What Scottish Labour desperately needs now is an insurgent, anti-establishment challenge to the SNP. For the first time in decades, Jeremy Corbyn is providing a glimpse of that leadership."

status_message:
David Wearing presents the two visions of the future of the Labour Party which are currently in conflict:

"Two fundamentally opposing visions are in conflict. The first seeks to market the parliamentary Labour party to majority public opinion, the press and big business as competent managers of the status quo. 

The second vision is one that sets the party a harder task: to win power in order to substantively change the country (as it did after world war two). This involves turning Labour into a social movement, with a mass membership playing an active day-to-day role in communities across the country, winning the battle for hearts and minds on the ground, countering the inevitable attacks from those with a vested interest in the Thatcher-Blair-Cameron settlement, and shaping party policy from the bottom up."
link_name: Labour NEC wins voting appeal: our writers' verdict | Polly Toynbee and David Wearing

status_message:
Labour party lawyers argued on appeal that the NEC had the right to ignore the rulebook and make up its own rules - and today the Court of Appeal overturned the High Court's judgement which gave all Labour members the right to vote in the upcoming leadership election.

Responding to the ruling, a spokesperson for Jeremy for Labour said:

"We think that this is the wrong decision - both legally and democratically.

The Court's ruling disenfranchises nearly 130,000 Labour members, who joined the party since January and were explicitly told that they would have a vote in any leadership election.

Crucial to the outcome today was the introduction of a new argument by the Labour Party HQ's lawyers, who invoked an obscure clause in the Labour Party rules (Chapter 4, Clause II, 1.A), which could be read as giving the NEC the right to ignore all of the rules laid out for leadership elections. In other words, this is a "make it up as you go along" rule. We do not think that making it up as you go along is a reasonable way to conduct democracy in our party.

Serious questions must be raised, however, over why and how the NEC Procedures Committee brought this appeal. In doing so, it effectively risked new members' money on an attempt to disenfranchise them. If we are to build a big, inclusive party to take on the Tories, we need to secure democracy in our party."

The government's Islamophobic "Prevent" strategy has, as Human Rights Watch has warned, become a "significant source of grievance" among British Muslims and promoted mistrust between minority communities and the state, and been strongly condemned by unions such as the National Union of Students, National Union of Teachers and the University College Union.

Cases like that of Mohammed Umar Farooq are illustrative. A student at Staffordshire University studying Terrorism, Crime and Global Security, Mohammed was questioned by library security about his views on homosexuality, Isis and Al-Qaida after reading a textbook on terrorism. Library staff told security that "there is a man, who is Asian and with a beard, who is not a student and is reading a book on terrorism". The student found the incident deeply affecting and he withdrew from his course as a consequence of the experience.

Read more:
link_name: Dear Owen Smith - Backing the Racist Prevent Strategy Won't Win You This Election, It'll Lose Labour Votes

status_message:
Looks like it's time for some more myth busting about the EU referendum. 

Jeremy is absurdly being blamed for Brexit, but polling data shows that 65% of Labour voters went Remain, with Liberal Democrats and SNP voters at similar levels (68% and 64%). 35% of Labour voters did vote Leave - but so did 32% of Lib Dems and 36% of SNP, and even 20% of Greens. 

By contrast, a mere 39% of Tories voted Remain. It was Tory supporters, and the off-putting negative and pro-establishment message of the Tories and LabourIn, that cost us the referendum, not Jeremy. 

Like Jeremy, we supported Remain and campaigned hard for it. 

Sources: YouGov, plus Lord Ashcroft exit poll for SNP.
https://yougov.co.uk/news/2016/06/27/how-britain-voted/
http://lordashcroftpolls.com/2016/06/how-the-united-kingdom-voted-and-why/

John McDonnell MP, chair of the Jeremy for Labour campaign, responding to the decision by Labour's NEC Procedures Sub-Committee, said:

"This is a deeply disappointing decision by a small clique of people behind closed doors, many of whom have openly expressed their opposition to Jeremy Corbyn's leadership, who are now trying to use Labour members' money to fund what they think is a further attack on Jeremy. However, this is just an attack on the basic democratic rights of members in our party.

We are a democratic socialist party, you cannot have one without the other. I hope that Labour HQ rethinks this decision as it could leave a legal bill in the hundreds of thousands of pounds that we could be spending instead on campaigning to hold this Tory government to account, instead of subverting our own democratic processes.

Due this decision, we are now in the absurd position that Labour HQ is wasting members' money to prevent members having a democratic vote on the leader of their choice, which has already been firmly upheld by a High Court judgement."

status_message:
BREAKING NEWS ON HIGH COURT JUDGEMENT - STATEMENT FROM JOHN MCDONNELL:

John McDonnell MP, Shadow Chancellor and chair of Jeremy for Labour, responding to today's High Court judgement, said: 

"This is a huge victory for Labour Party members and party democracy.

The decision taken to freeze out new members since January was an affront to democracy and went against everything the party stands for.

We are pleased the High Court has seen sense today by coming to the right decision.

We are appalled by the possibility of an unnecessary and costly appeal. If it is taken forwards, the Party will be using members' money to try to stop members from voting. This is unacceptable.

I'm calling on Owen Smith to join with us in backing party members and calling on the Labour Party not to appeal and attempt to disenfranchise members.

We are now calling on the Labour Party bureaucracy to act sensibly and play by the rules for rest of this leadership election."

Richard Burgon MP lays our Labour's plans to scrap employment tribunal fees, which put a price on people seeking justice at work:

In a country where work is often insecure and low-paid, it is disgraceful that the Tory government has pursued an agenda of removing employee protections and denying access to justice at work.

The introduction of Employment Tribunal Fees in 2013 places a financial barrier to challenging employers over equal pay, sex or gender discrimination and a host of workplace issues.

Jeremy Corbyn announced his plans to extend the right to collective bargaining today:

"A Labour Party under my leadership will give you the power to transform your workplace.

Earnings in Britain have fallen for a decade. In many communities job opportunities are scarce. Millions face insecurity at work because of unscrupulous bosses like Philip Green and Mike Ashley. More than ever, we need a powerful voice in the workplace.

As a lifelong trade unionist, I know strong trade unions give people that voice. In government, we will introduce mandatory collective bargaining for big businesses.

We want to give collective representation to every person working in a business employing 250 people - so your wages, working hours, training, health and safety, overtime and grievance mechanisms will be in your hands.

Labour will protect workers by banning zero hours contracts and repealing the Trade Union Act - because no-one should have to live with the levels of insecurity workers currently face.

Labour should always be the party that fights for the rights of people at work. I have done so all my life. With strong trade unions, we'll build an economy where no one is left behind."

Jeremy's campaign is fired by the energy, enthusiasm and donations of people across Britain - and we're still waiting for a contribution from Irn Bru! 

If you can, please donate here:
www.jeremyforlabour.com/donate

In ten months Jeremy and John have drastically shifted the political narrative in Britain on issues like austerity and workers' rights. Last month John announced that the IER's "Manifesto for Labour Law", drafted by experts in response to the Workplace 2020 Consultation launched by Jeremy Corbyn in May, would form the blueprint for future Labour policy.

Key recommendations included:
- Reinstating a Ministry of Labour
- Reinstating sectoral collective bargaining across the economy
- Repealing the Trades Union Act

The Ministry for Labour, announced by John McDonnell last month,  will end the UK's current regional imbalances, with communities in the North of England having been left behind for far too long.

Under Jeremy Corbyn's future Labour government northern towns and cities will be prioritised, using the ¬£500 billion unlocked through a national investment bank and a network of regional banks to "rebuild Britain's industries after years of neglect."

http://www.ier.org.uk/news/shadow-chancellor-ier-manifesto-will-inform-future-labour-policy

Excellent article from David Wearing:
"This was not merely a case of Labour deferring to public opinion, which it was happy to defy over Iraq and the continued corporate ownership of public utilities. New Labour was primarily about deference to the established order, whether or not public opinion could be used as an alibi. At its worst, this led to a kiss-up-kick-down politics, where ministers preferred taking a hard line on asylum and immigration to standing up to the xenophobia of the gutter press, and where the harsh regime imposed on disabled people claiming social security contrasted sharply with the light touch approach to financial regulation."

On the Marr show today John McDonnell made an emotional plea to Labour MPs to stop the personal attacks on ordinary members of his staff: "We've got to stop this now... If you want to come for me and Jeremy Corbyn that's up to you, but don't pick on staff who can't defend themselves."

The Mail on Sunday sent an undercover reporter into Momentum's offices posing as a volunteer over the last five weeks. The resulting piece in today's paper contains a number of misleading allegations against Momentum. 

As with all parts of the Momentum network, the staff and volunteer team at the national office are committed to building a kinder, fairer society based on cooperation, compassion and social justice. The team have an open door approach and have always welcomed people who want to volunteer their time and skills. We remain absolutely committed to this philosophy and will not be deterred by underhand, cynical and exploitative attempts to derail us. For a more balanced representation of the Momentum team and how we operate, here is Owen Jones' Guardian video when he visited the same offices that the Mail on Sunday had its mole in: 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pKJxG38ctMY

Here is the statement we sent to The Mail on Sunday, which refutes and clarifies the allegations:

"The Mail on Sunday and Omar Wahid have exploited two of Momentum's strongest attributes: its enthusiastic and young activists and its open, welcoming approach. Wahid posed as a socially awkward volunteer of limited competence. As with other 'genuine' volunteers, he was warmly welcomed, given a variety of volunteer tasks to complete and offered friendship and kindness. In return, Wahid has undermined the trust and generosity of spirit of the Momentum team. It is particularly concerning that he appears to have targeted young, female volunteers and acted in a way that appears to proximate entrapment. 

In addition, he seems to have specifically targeted Muslim volunteers and activists in what looks like an attempt to smear them and Momentum as antisemitic. If this approach was indeed a deliberate strategy, it would appear to have Islamophobic undertones.

The Mail on Sunday's hypocrisy is striking. The paper used a mole, when also accusing Momentum of using a mole to find out about Tory party activities. It's clearly one rule for the right wing media and another for Momentum. 

T-shirts

If the allegations of the MoS are true, Momentum and one of its suppliers appear to have been misled by a third party supplier in relation to its labour practices. The order placed with this company has been cancelled and a new supplier sought with full ethical standards. 

Momentum is dedicated to championing rights at work both at home and overseas; we want every worker at home and broad to be in a trade union, and to enjoy the full protections that the ILO recommends as minimum standards. We will refuse to work with any supplier who does not uphold these standards.

MPAC

Momentum has no relationship with MPAC. Faduma Hassan has had no contact with MPAC either as an individual or on behalf of Momentum.

Wahid repeatedly asked Rob Lugg, who is a volunteer, not a "senior official", if he, Wahid, should be in contact with MPAC. Lugg response should be read in the context of his efforts to be polite to an apparently socially awkward volunteer. 

"Bullying"

Any bullying that is alleged will be investigated immediately, and any individual that is proven to have indulged in unacceptable behaviour will be dealt with through Momentum's code of conduct and, if necessary, stopped from any further participation in the organisation.

Sophie Nazemi, a 21-year-old volunteer, was clearly being humorous in light of the numerous unfounded allegations of bullying against Momentum. She joked that discussing Angela Eagle's voting record would be ridiculously and unfairly cast as "low key bullying" by Corbyn's opponents. Any claims that Nazemi is a bully, or endorses bullying or that Momentum is engaging in bullying are utterly false.

"Front organisations" and "proxies"

Novara Media is an independent media outlet. It existed before Momentum was launched. Aaron Bastani, the co-founder, negotiated access to Momentum to cover developments in the Labour Party. 

Michael Walker is a volunteer for Momentum. He also has made several appearances on Novara Media as a presenter. His volunteering for Momentum pre-dates his relationship with Novara Media. 

James McAsh, who is a volunteer not an "official", wrote an article for Novara about how the Labour's trigger ballot process works, in his own capacity. He often writes under a pseudonym. Other people who work for or volunteer for Momentum write articles on a range of subjects for a range of media outlets. This is not underhand but completely ordinary. 

The comments James Schneider made in the Friday 1 July meeting are very similar to ones given on the public record on the Today Programme on BBC Radio 4 the following morning, which were widely reported. He was speaking about embarrassing the failed coup plotters into putting up a candidate and stop attempting to subvert democracy in the Labour Party by forcing Corbyn out without an election. Momentum rejects any accusation that Schneider acted improperly.

Zac Goldsmith stunt

Momentum engaged in one successful media stunt during the London mayoral election to highlight questions around Zac Goldsmith's tax affairs. Momentum attempted a second stunt on the eve of polling. It was unsuccessful. Sadiq Khan's campaign team had no knowledge of the plans.

Update:

The Mail on Sunday put allegations about Marshajane Thompson to us which they did not publish. The Daily Mail did publish them the day before, including the incorrect claim that Thompson registered "more than 100 fake voters". 

Here is our statement sent to the Mail on Sunday:

Over a decade ago, Marshajane Thompson pleaded guilty to offenses of false instrument and false accounting, not electoral fraud, and completed community service. Marshajane's conviction is now spent. She has always been open about the conviction, which she still deeply regrets, with her employers. Momentum refutes efforts to smear Marshajane or Momentum.
link_name: Are you a bunch of far left extremists? | Owen Jones meets Momentum

status_message:
Jeremy summed this up perfectly at his grassroots campaign launch in Salford.

It's not a choice between building a movement or winning power. Without this movement we won't win power or deliver real, transformative change. 

If you missed the live stream check the video on our Facebook page, and sign up to get involved in Jeremy's campaign here:
http://www.jeremyforlabour.com/volunteer

Momentum to review ethical procurement policy

Momentum is to agree a rigorous system of checks on materials and merchandise to ensure a zero tolerance policy on unethical practices anywhere in the supply chain.

This move has been taken after allegations surfaced that Momentum and one of its suppliers may have been misled by a third party supplier in relation to its labour practices. 

The order placed with this company has been cancelled and a new supplier sought with full ethical standards. 

Momentum will be looking at successful ethical trade initiatives in order to draw up a code of practice capable of maintaining confidence, in spite of the complexity of modern supply chains, that all campaign materials have been produced by businesses that respect labour rights and human rights. 

A spokesperson said: "Momentum is dedicated to championing peoples rights at work both at home and overseas; we want every worker at home and abroad to be in a trade union, and to enjoy the full protections that the ILO recommends as minimum standards. We refuse to work with any supplier who does not uphold these standards".

At his launch today, to thousands of attending people in Salford and 1.8 MILLION people through the live stream, Jeremy Corbyn reiterated again his adamant opposition to any personal abuse in politics.

Labour's calling time on discrimination. It's been almost half a century since the Dagenham sewing machinists' strike for equal pay, immortalised in the film "Made In Dagenham", and the Equal Pay Act - and we still have a long way to go.

A recent investigation by the TUC of the top 10 per cent of earners showed that the gap in annual salaries between men and women working full-time rose steadily through each percentile, with the highest paid men paid a whopping 54.9 per cent more than their female colleagues. As Jeremy said yesterday: "We can and must do far better."

It's been forty six years since the Equal Pay Act, but women, disabled workers, the youngest and the oldest workers, and black and ethnic minority workers still face systemic discrimination. At the launch of Jeremy's campaign today he and Kate Osamor MP, Shadow Secretary of State for International Development, announced a series of policy measures, including pay audits, designed to stamp out this discrimination in the workplace.

As Jeremy said: "If our economy is to thrive it needs to harness the talents of everyone - so this is about making our economy stronger, the workplace fairer - reducing the discrimination that holds people back."

Read a summary and the full speech here:
http://labourlist.org/2016/07/corbyn-seeks-inspiration-from-beveridge-as-he-launches-leadership-campaign/

Let's start busting a few myths! Jeremy supposedly lead a "half-hearted" and "lacklustre" EU campaign, and/or secretly supported Leave. But he traveled 2,768 miles across Britain campaigning for Remain, making 123 public appearances all over the country (including 60 in just 22 days).

As Angela Eagle said in June: "Jeremy is up and down the country, pursuing an itinerary that would make a 25-year-old tired - he has not stopped. We are doing our best, but if we are not reported, it is very difficult".

"We've DEMOLISHED the case for austerity. No politician uses terms like "scrounger" any more. The Tory "long-term economic plan" is dead."

#JeremyForLabour

Deaf and disabled people on why they want #JeremyForLabour.

Since 2010 deaf and disabled people have been targeted for cuts and seen hard won rights and freedoms pulled away whilst the rich got richer ‚Äì the UK is now the first nation state to be investigated for grave and systematic violation of Disabled people's rights under the UNCRPD.

Through all this, while much of Labour was competing with the Tories on who could be the toughest on welfare, Jeremy and John stood with us and opposed the cuts.

Important Momentum Guidance on Voting in Labour Leadership Election - please read carefully and in full.

Many of our members and supporters will have watched in dismay as various restrictions were put in place to exclude hundreds of thousands of Labour Party Members and Supporters from voting in the upcoming leadership election.

We profoundly disagree with these moves, they are an attack on the democracy of the labour movement. A number of individual members are seeking legal advice, and the Labour NEC is due to meet again next Tuesday to further discuss these issues.

However, it is extremely important that members and supporters do what they can in the meantime to ensure they can take part in the leadership election. The options open are as follows:

‚Ä¢ If you are Labour Party member who joined before 12th January 2016 you should automatically have a vote. Please make sure the Labour Party has the correct contact details and address for you. You can do this at members.labour.org.uk or by calling 0345 092 2299 (better to do this online).

‚Ä¢ If you are a member of an affiliated trade union, or another affiliated organisation (e.g. The Fabians, LGBT Labour) and joined before 12th January 2016 then you can register as an affiliated supporter at support.labour.org.uk (if you registered last year you won't need to do so again unless your details have changed).

‚Ä¢ If neither of the above bullet points apply to you then, as things currently stand, if you want to vote then you will have to register between Monday 18th July and Wednesday 20th July and pay ¬£25 to be a registered supporter. You can register at support.labour.org.uk

If you can reasonably afford to pay the ¬£25 then we would strongly encourage supporters to do this from Monday.

We will keep our members and supporters updated on this issue as much as possible so watch this space.

With love and solidarity!
Team Momentum

#Jeremy4Labour #JezWeCanAgain
