Black People Matter - A statement in response to the Chakrabarti Inquiry Report by Jackie Walker, Vice Chair, Momentum Steering Committee 

Shami Chakrabarti's Inquiry into Anti-Semitism and Racism in the Labour Party made big news soon as it was published ‚Äì and for all the wrong reasons, just one of the ongoing consequences of the "occasionally toxic atmosphere" that is "in danger of shutting down free speech within the Party rather than facilitating it." Chakrabarti makes it clear her intention is not to "close down debate on delicate issues around all kinds of personal and political differences within the Party" but to conduct these debates "in a more trusting and constructive environment." My response is made with the same intent.  

As a recently suspended Labour Party member, and the only person as yet (at the point of writing) exonerated, I was bound to read Chakrabarti's report, and the coverage that followed, with more than a little interest. I write as a long time Labour Party and anti-racist activist for whom Chakrabarti's findings are personally and politically important. My partner is Jewish, his family observant, but I comment as a woman of mixed Jewish and other heritages who identifies as, and is perceived by others as, a black person of African descent. 

Much of the mainstream media response to the Inquiry focused on anti-Semitism, was superficial, poorly informed or with one intent - destabilising Labour and its present leadership. Chakrabarti's generally well expressed 'state of the Party' contextualisation of race relations, and her many well thought through and sensible recommendations, were sidelined as charges of anti-Semitism yet again took centre stage, immediately undermining the Inquiry's key findings on BAME (Black and Minority Ethnic) members. 
At the core of the debate is the way competing claims by minorities are positioned in the (at this point in time) supercharged arena of Labour Party politics. In the political arena, perhaps more than elsewhere, race is about power - who has it, who is chosen to represent the Party, who gives power to others and how that power is communicated. Two areas are highlighted in the part of the Chakrabarti Report that focuses on BAME members - that of representation and vocabulary. 

Chakrabarti begins with evidence; that in 2010 the BAME community voted for Labour more than double in relation to whites. She describes an unwelcoming environment and a lack of representation at all levels, including in Parliament, but also in the administrative structures of the Party, singling out the lack of black members in the NEC for special mention. What an irony then that it is the voices of people of colour, in particular those of African descent, that were so effectively sidelined in reporting of the Inquiry. 

In today's Labour Party Chakrabarti situates anti-Semitism within a set of feelings and responses as reported in many submissions by some in the Jewish community. Stereotypes limit the ability of peoples to be treated and respected as individuals and Chakrabarti's comments on the need for sensitivity in the language of debate, whether on issues that relate to Israel or elsewhere, are to be welcomed. But there is acknowledgement that it is power, or the lack of it, that excludes and discriminates against BAME people in the Party, as it does of course in the rest of society. Blacks do not only feel under-represented, or stereotyped in the Party. They are under-represented. They may be members and supporters, they are of course, particularly in Labour's urban heartlands, often the foot soldiers and voters, but BAME members are effectively excluded where it matters - from power.  

Given the terms Chakrabarti was given for her inquiry it is difficult to see how this could have been avoided. If anti-Semitism is set apart from 'other forms of racism', can we be surprised when the Inquiry fails to attract a significant number of submissions from BAME groups, or when black individuals are significant only by their absence at its launch?  The reception of the Inquiry in the media and elsewhere simply underlined the powerlessness of the BAME community. The paucity of any black response, at a national level, confirms the exclusion the report attempts to redress. In this three card trick discrimination against BAME members is the card that appears, I hope only for the moment, to have been made to magically vanish.

I come now to the issue of vocabulary, in particular comments on the use of the term 'holocaust,' a point that concerns many people of African descent who await both recognition or recompense for past wrongs inflicted. 

Chakrabarti makes plain her Inquiry is an attempt to bring people together. To stand in solidarity, as Chakrabarti suggests all minorities need to, people of African descent must see the structures that exclude them from power, and have kept them silenced for so long, being changed.  This is the only way in which attempts to build an inclusive Party will succeed. 

Groups that have suffered oppression need to have conditions, a level playing field, in which they can form united political fronts, working in solidarity with others, rather than having to fight for a place at the table, forever bogged down in disputes about equity, access to power, or the meaning of the past. If the Party does not succeed in this, Labour will remain entangled in the impossible task of being a moral referee as minority ethnic groups engage in a 'competition of victimhoods' in order to gain, build or protect recognition. 

Others have argued elsewhere for dropping the use of the contested terminology of 'holocaust' and replacing it with 'genocide'.  Some suggest opening Holocaust Day more fully to all communities that have suffered mass murder. As Jews retain the word Shoah, so peoples of African descent refer to Maangamizi for their holocaust. Maangamizi describes the slave trade and history of enslavement when millions of Africans were killed, tortured, kidnapped and enslaved for profit but it also refers to the genocides and deprivations of colonialism and the ongoing, consequential suffering and oppressions of peoples of African descent. 

I am in agreement with Chakrabarti there are, and can be, no hierarchies of suffering. The Inquiry rightly warns of dilution of effect 'if every human rights atrocity is described as a Holocaust'. However, I cannot see the term 'holocaust' as something the Labour Party can, or should police, though it may provide a useful forum where terminology can be discussed. As ever, the Labour Party must recognise the right of minorities to both name themselves and choose how their history is narrated.

It is in the ability of the labour movement to listen to the experience of people of African descent and other BAME peoples where I now place my trust. It is with hope that I ask that our leaders listen to the concerns of people of colour whose voices before and during the Inquiry, and even now, remain barely heard. I look forward to the changes to come.

Unite general secretary Len McCluskey has just issued an important statement refuting claims that Jeremy was responsible for Tom Watson's withdrawal from union-led efforts to re-unite Labour. Read it below:

"I am dismayed at the statement issued by Tom Watson announcing his withdrawal from talks aimed at resolving the crisis in the Labour Party.

"Extraordinarily I received no notice of this statement before it was issued. I had made arrangements for a meeting of trade union leaders, Tom Watson and representatives of the PLP and the Party Leader for tomorrow, arrangements requested by Tom Watson and his colleagues, specifically for Mr Watson's convenience.

"In that context, when the possibility of a workable plan had never seemed closer, Tom Watson's actions today can only look like an act of sabotage fraught with peril for the future of the Labour Party.

"I must clarify one point in Tom Watson's statement - I made it absolutely clear from the outset of these discussions that Jeremy Corbyn's resignation as the Leader was not on the agenda. Mr Watson knew that, and it is entirely wrong to suggest that any public statement by Jeremy represented any change in the situation. This is a deeply disingenuous manoeuvre.

"I will continue to work with trade union colleagues and others to chart a way forward, including meeting the legitimate concerns of Labour MPs. Should there have to be a leadership election, I must warn that any attempts to keep Jeremy Corbyn, elected just ten months ago with an enormous mandate, off the ballot paper by legal means risks a lasting division in the Party.

"It is time for everyone to commit to a democratic and dignified procedure as the only way to avert such a disaster for working people."

In 2003 Jeremy was at the heart of the anti-war movement. He and the two million people across Britain who marched against the war were right - and we need a statesman like him now more than ever.

This video features footage from Amir Amirani's powerful film "We Are Many" alongside Chilcot's presentation of his conclusions. It shows what we have known for years, and Chilcot has finally confirmed: Iraq was a disaster that didn't need to happen.

He will go on the ballot paper and he will win."

Statement on Personal Conduct 

Many Labour members and supporters across the country are disappointed and upset by the behaviour of a number of MPs in the past two weeks. The actions of some MPs have destabilised Labour and sought to subvert democracy.

In these difficult times, we must redouble our efforts to treat each other with respect. As Jeremy Corbyn has repeatedly stated, personal abuse has no place in our politics, whether in the corridors of Westminster, at a party meeting, or online. 

While MPs must do more to engage with their members to understand how members wish to change the party, members must understand the vital role MPs and their staff play, especially in their constituencies. We call on Momentum's members to not demonstrate outside MP's offices or surgeries.

Despite the difficulties of the past two weeks, Labour's membership has grown dramatically and now stands at over half a million, the highest in decades. Labour is now the biggest left of centre membership party in Europe.

As we grow and welcome new members, we must always keep in mind that we achieve more by our common endeavour.

This is what we consider leadership. 

Jeremy's statement in full:

"I now apologise sincerely on behalf of my party for the disastrous decision to go to war in Iraq in March 2003.

That apology is owed first of all to the people of Iraq. Hundreds of thousands of lives have been lost and the country is still living with the devastating consequences of the war and the forces it unleashed.

They have paid the greatest price for the most serious foreign policy calamity of the last 60 years.

The apology is also owed to the families of those soldiers who died in Iraq or who have returned home injured or incapacitated.

They did their duty but it was in a conflict they should never have been sent to.

Finally, it is an apology to the millions of British citizens who feel our democracy was traduced and undermined by the way in which the decision to go to war was taken on the basic of secret 'I will be with you, whatever' understandings given to the US president that have now been publicly exposed."
"I marched against the war, argued against it and voted against it. Labour needs to say clearly that the Iraq war was WRONG." - Diane Abbott MP

MOMENTUM'S STATEMENT ON THE CHAKRABARTI INQUIRY REPORT

Momentum welcomes the Chakrabarti Inquiry Report as an intelligent and sensitive engagement with a range of complex and highly emotive issues.

The Chakrabarti Report responds to the specific particularities of anti-Semitism within the broader context of anti-racism. Anti-Semitism and other forms of racism are real problems in British society and the Labour Party is not immune. Momentum recognises that being conscious of racism is the responsibility of all of us, we must all challenge racist ideas wherever they occur so that we can enable the Labour Party to be a political space where everyone can participate in discussion.

We also recognise the right of different communities to narrate their own histories using the language and terminology they are comfortable with while acknowledging the need for sensitivity and respect of how words may be perceived by other communities who have their own histories and experiences.

Finally, we welcome the Report's emphasis on the importance of establishing due process and natural justice in responding to complaints. It is vital that all in our party know that if they raise concerns they will be taken seriously and that everyone can have faith in the process.

We look forward to the full implementation of the report's recommendations.

Please read the report here, and share widely:
http://www.labour.org.uk/page/-/party-documents/ChakrabartiInquiry.pdf

*CANCELLED* Join us tonight at 7pm at Congress House, the home of the labour movement in Britain, to be part of a discussion with trade union leaders, MPs and activists about what we do next, and how we keep alive the new politics that triumphed last September.

A quarter of a million of us voted for Jeremy Corbyn last September. Since then all of us have worked hard, winning for Labour, and taking a new kind of politics out into our communities.

So it's been shocking to see our effort squandered by some MPs unable to accept Labour's decision, launching a determined and deeply undemocratic attempt to topple the leadership, in the middle of a national crisis.

Jeremy has made clear that he's going nowhere. He will need all of our help in sticking to that.

"In the aftermath of last week's referendum, our country faces major challenges. Risks to the economy and living standards are growing. The public is divided.

The government is in disarray. Ministers have made it clear they have no exit plan, but are determined to make working people pay with a new round of cuts and tax rises.

Labour has the responsibility to give a lead where the government will not. We need to bring people together, hold the government to account, oppose austerity and set out a path to exit that will protect jobs and incomes.

To do that we need to stand together. Since I was elected leader of our party nine months ago, we have repeatedly defeated the government over its attacks on living standards.

Last month, Labour become the largest party in the local elections. In Thursday's referendum, a narrow majority voted to leave, but two thirds of Labour supporters backed our call for a remain vote.

I was democratically elected leader of our party for a new kind of politics by 60% of Labour members and supporters, and I will not betray them by resigning. Today's vote by MPs has no constitutional legitimacy.

We are a democratic party, with a clear constitution. Our people need Labour party members, trade unionists and MPs to unite behind my leadership at a critical time for our country." - Jeremy Corbyn

(Photo credit: Jason Harris - www.harrisdpi.net)

All Labour Party members will soon get to vote in the elections for Labour's National Executive Committee (NEC). 

Here's a message from Jeremy. 

"I was honoured to be elected the leader of the Labour Party and since then our membership has doubled.
 
We need the enthusiasm and energy of all members of our Party to campaign for a better, more equal and more democratic society.
 
If you're in our Party and want to help shape its future - please take part in the elections for our National Executive Committee ‚Äì the NEC."

Yesterday 10,000 people (and that was the Police's figure) gathered in central London to show the Parliamentary Labour Party what democracy looks like. There were also other gatherings across the UK.

Nearly 300 thousand have now signed petitions supporting Jeremy as leader of our Party. 

Today at 4pm, MPs will hold a vote of no confidence - because those MPs are not listening to the vast majority of their members.

So we need to be even louder and make them listen.

We need to be very clear that their juvenile vote has no power - if they want a leadership election, there are procedures to trigger one and they should get a candidate and stand against Jeremy.

We all now need to make our voices heard. Here are some ways you can:

Momentum will fight for Corbyn 

Momentum pledges its total commitment to Jeremy Corbyn as leader of the Labour Party. The last thing the country or the Labour Party needs in the Brexit confusion and before a snap general election is the Party to have a needless leadership election. 

Let's be clear; this attempted coup is unwarranted, undemocratic and irresponsible - as well as a waste of time and money.

If there is a leadership election, Jeremy will automatically be on the ballot paper. Momentum will campaign tirelessly for him, and he will win. 

In an attempt to further destabilise the leadership and undermine the membership's support for it, rumours have been peddled today that Momentum doesn't support Corbyn and instead wishes to back John McDonnell. These rumours are categorically untrue. They are lies designed to do harm to our movement.

Momentum exists to create the social movement Jeremy promised, on which Labour will depend to beat the Tories and cut though public disenchantment with the failures of the political elite.

John McDonnell told the Sunday Politics earlier today that he will be the chair of Jeremy's leadership campaign should reckless MPs force an irresponsible leadership election on the Party.

The division promoted by a section of the parliamentary party is the last thing we need. 

We call for unity and for all of the PLP to get behind Jeremy and the Labour Party to offer a programme of hope for our people.

The below is a statement from union leaders backing Jeremy Corbyn to continue as Labour leader.

The Prime Minister's resignation has triggered a Tory leadership crisis. At the very time we need politicians to come together for the common good, the Tory party is plunging into a period of argument and infighting. In the absence of a government that puts the people first Labour must unite as a source of national stability and unity.

It should focus on speaking up for jobs and workers' rights under threat, and on challenging any attempt to use the referendum result to introduce a more right-wing Tory government by the backdoor. 

The last thing Labour needs is a manufactured leadership row of its own in the midst of this crisis and we call upon all Labour MPs not to engage in any such indulgence.

 

Len McCluskey, General Secretary, Unite the Union

Dave Prentis, General Secretary, UNISON

Tim Roache, General Secretary, GMB

Dave Ward, General Secretary, CWU

Brian Rye, Acting General Secretary, UCATT

Manuel Cortes, General Secretary, TSSA

Statement on Britain's vote to leave the EU

Yesterday, the British people voted to leave the European Union. Momentum, which campaigned to remain in the EU to transform the EU, respects the decision taken by the electorate.

We recognise that people voted 'Leave' for many reasons. Much of this vote reflected anger in communities which have experienced many years of industrial decline with the subsequent loss of secure employment. Many such working class communities have been utterly neglected for years by those in power. Millions appear to have chosen 'Leave' to vote against the unfettered globalisation that has seen living standards stagnate or fall, as the cost of living rises. We share this scepticism of big business dominance, austerity and distant elites, be they British, European or Global, and share that demand for a country where working people have control.

Many 'Leave' voters usually vote for Labour or are working people Labour should represent. Now the Party and the whole labour movement needs to show the country that it alone can offer working people genuine control over their lives, workplaces and communities.

Labour must clearly demonstrate how it will improve lives through policies that will increase wages, tackle the housing crisis, and give people a greater say at work and in their communities.

If we do not, we will not only be failing to advance the policies that will benefit working people but also could enable the populist right, who blame immigrants, not the powerful for the problems in our country. Part of the Leave campaign empowered these racist, reactionary forces, who peddle hatred and offer false hope. We must redouble our efforts to stop migrant scapegoating, focus our attention on the needs and desires of the overwhelming majority, and offer a real programme of hope for our people.

Although we will leave the EU, our movement remains an internationalist one. We must continue to work with our friends, partners and allies across Europe in the shared struggle against austerity, to tackle climate change and to build a sustainable economy with full employment for all the peoples of Europe.

As the polls tighten, the prospect of a victorious Gove-Johnson-Farage axis has jolted thousands of activists, old and new, into action. Fed up with the EU debate being dominated by 'Project Fear' and men in suits arguing with each other, there has been a huge, last minute surge in activity across the country from volunteers organising citizen-led doorknocking, phonebanking, leafleting and other actions through our Your Referendum platform.

Today, Momentum and Another Europe is Possible organised hundreds of people to gather at the Thames today. As Farage's Brexit flotilla passed by Westminster, activists dropped a 100 ft banner over the side of Westminster bridge with the message, "Don't let Farage sink Britain. Vote remain."

The hypocrisy of Farage pretending to be on the side of Britain's fishing industry was a little too much to take, given that he has
attended just 1 out of 42 meetings of the European Parliament's Fishing Committee. 

Instead, over a 100 people, many of whom are young and new to politics, are expressing their positive vision for a social Europe, where fishing communities, and all workers, have rights and protection; a reformed Europe based on cooperation, rights for workers, opportunities for young people and environmental justice.

#BoatRemain #AnotherEuropeIsPossible

As the debate around the EU becomes increasingly focused on xenophobia and scaremongering, now more than ever, we need to show our support to the refugees in Europe fleeing war, crisis and persecution. 

Momentum is joining together with other progressive forces in Britain to show solidarity and support to the refugees in Calais. There will be music, shared ideas and celebration of humanity.

It's not too late to join Momentum activists and others from around the UK, and get involved: http://www.convoytocalais.org/

Solidarity with all of the victims of yesterday's terrible attack in Orlando, Florida. This was a hate crime specifically directed against gay people because they were gay.

Any attempt to deflect this as Sky did here in an interview with Owen Jones is simply unacceptable. 

If someone kills Jews because they are Jews, it's an anti-Semitic hate crime and nothing else. If someone kills black people because they are black, it's a racist hate crime and nothing else. If someone deliberately goes into a gay venue and kills 50 people because they are gay, it's a homophobic hate crime and nothing else. 

Our solidarity needs to go 100% with the LGBT community and the reaction of some commentators and politicians is shameful for trying to make this appalling crime out to be something it was not.

In the event of Brexit, our movement would be left trying to defend some of the most basic workers' rights, rather than fighting to shape what the future might look like. As the leaders of Unite, Unison, GMB and other unions emphasise, "We simply do not trust this government if they are presented with an unrestricted, unchecked opportunity to attack our current working rights."

We're fighting for a different kind of Europe from the Tories, but this can only be achieved working together with our allies across the continent. We're In for a worker's Europe ‚Äì not a Tory Brexit.

In March, Momentum carried out a survey asking you what campaigns it should prioritise. Here are the results:

1. Defending the NHS (56.3%)
2. Promoting public ownership of public services and utilities (34%)
3. Providing political and economic education (19.7%)

Thank you everyone who filled in the survey and participated. A consultation and campaign development process for our members will commence after the EU referendum.

http://labourlist.org/2016/06/momentum-picks-nhs-as-top-campaign-after-exhaustive-poll-of-members/

Over the years, workers in Britain and Europe have fought for and won some fundamental rights at work which are currently protected at the level of the EU; from maternity and paternity leave, to guaranteed paid holidays.  These are currently protected at the level of the EU. These basic rights are far from sufficient - they need to be built on and expanded. A Tory Brexit, however, promises "a bonfire of workers' rights, brutal welfare cuts, crippling tax hikes and devastating job losses". We must stop it.

Check out the article to find out more, and visit our #YourReferendum page to join the campaign to Remain in Europe ‚Äì and change Europe for the better. There are two weeks left to prevent this disaster - let's make every day count!

http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/after-brexit-boris-johnson-pm-8153471

http://yourref.peoplesmomentum.com/

On 23 June, Britain will take the massive decision to remain in or leave the EU. Sadly, many feel that much of that debate so far has been an alienating squabble between different factions of the Tory Party. But this isn't their referendum, it's your referendum.

That's why Momentum and Another Europe is Possible, who support a progressive remain vote, have created #YourReferendum, a crowdsourced, online platform for campaigning and organising tools to take the debate out of Westminster and into our communities.

YourReferendum is your platform to take back this referendum from the Tories, UKIP and 'Project Fear' and make it yours.

Find out more at http://yourref.peoplesmomentum.com/

Donating will help us empower as many citizen activists as we can in these vital closing stages of the referendum. It's your referendum, not just theirs. Get involved.

Donate to our Crowdpac today.

https://www.crowdpac.co.uk/campaigns/37/yourreferendum
link_name: It's Your Referendum: Momentum for IN

status_message:
In November 150 Momentum activists descended on Oldham to help Labour win the parliamentary by-election - with an increased majority.

We're doing the same THIS weekend in Tooting, Sadiq Khan's old seat, where junior doctor Rosena Allin-Khan is fighting to keep the Tories at bay and ensure another Labour victory. If you can make it, we hope to see you there, for two days of campaigning and picnicing! Join at any of the times below, or just give us a call when you can get there and we'll let you know where we are (07516 387098). Canvassing is very simple and if you haven't done it before you will be able to shadow those who have ‚Äì everybody is welcome!

On Saturday meet at 112 Mitcham Road, SW17 9NG at 10am (closest tube Tooting Broadway). Lunch will be provided at a local restaurant, inbetween canvassing from 10am-12pm and 2-4pm.

Rhea Wolfson's campaign for Labour's National Executive Committee is still ongoing. Following the incredible amount support she has received, it's clear there is a massive demand for what she offers the party: important perspectives and promoting a credible democratic socialist agenda, and to empower members to fight for a more democratic party that can deliver change. Read her full statement: 

"Thank you so much for all the kind tweets, messages, endorsements, and nominations. Without these I might have given up last week, with them I am convinced that we can win.
This campaign is not over.

Last summer, I moved back to Scotland to provide end-of-life care for my father. Since then, I have split my time between my family home and that of my partner. I am sure that many other young members will find this kind of living arrangement very familiar!

Labour Party rules stipulate that members should register at only one address, and therefore only one Constituency Labour Party (CLP). Despite spending more time, and being more politically active, at my partner's, I have been registered at my family home. This is, in part, due to an emotional connection to the area: it was here that I first campaigned for the Labour Party in 2005, and where I volunteered in my local MSP's constituency office when still at school.

Last week, I was unsuccessful in securing a nomination from Eastwood, the CLP I grew up in. I released a statement on this and will not be commenting further. Since then, I have been overwhelmed by the support I have received from members up and down the UK. This has confirmed for me the reasons why I first wanted to stand: to promote a positive and credible democratic socialist agenda, and to empower members to fight for a more democratic party that can deliver change.
I have transferred my membership to my other address and will seek nomination from my home CLP. If successful, I will be an officially nominated candidate for Labour's National Executive Committee."

#WeSupportRhea
https://www.facebook.com/rhea4nec/

The NHS is currently undergoing a massive reorganisation in order to reduce its services and further entrench privatisation. It is an absolute scandal that private companies should be able to profiteer in our publicly funded health service.  NHS campaigners are fighting to stop this with the the NHS Reinstatement Bill.

On Tuesday 28th June, at 5pm, an important meeting will be held in parliament to brief MPs on the issue, organised by campaigners and chaired by Rachael Maskell MP, Labour MP for York Central and former head of health at Unite.

We can all help by writing to our MPs and asking them to attend this meeting and support the Bill. If there's a strong turn-out of MPs at the meeting, there's a good chance that the Bill will be re-tabled again in the Commons as a cross party Bill presented by Labour.

So please get writing, and let's save our NHS!

http://www.nhsbill2015.org/what-is-your-mp-doing-28-june/

http://www.parliament.uk/get-involved/contact-your-mp/

Migrants are net contributors to Britain's economy and society, and tens of thousands of them work in services like the NHS. But in austerity Britain, local services can easily come under pressure, and people can become alarmed about the changing nature of their communities. A lot of these concerns have fuelled opposition to the EU, and contributed to the rise of UKIP. Today Jeremy Corbyn set out the case for staying in Europe, and the pragmatic Labour argument for managed migration:

"[People concerned about migration aren't] Little Englanders, xenophobes or racists. More people living in an area can put real pressure on local services like GPs surgeries, schools and housing.

This isn't the fault of migrants. It's a failure of government. The coalition government in 2010 abolished the Migrant Impact Fund; a national fund to manage the short term impacts of migration on local communities. By abolishing it, David Cameron's Coalition undermined the proper preparation and investment that communities need to adapt. 

We cannot and should not want to close the borders. But we do have to make sure that public services are able to sustain the communities we have here, part of that is through a Migrant Impact Fund, but partly too it is about reversing the damaging and unnecessary austerity policies that this government continues to impose on our communities and our country."

http://labourlist.org/2016/06/corbyn-a-labour-government-will-block-ttip/

Jeremy Corbyn's unlikely Labour leadership bid and Leicester City's even more unlikely Premiership campaign shows that the remarkable can happen and another future is possible. We seek to establish a broad alliance of football fans, players, teams and organisations that, not only want to make football more inclusive, democratic and fair but also want to use football itself as a force for social, political and economic change.

Constituency Labour Parties (CLPs) are currently nominating candidates for elections to Labour's highest governing body between conferences - the National Executive Committee (NEC). CLP nominations close on 24th June and then all members will receive a 'one member one vote' ballot in early July. 

Momentum is backing the election of the Centre-left Grassroots Alliance (CGLA) candidates. These candidates support Jeremy's leadership and will help build support for progressive, socialist policies within the Party.

Ken Livingstone was initially one of the CGLA candidates but as he is currently suspended from the Party he is unable to stand. Therefore, Rhea Wolfson has been added in his place. 

Rhea, who last year actively supported Jeremy Corbyn's leadership campaign, is a young Scottish activist, Co-Chair of the Co-op Party Youth and GMB activist. She said "Our party needs to be strong and united, with all levels of the party working in a transparent and tolerant manner. I will work to empower members, local parties, and activists; to fight for a more democratic party that can deliver change - and ultimately, deliver victory." 

To support Jeremy's leadership, please consider encouraging your CLP to nominate the CLGA candidates: Rhea Wolfson, Ann Black, Claudia Webbe, Darren Williams, Christine Shawcroft, and Pete Willsman. 

If you would like more information about this, please contact: info@peoplesmomentum.com

A Thank You Email From John McDonnell 

On behalf of the Labour Party and its leadership, I would like to express my sincere thanks to each and every Momentum member and supporter who played a part in our tremendous effort to secure Labour wins in the elections last week.
Whilst we have a long way to go to rebuild our trust with the electorate in Scotland, there is a strong showing for Labour in England and Wales. These results are a real improvement on the 2013, 2014 and 2015 local elections and show that Labour under Jeremy leadership has a firm base to build from. 48% of councillors elected last week are Labour, in comparison to the Tories' 30% and Labour are not just the biggest party, but have an overall majority in 58 of the 124 councils up for election.

What is more, we held our own or advanced in key marginal councils with Tory MPs, including: Worcester, Redditch, Derby, Ipswich, Norwich, Harlow, Crawley, Southampton and Hastings. Not to mention the four excellent Labour mayors we've elected in London, Bristol, Liverpool and Salford. I know that Momentum groups have been particularly active in many of these areas, and indeed elsewhere, so thank you for the remarkable impact you have made.

What is perhaps most heart-warming of all, is the knowledge that Momentum groups played a key role in mobilising many new and less experienced activists. Jeremy's leadership inspired many tens of thousands of people to join Labour and get involved in politics for the first time, and now that fresh energy lives on in Momentum.

Searching #Momentum4Labour on social media shows months of Momentum's superb campaigning for Labour, with the "Six O'Clock Squad" in Plymouth, Sheffield's solidarity road trips to Rotherham, the #WheresZacsTax stunts and #JezWeKhan post-canvassing socials in London, Momentum groups are pioneering creative and engaging ways of doing politics.
So, now what? We have a solid Labour base in England and Wales, but there is much more work to be done. If you're not already, I would urge you join the Labour Party and to join Momentum as well. Becoming a member of Momentum will enable to you to be part of and shape a growing network of people and groups who are committed to building a more democratic and equal society and see a Jeremy-led Labour Party in government.

There has never been a better time to get involved in politics.

Join Labour and Join Momentum. Let's build our movement.

Join Momentum (www.peoplesmomentum.com/join).

In solidarity,

John McDonnell
Shadow Chancellor of the Exchequer 
@johnmcdonnellMP

A statement from Momentum on the suspension of Jackie Walker from the Labour Party:

Momentum condemns the suspension of Jackie Walker, Vice Chair of our Steering Committee, from the Labour Party on 4 May. Jackie, a black activist of Jewish heritage and lifelong anti-racist campaigner and trainer, was suspended by the party for alleged antisemitism following an article that appeared in the Jewish Chronicle, which quotes statements she made on Facebook discussing her family history.

We are extremely concerned by the lack of due process in this case, and the failure to apply the principles of natural justice. Journalists were briefed about Jackie's suspension by party staff before she had been informed. Indeed, she is still yet to receive any formal notification of either her suspension, the basis for it, or a timetable for her hearing. As the suspension was not briefed to the press as 'without prejudice', it has been interpreted by some as a presumption of guilt before any process has taken place. 

Momentum calls for the immediate lifting of her suspension and for new rules to be put in place by the party to govern the handling - and the press briefing - of sensitive disciplinary matters, and for all suspensions to be agreed in advance by NEC members after the person concerned has the right to make representations.

Momentum unambiguously condemns antisemitism and welcomes Jeremy Corbyn's launch of an expert-led inquiry. 

We hope that this inquiry is the start of a process of investigating how all forms of racism and oppression that exist in society replicate themselves in any way within the Labour Party. For the labour movement to fight racism and oppression effectively, we need comradely self-criticism, education, and awareness raising of these complex issues. We pledge that Momentum will play a productive role in this process.

status_message: The Tories made the London election a referendum on Corbyn. He won, decisively. Congratulations to Sadiq Khan and all who campaigned hard for a Labour Mayor in the face of vicious attacks
Congrats and huge thanks to Momentum activists who have been campaigning tirelessly for Labour victories. Our hard work has paid off!

Today's election results show that despite the hostile media speculation, there is strong support for Jeremy's Labour, especially in key battle grounds in the South and the Midlands.

A huge thanks to all the Momentum supporters out on the streets, making a crucial difference to the outcomes in target Labour councils - Harlow, Crawley, Southampton, Hastings, Worcester, Exeter, Birmingham, Derby and Cannock Chase.
Never doubt that our combined actions can make a big difference.

Of course, there is much more work to be done. Of course, it's not going to be easy. Of course, the Labour Party and Labour movement must continue to adapt and grow.

But today, we should stop and recognise that we have a lot to be hopeful about. Onwards to Jeremy for PM in 2020!

status_message:
Today, we stand in solidarity with the striking Junior Doctors. Tens of thousands of hard-working doctors have been forced into a situation where removing their labour is a last desperate measure to stop Jeremy Hunt and the Tories from imposing a contract which they know will put patient safety at risk. 

Until this industrial dispute, doctors haven't been on strike for over 40 years and yet 98% voted in favour of strike action. What does this tell us? 

1)  Jeremy Hunt has completely failed to deal with this situation and has allowed it to escalate to an all out strike. He is not fit to be Health Secretary.

2) David Cameron has also completely failed to intervene and handle this dispute, allowing a Health Secretary to impose a contract against the will of 98% of those it is being imposed upon. He is not fit to be Prime Minister.

3) This attack on the pay and conditions of Junior Doctors is part of a broader agenda to undermine the core values and principles of our publically funded health service, free at the point of care. The Tories are not fit to be in government.

This government has shown that they have little regard for our NHS. If we let them, they will systemically dismantle it over the next 4 years. All that can stop them is us. Our collective action.

Be sure to pay the Junior Doctors a visit on the picket lines today. Take them some cakes or a cup of solidariTEA to show your support. Share your photos with us on Facebook and Twitter. #JuniorDoctorsStrike
Let's be in no doubt who is to blame for the Junior Doctors Strike tomorrow. #Solidarity

Momentum calls for public ownership of Britain's steel industry as part of a forward-looking industrial strategy.

As the steel crisis threatens Britain's industrial capability, thousands of jobs, and the devastation of entire communities, the labour movement urgently needs to put forward a coherent, progressive alternative to the government's wilful inaction.
That is why Momentum is calling for permanent public ownership of the steel industry as part of a forward-looking industrial strategy.

With steel publicly owned by workers, communities, and a strategic state, the UK will be better placed to develop a high tech, high productivity economy, which grows our industrial base and produces shared prosperity. Public ownership will give working people control over a strategic asset to develop our economy, build homes, improve our national infrastructure, and support public services, as well as safeguard the workers and communities that built the steel industry.

We are not calling for control from Whitehall but a genuinely democratic public ownership, run by workers and communities with strategic input from the state.

We support Labour's campaign to expose the Tories' indifference to the steel industry, steelworkers and their communities and call on Labour to adopt permanent public ownership as part of an industrial strategy as party policy.

The government is in crisis. Now is the moment to demand our alternative. 

On Saturday, join Momentum either on the doorstep canvassing for Labour wins in the May elections or at the Labour bloc demanding Health, Homes, Jobs and Education at the People's Assembly national demonstration in London.
If you're coming to the demonstration, meet at the Byng Place corner of Gordon Square Gardens, WC1H 0PQ at 12:30 pm on Saturday 16 April to collect your free JC4PM placards.  Look out for the Momentum and Labour banners. For more information, and to invite others to the bloc, click here.

Whether we're canvassing for Labour or marching the streets, our messages are the same:

*The junior doctors are out on strike defending our NHS. Their fight is our fight: we demand a fully funded, publicly owned NHS.
*Council tenants are mobilising against the Housing Bill to reduce the cost of housing for all. Their fight is our fight: we demand secure, affordable homes for all.
*Trade unionists are fighting the Trade Union Bill's attacks on our political liberties and freedoms at work and steelworkers are challenging the Tory's wilful inaction to save our steel industry. Their fight is our fight: we demand extended rights at work and a genuine living wage for all.
*Teachers, parents and students are organising against the forced academisation of schools. Their fight is our fight: we demand investment in our futures and an end to marketisation.

#Momentum4Labour #4Demands
https://www.facebook.com/events/661801893962120/

Interesting company our PM keeps. 

As the media frenzy fades, we mustn't let Cameron and the Tories off the hook. Tax avoidance and evasion is immoral. It is literally taking money out of our schools, hospitals and public services. Despite the revelation last week that he personally benefitted from offshore banking, we are yet to see a full tax return from Cameron. 

Whilst Jeremy's Labour make the strong case for tax justice in Parliament, it's down to us to make the case on the #LabourDoorstop and on the streets this weekend. So join Momentum all across the UK, either canvassing for Labour wins in the May elections or in London for the national demonstration for Health, Homes, Jobs and Education (see here for more info: https://www.facebook.com/events/661801893962120/).

Last night, 19 year old Momentum volunteer, Beth, chaired the launch of Consensus in Parliament. 

The successful launch featured a positive panel discussion with John Cruddas MP, Seema Malhotra MP, Stephen Kinnock MP and Cllr Sam Tarry. John McDonnell popped in to join the audience of MPs, Labour members and supporters from across the Labour spectrum.

Momentum Steering Committee member, Sam Tarry, was well received by the room when he called for the Labour Party to embrace the ideas, energy and wisdom of the new membership. He called for investment in community organising and digital campaigning to engage more people in politics and build a credible economic alternative that works in the interests of the many. 

John Cruddas and Stephen Kinnock both condemned members of the Parliamentary Labour Party who brief the media against the new leadership, calling the behaviour "disgraceful." 

Whilst it was recognised that consensus may not always be reached on areas of genuine political difference, it was highlighted that there is overwhelming consensus for Labour as an anti-austerity party committed to delivering a more democratic and equal society.

I'm sure we'll all be pleased to engage in a more consensual style of politics. After all, it was Jeremy's new kind of politics that inspired many tens of thousands of people to join the Labour Party last summer.

http://labourlist.org/2016/04/consensus-launch-cruddas-calls-for-boundaries-to-curb-plp-in-fighting/
link_name: Consensus launch: Cruddas calls for "boundaries" to curb PLP in-fighting | LabourList

Insightful reflections from Yannis Gourtsoyannis, Camden Momentum activist and member of the BMA Junior Doctors Committee.

Teachers and Doctors are custodians of a powerful idea; that everyone has the right to a flourishing life. That's why this Government wants to break us"

We live in interesting times‚Ä¶.

We seem to have a government ruling by decree. A government contemptuous of democratic norms.

A few weeks ago this Government made clear that it would attempt to impose a new doctors' contract upon the junior doctors; and the same Government only a few days ago also signaled its intention to force "academisation" onto every school in the country. These two "impositions" (against the counsel of both the medical and teaching professions) are the latest examples of a nasty authoritarianism that seems to lie at the heart of the Conservative project.

By simultaneously imposing far-reaching and unevidenced reforms on both teachers and doctors the Conservatives want us to perceive this authoritarian style of government as the "new normal". They will not succeed in that. There is no way that we doctors are going to accept this deplorable state of affairs, and it looks like teachers won't either.

The Conservatives have form on this kind of thing.

Take school academisation for example. When I read about the new Government white-paper I was struck at how similar their tactics are to the manner in which they rolled-out a previous piece of pernicious and damaging legislation. 4 years ago the Government initiated the most far-reaching top-down reorganisation that the NHS had ever seen; the Health and Social Care Act 2012. This ended the government's duty to provide a comprehensive and universal health service in England. It deepened existing market mechanisms within the NHS and opened up the NHS to external private providers of health care (all this occurring along the biggest squeeze on health funding since the inception of the health service).

School academisation is directly analogous to the above process.

It is an attack on the very idea of comprehensive education.

Just as the new Academy "chains" can absolve themselves of the obligation to educate every child in any given geographical area (and "cherry-pick" instead), so too do the new NHS CCG's absolve themselves of treating all patients in a given geographical area. Just as academisation is justified as simply an attempt to put power into the hands of Teachers and Headmasters so too was the same claim made about the Health and Social Care Act; that it was about "empowering clinicians".

The reality of both process it that they reduce accountability. Both processes encourage private sector involvement. Both processes undermine national bargaining on terms and conditions. Both processes erode national minimum standards. Both processes do nothing to solve the recruitment and retention crises faced by our respective professions.

So, whilst both processes are touted as benign and devolved they are in-fact highly centralised and undemocratic, whereby all hospital trusts and all schools are being forced to accept their new "independent" status. We are witnessing a centrally directed fragmentation of both the health and education services; with a view to enabling privatisation by stealth.

The Government have shown that they have no qualms about misleading a compliant media and systematically misinforming the public.

But we, teachers and doctors, will not be misled. Because we share something more than just the huge responsibilities of our day to day jobs.

What we share is an insight. An insight into how harsh society can be as well as how magnificent, and vulnerable, human potential is.

We therefore have a direct view of exactly what this government is trying to do.

We know that rising child poverty means that those born today will from their very first few days on this Earth start to feel the indelible imprint of austerity on their cognition, their bodies and their social relationships.

We know about the moral necessity of a robust welfare state to provide for the disabled and the troubled.

We have first-hand experience of the unequal life trajectories of patients and pupils within a sharply delineated class society.

We see the consequences of social breakdown on a daily basis and we are the ones who pick up the pieces.

As doctors and teachers, we (along with other NHS and education workers) are some of the last, remaining representatives of the social democratic consensus in this country. 
 We are the custodians of a powerful idea: that everyone has the right to a flourishing life.

And the fact that we together are the bedrock of that social democratic consensus is the very reason why this conservative government is gunning for us, why it wants to break us.
 The government will not succeed. Although they are they are trying their utmost best to tear apart the social fabric of this country Cameron, Osborne and Hunt have failed to take into account one crucial thing‚Ä¶..the determination of tens of thousands of determined doctors and teachers.

As trade union members we stand ready to defend our services. By standing up for ourselves, we stand up for patients, for pupils and for the future of a civilised society.

Doctors are escalating their action as we go into April.

On the 26th of March, teachers at the National Union of Teachers voted to ballot for industrial action.

We are probably entering the most important period of industrial action in a generation.

The Government is right now at its weakest and most divided.

It's authoritarianism is a sign of desperation and haste.

We are entering the endgame.
 How this plays out will determine the kind of country that we bequeath to the future.

Well, this just about sums up the Tories. 

Yes, this made us chuckle - but now we must build a credible, compelling alternative to ensure these people have no place in government.

A powerful poem written by an activist in Scarborough, beautifully summing up the sentiment shared by so many people dissatisfied with the status quo.

Now, the question is: what should we do with the anger so many of us rightfully feel? How can channel this towards building a compelling and credible alternative? How can we make the changes we want to see in our communities? 

Any ideas? Please share below.

"Why are you so angry?"

I was asked the other day
I said: I'm angry about long hours
I'm angry about low pay
I'm angry about the boss
Who'd hand a family man his cards
Then say we'll get the same
If we don't all work twice as hard
I'm angry about closed hospitals
Fire Stations, Schools
I'm angry that the papers
Feed the bigotry of fools
I'm angry that elections
Yield a government that gloats
They have a working mandate
With a quarter of the votes
Or that refugees aren't welcomed
And instead we justify
The reason why we turn our backs
While hungry children die
I'm angry for the homeless
The hopeless and the lost
I'm angry that compassion
Comes in second now to cost
I'm angry for equality
Still screaming to be heard
Above the empty gestures
Above the wasted words
I'm angry at statistics
How they've come to run this land
How the tail it wags the dog now
While the dog it bites your hand
I'm angry that this island
Where we once shot fascists down
Now queues in droves to cast its votes
To let them run this town
I'm angry that your colour
Your culture, creed and class
Define you and resign you
To being written off en masse
So don't you dare say I'm ungrateful
I should be happy with my lot
You wonder why I'm angry?
I wonder why you're NOT.

Joe Solo

The housing crisis may be at its most acute in London but it affects millions of households all around the country. Now, as the chronic shortage of housing drives Londoners out of London, cities like Birmingham and Manchester look set to become part of the London commuter belt with the arrival of HS2, with knock on effects for natives of those cities who will, in turn, be priced out.

Will we allow the blight of this crisis to continue to spread? Or will we fight for a radical solution that provides truly affordable housing for all?

Up to 18,000 mums to lose free childcare as Labour slams 'broken' Tory election promise: 

"Childcare in Britain is in crisis thanks to broken Tory promises according to new analysis released by Labour .

The stats show 18,000 single mums will be excluded from the 30 hours of childcare promised in the Conservative election manifesto.

And a government report released this week showed more than half of mums who are out of work said they would prefer to go to work if they could get childcare."

Jenny Chapman MP, Labour's Shadow Childcare Minister, said:

"This is yet more evidence that the Tories are letting parents down and are breaking their promises to single mums up and down the country.

Their childcare plans are a complete mess and many parents say they're not able to access childcare due to high costs and a lack of places."

http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/up-18000-mums-lose-free-7503659
link_name: Labour blast 'broken' promises as thousands set to miss out on free childcare

More devastating news on the jobs front. Expect a lot more if this in the coming months. Recovery, what recovery? 

"Energy firm Npower is to cut up to 2,500 jobs, more than a fifth of its UK workforce, with an announcement to staff expected this week.

Npower, which is owned by the German energy giant RWE, employs 11,500 people in the UK and is one of the country's big six gas and electricity suppliers."

Unison general secretary Dave Prentis said: 

"These huge job losses will come as a devastating blow to the workforce."
[The cuts will] "leave the already struggling business in an even worse state"

Eamon O'Hearn of the GMB union said:

"Many hard-working staff have already been outsourced and so any further job losses for directly and indirectly employed staff would be another kick in the teeth for communities."

The Unite union's Kevin Coyne said:

"It is an inexcusable way for the company to treat a loyal workforce which has worked hard to turn Npower's record on customer service around in the last year."

http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-35740275

status_message:
Very few people are aware of how privatised the NHS already is, and how much of it has been sold off - unsurprisingly, as there has been very little coverage in the mainstream media: 

"Yet, tragically, the present government is doing its best to dismantle the NHS, with the ultimate goal, it would seem, of replacing it with the US model. The Health and Social Care Act of 2012 put an end to the mandate for the state to provide comprehensive healthcare to every resident of England free at the point of use, and has allowed for-profit companies to buy up huge chunks of the NHS (¬£10 billion worth of contracts have already been handed out since the Act was passed).  The Tories know the US system performs worse on every conceivable count, but they are willing to go there anyhow: the healthcare market-in-waiting is just too juicy to leave untapped.

Bevan knew that the NHS would face opposition from powerful private interests, but he was hopeful that it would prevail: "The NHS will stand," he said, "as long as there are those who will fight for it." Many Britons are doing just that. But, thanks to skillful government subterfuge, the vast majority do not even know that their cherished healthcare system is under threat, and many others don't understand what it's like to live with the dysfunctions of a private alternative.  It's sometimes hard to realize how good something is until it's taken away from you. To England, I say, take it from an American: what you have is as good as it gets, and it's worth defending. Your civilization depends on it."

https://www.opendemocracy.net/ournhs/jason-hickel/take-it-from-american-britain's-nhs-is-as-good-as-it-gets

Via Momentum in Bristol and the West of England
link_name: Take it from an American - Britain's NHS is as good as it gets

status_message:
They gave us the weekend, the eight-hour day and the paid holiday. Now they need our help. Please make a start by signing the petition to David Cameron, George Osborne, Sajid Javid: "scrap the Trade Union Bill. It's undemocratic, unnecessary and deeply unjust.":

"This is terrifying. The government is about to eliminate our rights to collectively bargain for safe working conditions, fair wages and healthy working hours -- and we have just weeks to stop it.

In the biggest attack on workers' rights in 30 years, David Cameron's government is pushing through legislation that will bring our trade unions to their knees.

It will make legal strikes all but impossible, potentially criminalise picketing, allow corporations to hire strike-breaking agency staff and introduce rules that are aimed squarely at bankrupting unions. And that's just for starters.

Our trade unions are worth defending. They protect ordinary workers -- care workers, teachers, nurses, shop workers, cleaners -- from poor conditions, low pay and unfair dismissal. But now they need our help -- and they need it fast, before the Trade Union Bill has its second reading in the Commons in just a few weeks' time.

David Cameron: scrap the Trade Union Bill. It's unnecessary, undemocratic and deeply unjust."

http://action.sumofus.org/a/trade-unions-cameron/
link_name: They gave us the weekend, the eight-hour day and the paid holiday. Now they need our help.

"This general forum meeting is open to Labour party members AS WELL AS TO supporters of Momentum who are not members of any other political party.

"The number of homeless people found sleeping rough in recycling bins is growing, according to one of the biggest waste management firms in the UK. Why is this happening?

"In the park, you do get abused and kicked and stuff like that. The other night‚Ä¶ a few young guys were walking past, and one of them just booted me right in the face.

status_message:
Via the Trades Union Congress (TUC): 

"As the Trade Union Bill continues its passage through the House of Lords it is worth reminding ourselves about the potential implications for health and safety. As Frances O'Grady said in Hazards Magazine, the Bill will allow the Government to restrict the time given to trade union health and safety representatives in the public sector, allow agency workers to be used during strikes, thereby creating potential risks, and restrict the ability of workers to strike over safety issues.

At committee stage the Lords were particularly critical over the attack on health and safety representatives, as the debate shows, and were concerned that the Government was now threatening to force unions to restrict the time taken by health and safety representatives by bundling all time off together and imposing a single cap." 

http://strongerunions.org/2016/03/01/safety-representatives-still-all-to-play-for/

Nice report in the Hackney Gazette on the People's Philosophy, Politics and Economics (PPE) initiative kicked off by Momentum activists in London:  

""Debt is to capitalism what hell is to Christianity", Yanis Varoufakis told an audience at the Round Chapel on Tuesday, "horrible, but absolutely necessary".

More than one thousand people had packed out the Clapton venue to hear the self-styled "recovering former finance minister of Greece" speak at a free panel event, 'The Hitchhiker's Guide to Economics'.

The talk was the second in a series of lectures and workshops for People's PPE, a new initiative across Hackney and Tower Hamlets designed to empower the grassroots and engage 'ordinary people' in philosophy, politics and economics.

The event organiser, Imad Ahmed, is also an English teacher at Clapton Girls' Academy. He said: "Democracy cannot function without knowledge.

"People's PPE was born out of a need to find out what the false dogma are that exist about politics and economics, and see whether we can educate ourselves to make better informed choices.""

http://hackneycitizen.co.uk/2016/02/29/greek-finance-minister-yanis-varoufakis-peoples-ppe/

#PeoplesPPE
link_name: Yanis Varoufakis speaks truth to power at Clapton economics talk

Brilliant little initiative! Well done Little Atoms:

"These very junior doctors have a message for Jeremy Hunt:

What's better than a junior doctor? A junior junior doctor!

With the threat of junior doctors' strikes looming, one group of patriotic young Britons has taken up the challenge of tending to the nation's poorly in unsociable hours for no money: step forward the junior junior doctors.

Eighteen London children aged between six and twelve years old gathered in Limehouse Town Hall, east London during half term to learn the basics of junior doctoring from their striking elders.

After a long day of tuition in all the skills needed to run a busy A&E department over a weekend with no sleep  ‚Äì including suturing, bandaging and even minor operations ‚Äì the young medics came to a conclusion: Being a junior doctor is hard, and they probably deserve good working conditions."

#JuniorDoctorsStrike

http://littleatoms.com/society/these-very-junior-doctors-have-message-jeremy-hunt
link_name: These very junior doctors have a message for Jeremy Hunt | Little Atoms

Great letter signed by over 70 medics criticising the Tories for eroding NHS workers' ability to provide good quality care: 

"Over the last five years, the Conservative Party's relentless austerity drive has eroded the welfare state and, as NHS workers, our ability to provide good quality care to the millions who rely on our services is being hampered.

Recent governments have targeted the NHS for cuts and 'reform' in order to mould it into an institution primarily geared to serve private sector interests.

Deliberate underfunding, as well as the recent attack on the working conditions of junior doctors, threatens patient care and the long-term sustainability of the NHS.

Furthermore, the Government's proposed scrapping of NHS student bursaries will limit the healthcare professions only to those who can fund their own training.

Furthermore, the Government's proposed scrapping of NHS student bursaries will limit the healthcare professions only to those who can fund their own training.

Our public services must be preserved for the welfare of all who need them and we ask everyone to join the demonstration in London called by the People's Assembly Against Austerity on April 16 in the March for Health, Homes, Jobs and Education.

Only by working together will we have the means to resist these attacks effectively and to safeguard these services for the future use of the many - not just the few.

Yannis Gourtsoyannis, BMA Junior Doctor Committee

Mona Kamal, Junior Doctor

Danielle Tiplady, Student Nurse, NHS Bursary Cuts Forum

If you are a health worker and want to add your name to this letter, along with 70 others, please go to the People's Assembly website: 

http://www.thepeoplesassembly.org.uk/healthletter
link_name: More than 70 medics signed this letter blasting the Tories for 'eroding' the NHS

The Tories hack their way through yet more of the safety net. Disgusting: 

"Charities slammed the Tories tonight for surging ahead with disability benefit cuts despite a major defeat in the House of Lords.

MPs have renewed plans to cut Employment and Support Allowance (ESA) by ¬£30 a week - ignoring a desperate protest from a Tory backbencher who declared: "This is my warning shot to government".

Heidi Allen's speech made an 11th-hour plea for her own party to find "the compassion to look after the little man".

"Today I will not support [the government]. Today I may abstain, but only for today."

But her plea fell on deaf ears as a motion to challenge the House of Lords, which struck down the cuts last month, was passed by 306 votes to 279.

MPs also voted 310-277 against a Lords decision to reverse the scrapping of child poverty targets - which are being replaced by "shameful" measures that don't count parents' income."

This callous government will be forcing millions of already poor children into further poverty by their ideological and draconian cuts programme. Unacceptable: 

"More than 7 million children living in low-income families will be affected by a four-year freeze to their benefits that risks pushing many more into poverty, according to new research.

A report by the Children's Society, published on Tuesday, says families could lose up to 12% from the real value of their benefits over the next four years as a result of government plans to freeze child tax credits, working tax credits and jobseekers' allowance from April.

The charity is calling on ministers to reconsider the planned freeze and agree to a moratorium on any further cuts in support for low-income families. It says almost two thirds of those who will be adversely affected live in working households who receive benefits to top up low pay."

The UK government's focus has been on infrastructure spending and policies that favour development ‚Äì the housing and planning bill now going through parliament includes several measures aimed to ease development.

TTIP deal poses 'real and serious risk' to NHS, says leading QC:

"The controversial transatlantic trade deal set to be agreed this year would mean that privatisation of elements of the NHS could be made irreversible for future governments wanting to restore services to public hands, according to a new legal analysis.

The legal advice was prepared by one of the UK's leading QCs on European law for the Unite trade union, which will reveal on Monday that it has been holding talks with the government about the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) deal between Europe and the US.

Unite believes the government has been keeping Britain in the dark over the impact of the deal and argues the NHS should be excluded from the trade deal. The government dismissed the idea that TTIP poses a threat as "irresponsible and false"."

status_message:
This coming Saturday 27 February, Momentum will be marching with many thousands of people calling for Britain to scrap Trident. 
 
Later this year, parliament will vote on the renewal of Trident; a decision which would save over a ¬£100 billion of public money. Opposition to Trident is mounting around the UK, not least with the landslide victory of Jeremy Corbyn as Labour leader. Despite being called a nuclear deterrent, many are questioning whether Trident actually makes us safer against the 21st century threats of terrorism, cyber-attacks or climate change. 

By scrapping Trident, Britain would be taking a brave and moral step on the international stage, making a nuclear-free world more likely (and freeing up ¬£100 billion over the next decade!). 

Watch this video for more info:

http://moveontrident.org/

or take a look at this Labour CND Factfile:

http://www.labourcnd.org.uk/2016/02/labour-cnd-trident-fact-file/

Join the Momentum and Labour CND bloc at Cumberland Gate, near Marble Arch, London, W1C 1CX at 11.30 am (the demonstration begins at 12 noon). 

See the Facebook event page for more details:

https://m.facebook.com/events/213766388976389/

We are delighted that Jeremy will be speaking at the rally along with many others.  

Coaches are leaving from all across the UK - see the travel map on the CND website for more information if you are travelling from outside London:

http://cnduk.org/component/k2/item/2312-stop-trident-demo-transport-to-london

Many Momentum groups are holding public discussions in the coming weeks - see our new events page for more information:

http://www.peoplesmomentum.com/calendar?utm_campaign=trident_3&utm_medium=email&utm_source=momentum

If you can't be there on the day, please help spread the word on social media using #Momentum and #StopTrident.
 
If you are a Labour Party member and would like more information about how you can submit contributions Labour's Defense Review before 30 April, please click here:

http://www.labourcnd.org.uk/2016/02/labours-defence-review/

Be part of this growing movement, for a more democratic, decent and peaceful society.

In solidarity,

Team Momentum

http://www.peoplesmomentum.com/

Network Rail earmarks 18 major stations for privatisation in bid to tackle debt:

"State-backed Network Rail is preparing to sell its biggest stations to developers and shopping centre landlords in its first substantial act of privatisation since moving on to the government's books nearly 18 months ago.

Bankers at Citigroup have been hired to look at options for 18 major stations, such as London Waterloo, Reading, Leeds and Edinburgh Waverley, which most eye-catchingly include either outright sales or the handing of concessions to big firms that would last decades."

http://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/network-rail-earmarks-18-major-stations-for-privatisation-in-bid-to-tackle-debt-a6886551.html
link_name: 18 major British railway stations have been earmarked for privatisation

Those with least being hit hardest again by this Tory government: 

"Low-paid private sector workers will be the worst-hit as 20million people lose out in a Tory pensions shake-up, experts have claimed.

Shocking analysis says those on less than ¬£15,000 a year will be badly affected as perks introduced under Labour are axed.

Chancellor George Osborne is launching a "simpler and fairer" ¬£155.65-a-week flat rate pension this April in the biggest shake-up for 40 years.

But although that's much higher than today's ¬£115.95 basic rate, it will no longer sit alongside top-ups called the additional state pension."

http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/tory-pensions-shake-up-will-7410549

Astonishing. Where's the transparency with these decisions? Or is this how Malcolm Rifkind earns his ¬£60k a year crust? Good investigative piece by Solomon Hughes: 

"An ¬£80 million contract to run cancer scans for the NHS has been given to a private health firm with a Tory MP on their board, despite a rival NHS consortium allegedly offering to carry out the work for ¬£7 million less.

The NHS Trust that runs Royal Stoke University Hospital in Staffordshire put together a consortium with other NHS hospitals to enter what they called a "competitive bid" for a 10-year contract to run scans across Cheshire, Staffordshire, Shropshire, Liverpool, and Lancashire. The scans, known as PET-CT, are mostly used for diagnosing and measuring cancers, and are a vital tool for fighting the disease.

However, NHS England, the "head office" of the health service, rejected the bid from state-run providers and instead awarded the contract to Alliance Medical, a private health firm whose board members include leading Conservative MP Malcolm Rifkind."

http://www.buzzfeed.com/solomonhughes/nhs-contract-stoke?utm_term=.mvdvdgVX4#.ovDajo6DY
link_name: NHS Contract Awarded To Private Firm Despite Rival Bid Being "¬£7 Million Cheaper"

Candidates supported by Momentum have swept the board in the party's youth elections. Congratulations to all those who were elected and commiserations to those who missed out. It's great to see a re-energised and enthusiastic youth section, obviously inspired by Jeremy Corbyn's victory in the summer and determined to re-engage young people in the Labour Party:

"Momentum activist Max Shanly, who was elected to regional board of Labour's south-east region, said: "The left did well because we organised the unorganised. We intend to continue doing so as representatives of Young Labour so as to fulfil Labour's historic role as a vehicle for the liberation of working people and their families."

Momentum have been helping delegates who are struggling to afford the high cost of the conference, with bursaries: 

A Momentum spokesperson said: "Momentum supports democracy in the Labour party, which is why we are offering bursaries to young members so they can attend Young Labour conference later this month. We look forward to seeing how the new Young Labour Committee engages with young people in the party, advances their interests, and broadens the party to attract and support more young members.""

http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/feb/19/jeremy-corbyn-momentum-sweeps-board-at-labour-party-youth-elections?CMP=Share_iOSApp_Other

Privatisation by stealth. Does anyone think this is in the best interests of children in Wiltshire, the staff or the future of the NHS?

"NHS staff working in child health services in one West county have been told they have a new boss ‚Äì Richard Branson ‚Äì after health chiefs unilaterally privatised their entire department in a ¬£64 million deal.

All community child health services in Wiltshire will be privatised, with council and NHS bosses defending their decision saying it was the best way to ensure a 'consistent' service across the county.

But leaders representing the staff being transferred said they had real fears the move would mean a worse service for more money, which they said was what happened when taxes were paid for 'profits and shareholders'."

Read more: http://www.westerndailypress.co.uk/Wiltshire-s-entire-NHS-Children-s-Services/story-28192161-detail/story.html#ixzz40bWWLfYC 
Follow us: @WesternDaily on Twitter | WesternDaily on Facebook

status_message:
The fact that some people might have call packages that exempt them from this charge is not the point. If this scandalous policy stops anyone from claiming their rightful benefits or pushes anyone into further poverty, it should be stopped in its tracks: 

"Struggling families will be charged up to 45p a minute to claim benefits over the phone on government helplines. 

The work and pensions secretary, Iain Duncan Smith, is refusing to set up a freephone number for the estimated eight million people who are set to claim the new universal credit over the next four years.

The decision contradicts the Department for Work and Pensions' pledge to make calls for all major benefit claim lines free.

Labour MP Frank Field, chair of the Commons work and pensions committee, said: "There is something really disturbing about the idea of people on their uppers having to incur a hefty phone bill just to talk to somebody about their benefit claim.""

http://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/feb/17/iain-duncan-smith-refuses-to-set-up-freephone-for-families-claiming-benefits?CMP=fb_gu
link_name: Iain Duncan Smith refuses to set up freephone for families claiming benefits

status_message:
The exodus of skilled, expert and trained junior doctors has already begun because of this Government's recklessness: There were 300 applications to leave the country on the day Jeremy Hunt said he will impose contracts - just 24 a day were granted last year

"Medics' bids to work abroad leaped by more than 1,000% as they learned new contracts will be forced on junior doctors against their will.

There were 300 applications to leave the country on the day Jeremy Hunt announced the move - up from 24 granted per day last year and 14 per day since 2008.

Labour, the British Medical Association and Royal College of GPs had all warned medics would "vote with their feet" and abandon the NHS when contracts start being imposed in August.

Today BMA junior doctors' committee chairman Johann Malawana said the figures were "absolutely horrendous".

He added: "This government needs to stop putting politics before the future of the NHS.""

http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/junior-doctors-bids-work-abroad-7388267
link_name: 1,000% more doctors try to leave Britain as Jeremy Hunt unveils his new contract
