status_message:
From James Matheson, a delegate member of Momentum's National Committee. James is taking part in the Bethlehem Marathon to raise money for Medical Aid for Palestinians. He suffered a spinal cord injury in 1979, and is raising money to support facilities in Gaza for people with spinal cord injuries. Please support: 

"Having suffered a spinal injury in 1979, I am only too aware of the importance of the medical facilities and the appropriate medical personnel necessary for effective rehabilitation.  

During the Israeli army's onslaught on the Gaza Strip in the summer of 2014, this most 'moral army' was given the coordinates of institutions which serve the humanitarian needs of Gaza's residents. The hope was that this would give Israel no excuse for obliterating the infrastructure for life to continue in Gaza. 

Although provided with locations of medical facilities, facilities which are given protected status in times of conflict, the deliberate destruction of Al-Wafa Rehabilitation Hospital in Gaza during the summer of 2014, has left no treatment facilities, nor equipment, for those who suffer spinal injuries.  Twisted debris is all that remains of both equipment and hospital following Al-Wafa's destruction.  

With work and fundraising going on elsewhere to rebuild hospital facilities, my aim is to support MAP's joint programmes of training Palestinian neurosurgeons and purchasing much needed equipment for individuals who have suffered a spinal cord injury."

Of course, it's no surprise that Jeremy Hunt's arguments don't stack up - this isn't about patient care, it's about attacking the terms and conditions of junior doctors and dismantling the NHS: 

"Jeremy Hunt's key argument in his demands for a seven-day service in NHS hospitals has been called into question by his own department, in a leaked report which says it is not able to prove that fuller staffing would lower the numbers of weekend-admitted patients dying."

http://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/feb/15/weekend-effect-on-hospital-deaths-not-proven-say-hunts-own-officials
link_name: Weekend effect on hospital deaths not proven, say Hunt's own officials

It's #heartunions week and today Momentum activists at our London office stood with thousands of other Trade Unionists around the UK to celebrate our union membership.

We'll be working locally and nationally with unions and union members to fight the tory (anti) Trade Union Bill, and for Jeremy Corbyn's policy of a comprehensive set of union and workers' rights under the next Labour government.

For more on the campaign go to: http://heartunions.org/

#heartunions

The junior doctors dispute, coupled with the way the Government has dealt with it, has unleashed a tide of discontent amongst ordinary people up and down the country. Millions are outraged at the way that Jeremy Hunt has announced that he will impose a contract on junior doctors and many people understand that this is part of a sustained attack on the NHS, preparing our most treasured institution to be carved up and privatised by stealth. 

All this is clear. The anger is palpable. But it needs expression and channeling. One small way in which we can do this is on social media - on Facebook and Twitter especially. So we'd like to ask Momentum supporters to contribute. We'd like you to share your personal messages of support for the #juniordoctors. If you have a meme, a video, a GIF animation or anything else shareable that we could use, please email it to info@peoplesmomentum.com. Please put #juniordoctors in the subject field. We'll then share the best.

Thank you,

Team Momentum

This week is #heartunions week. With Tory attacks mounting by the day, we all need the strength of a union. There's no time like the present to join a union. See more here: 

http://heartunions.org/

Tomorrow, (Saturday 13/02) local Momentum groups in partnership with Brick Lane Debates, Verso Books and Red Pepper are hosting Corbynomics: An Everyday Guide at the Karibu Education Centre in Brixton. 

Over the course of three participatory sessions on busting tory economic myths, fighting local austerity and generation rent, we'll hear from activists and academics and attempt to connect economics with the everyday, discuss how communities can resist and explore the kind of caring, co-operative, post-austerity economy Corbyn should be arguing for. 

10am - 5pm, Karibu Centre Brixton, 7 Gresham Road, SW9 7PH. Tickets: FREE on Eventbrite here (donation on the door):

https://www.eventbrite.ca/e/corbynomics-for-everyday-life-tickets-21078651815

Given it's Valentines we're hosting a special party at Xperience on Loughborough Road at 7pm after Corbynomics. Come along, enjoy our rhythms of resistance and show your love for all the junior doctors, librarians, council tenants, students and others who have been left broken-hearted by this government. 

Facebook event here:

Concert to Calais is a music tour aimed at bringing supplies and raising awareness of the plight faced by those across the channel. 

The tour will start in London on the 20th of March, and will visit Bristol, Southampton, and Brighton, before finishing in Calais.

All gigs are free to attend, and attendees will be asked to bring supplies, which will be collected from each venue and taken over to Calais. 

The tour is completely crowd funded, and set up by 24 year old Tom Harvey, who is an supporter of Momentum. Please support this if you can. Details here:

https://concerttocalais.wordpress.com/

"Jeremy Hunt is not in many NHS workers' good books.

Interesting piece by Greg Foster - Sink estates are people's homes ‚Äì they don't need to be demolished:

"David Cameron has vowed to spend ¬£140m demolishing Britain's "sink estates" ‚Äì the worst public housing developments ‚Äì and replacing the notorious concrete tower blocks with elegant mid-rise complexes or modern glass flats. But if the experience of tenants in Bratislava, Slovakia, is anything to go by, this won't solve Britain's housing problems.

We don't know whether the brutalist nature of high-rise buildings causes poverty and crime, but relocating tenants and their problems is not the answer. There is another way: we have worked with tenants in public housing in Poland, Romania, Hungary and Armenia to resolve maintenance issues and improve living standards in their homes."

http://www.theguardian.com/housing-network/2016/feb/03/demolish-sink-estates-homes-david-cameron-bratislava?CMP=share_btn_fb
link_name: Don't demolish the sink estates ‚Äì they're people's homes

"I want to use this as a way to help other women in this position. Never apologise for your sexuality. Never apologise for your successes. But you should never accept something like what I faced yesterday, because it is only in our reaction, that we can show them exactly, what we are made of."

link_name: I'd Never Been Ashamed for How I Look or for Being Proud of Who I Am - Until Yesterday

status_message:
"Yesterday, I wrote a blog about the Jeremy Corbyn tour ‚Äì known as #JC4PM ‚Äì which the media had failed to cover. I wanted people to know about the existence of the tour, but I also wanted to alert people to the fact that none of the newspapers I contacted were interested in reporting it. Journalist after journalist told me that the story was 'not newsworthy'.

'Not newsworthy' is obviously not a scientific term. It's purely subjective. And it's also plain wrong if you consider what the #JC4PM tour is.

The #JC4PM tour was drawn up in the same spirit as the rallies that were organised by local activists during Jeremy Corbyn's leadership campaign. It was spontaneous. Comedians, musicians, poets and political activists were all enthusiastic about putting on big shows to show solidarity with Corbyn and to rally the troops in the same way as he had last summer. We were not asked to do this by the Labour Party - or even by Jeremy Corbyn's office. It was something we drew up together.

There is a fantastic range of talented people who will perform or speak for Jeremy, including Charlotte Church, Michael Rosen, Brian Eno, Ken Loach, Billy Bragg, Mark Steel, Jeremy Hardy, Francesca Martinez, Mark Serwotka, Shappi Khorsandi, Arthur Smith, Patrick Monahan, Janey Godley and many more. Some big names have said they are happy to perform but they are booked up for the dates we have already planned. So there are even more surprises to come."

The #JC4PM tour starts at the O2 Forum Kentish Town on Thursday. Tickets start at ¬£10 and can be bought online at http://o2forumkentishtown.co.uk/
link_name: The Jeremy Corbyn story that nobody wanted to publish

status_message:
Good piece by Margaret Corvid: 

"I'm a Labour member, a Momentum member, and a lifelong socialist who joined, like so many, because the election of Jeremy Corbyn as leader filled me with hope.

I'm a rabble-rousing, placard-waving leftist, but these days, you're likely to find me on the doorstep, Labour sticker affixed to my suede jacket, talking to voters. I'd like to encourage other members new to the party, particularly my fellow socialists inspired by Jeremy, to join me.

...In Plymouth, as in many other places, our Momentum group is vibrant and strong, and I hope to see everyone who is able on the doors and phones, speaking to voters. I passionately believe in Momentum's mission to reform the Labour Party, and I believe that this election gives us our chance. In my first time canvassing, I and other new members knocked doors alongside Tudor Evans, the leader of Plymouth City Council, and many other experienced Labour activists. In our shared work, we get to know each other; many a fruitful dialogue might start as a chat between two rain-soaked volunteers drinking tea before heading out for another round. Political activity shapes us; by working to win this election, we new members can help shape our party."

status_message:
Please support this petition. It can't be right that the cost of Labour Party Youth Conference is literally pricing young members out of democracy:

"To: Iain McNicol, General Secretary of the Labour Party

Please launch a crowdfunding campaign amongst the Labour Party membership to pay for delegates passes, accommodation and travel to Youth Conference in Scarborough on the weekend of the 26-28th February 2016.

Why is this important?

Despite attempts to persuade him privately, Iain McNicol, General Secretary of the Labour Party, is refusing to budge on the cost of Youth Conference. Labour are already charging elected delegates ¬£40 for their conference pass (seven times the national minimum wage for most young members), this is without provision for accommodation or travel, meaning in reality the cost of Youth Conference will come to ¬£200 or more for most delegates. This is the first Youth Conference in two years and the first youth elections conference in three years. Delegates have been elected by the entire youth membership regionally to represent them at #YL16, the lack of funding to get delegates there is pricing young members out of democracy and only the Party can resolve this issue.

Unless this issue is resolved, Young Labour's democracy runs the risk of looking like that of pre-universal suffrage Britain, in which only those with wealth will have the right (or ability) to vote; the Chartists, whose struggle led to the creation of the Labour Party, would not be impressed.

How it will be delivered

I intend to email the list of signatures to Iain McNicol as well as handing them to him in person."

Please sign here (and share):

https://you.38degrees.org.uk/petitions/launch-a-crowdfunding-campaign-to-get-delegates-to-young-labour-conference-yl16
link_name: Launch a crowdfunding campaign to get delegates to Young Labour Conference #YL16

"I come from a coal mining family who, by the time Thatcher came in, had won half decent wages, better working conditions, for a life outside of work and decent, secure housing. Privatisation in some instances has eroded all this. In many industries the job you thought was secure, no longer even offers you the kind of guarantee that lets you be sure about how much money you will make that week. We've always had to vote for Labour though because it was the least bad option. For the first time in a long time, the Labour Party has a leadership who offer a real opposition to the Tories and is anti-austerity and anti-war policies. We shouldn't be fighting about this in the party. This is what it should Labour was supposed to stand for. I want Momentum to encourage and publicise public support for Corbyn and McDonnell's politics. They are not alone - many people are against what this government is doing."

Richard Murphy, director of the campaign group Tax Research, said the "extraordinary" deal did not represent value for the British taxpayer:

status_message:
GE Healthcare: US healthcare giant makes fortune from NHS but pays hardly a penny in tax.

Remember,these are tax revenues that could and should be going towards public health services, social care and keeping our public services afloat. Instead it's lining the pockets of executives and share holders:

"One of the biggest suppliers of equipment and testing services to the NHS pays barely any corporate tax in the UK, despite receiving hundreds of millions of pounds a year from medical sales to British clinics and hospitals.

A study of GE Healthcare's accounts by The Independent suggests it has received more money back in tax benefits over the past 12 years than it has paid in, with the taxpayer appearing to be missing out on millions of pounds a year in lost revenues."

Gail Cartmail, assistant general secretary of the Unite, said: 

"The NHS is under massive financial strain: the tax contribution we all make is vital to the health of the nation. It's a national disgrace that private companies which profit from our health service can get away with having tax avoidance structures in place."

http://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/health-and-families/health-news/ge-healthcare-us-healthcare-giant-makes-fortune-from-nhs-but-pays-hardly-a-penny-in-tax-a6828446.html

status_message:
Solidarity with student nurses, who will be walking out in protests over cuts to their bursaries at the same time as junior doctors are on strike on February the 10th. Let's make sure plenty of Momentum groups are there too to offer their support: 

"Student nurses, midwives, and allied health professionals (AHPs) are planning a week of protests over cuts to their bursary from 8 February that will include a placement walkout during the junior doctors strike on 10 February.

The government recently announced that in a bid to create 10,000 more course places, it will replace the bursaries available to student nurses, midwives, and AHPs with loans, starting next year.

Instead of receiving an NHS bursary payment of up to ¬£4,491 while studying and completing full-time training placements, students will be expected to take out loans to fund their living costs ‚Äì trade union Unison has estimated the loans will see student nurses qualifying with around ¬£50,000 of debt.

On 9 January, thousands of student nurses, midwives, AHPs, and their supporters marched to Downing Street to protest against the switch to loans, and from 8‚Äì14 February, they will undergo a week of action to further dispute the changes. Action will include walkouts by those who are on work placements during the scheduled week of protest.

"The protest made a big impact, and helped us get a lot more people on board, but we need to keep the momentum going," one student nurse involved in organising the week of action who preferred not to be named told us.

"This isn't going to be an overnight win. It's our right to speak out and protest.""

http://www.buzzfeed.com/laurasilver/student-nurses-are-planning-a-week-of-protests-over-cuts-to#.rkDO1R3Dg
link_name: Student Nurses Will Walk Out During Junior Doctors Strike In February

status_message:
Great piece by Aditya Chakrabortty in the Guardian:

"These are our economic elites as they want the rest of us stuck on the flatlands below to see them: big-thinking, well-intentioned, hard-working ‚Äì and thoroughly meritocratic. This is also how they justify the mammoth rewards they enjoy: we sweat for it; we're worth it. The follow-up is usually only implied, but it is the one that underpins the entire system: put in enough hours and this could be you.

Set against that promise the finding from Oxfam that 62 billionaires have more wealth than half the world's population ‚Äì 3.5 billion people ‚Äì share between them.

Ponder those numbers for a moment because they make up possibly the most grotesque ratio in the world economy today. Go through the 62 richest people and plenty of names jump out to show that any notions of meritocracy are a big fat lie. None of those 3.5 billion men, women, boys or girls will be born into a fortune such as that enjoyed by the Waltons of Walmart fame, in which just six people own $149bn. Nor will they ever get to be a Saudi royal such as Prince Alwaleed bin Talal, worth $26bn."

http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/jan/19/davos-super-rich-wealth-inequality?CMP=share_btn_tw#img-1Aditya

A list of 42 loss-making branches has been released by the Post Office and many could now face closure.

Three of those, Barry, in South Wales, along with Antrim and Shaftesbury Square Belfast, in Northern Ireland look set to be shut outright.

"Ministers are being accused of "waging war" on Parliament by using a little-known device to push through profound and controversial changes to Britain's laws without proper debate or scrutiny.

Since the election the Conservative Government has used a parliamentary procedure called a statutory instrument to try to introduce swathes of significant new laws covering everything from fracking to fox hunting and benefit cuts without debate on the floor of the House of Commons."

Jeremy Corbyn says he will donate the ¬£6,000 raised by supporters to buy him his 'dream bike' to charity

"Jeremy Corbyn will donate the money raised by supporters to buy him his "dream bike" to charity, he has said.

This week Mr Corbyn was slated in some sections of the press after he recommended a ¬£475 aluminium-framed Raleigh Criterium when asked about bikes in an interview.

Despite the Criterium being a standard-priced commuter bicycle, the Daily Telegraph reported the story under the headline "Socialist Jeremy Corbyn reveals he covets a ¬£475 bicycle."

The headline was later changed, but not before criticism from Mr Corbyn's supporters on social media.

In a spirit of defiance, supporters raised nearly ¬£6,000 to buy Mr Corbyn the bike, chiefly to "annoy the right wing press", according the project's creator.

The bike was suggested as a present for Mr Corbyn's birthday, which is in May.

The Labour leader however told the Independent on Sunday that he would give all the money to charity and buy the bike himself for his 67th birthday, as a "treat".

Asked if he would accept the money raised online, Mr Corbyn said: "Of course not. I'll give it to charity."

status_message:
Why I joined: 'I believe in the NHS, the welfare state and Labour values'. Part of a great Guardian series looking at new Labour Party members and their outlook. Here's Joe Bryce: 

"I had always voted Labour. Always. That was until there came a point where I just couldn't any more," Joe Bryce, 54, from Glasgow says. "Iraq was the heart of why I left the Labour party."

Bryce, a lawyer, is one of the thousands of former party members from across the UK who have returned to Jeremy Corbyn's Labour after leaving while Tony Blair was leader.

He lives in a city that comprehensively rejected Labour in the general election, and looks set to do the same in May's Scottish parliament elections. Despite that, Joe is now cautiously optimistic for the future of his party.

"We're on the way back. It won't be easy, but it can be done.

"I was a member of the Labour party because I believed in the NHS, the welfare state and traditional Labour values," he says, "and too often we didn't live up to those values."

Political parties are generally tight-lipped about their membership numbers, but figures suggest that between the start of the Iraq war in 2003 and Labour losing the 2010 election, 70,000 people left the party.

Revealed: how Jeremy Corbyn has reshaped the Labour party
For some it was an immediate reaction, tearing up membership cards the day that MPs voted for the invasion of Iraq, but for Joe his anger had begun earlier: "My support began to wane after clause IV, but I kept voting for Labour up until the Iraq war.

"I wasn't totally critical of New Labour. There were a few good things about the Blair/Brown governments, especially during the first term."

But Iraq that was the final straw. "I couldn't continue to support the party after that. The alienation after Iraq was always total. It quickly became apparent that there were no weapons of mass destruction. There was no accountability. No punishment for what happened there."

Bryce, who specialises in asylum law, gave his support to other parties.

"I voted yes in the referendum on Scottish independence. I was disgusted by the rightward lunge of the UK, and I thought we could claw it back if we left. I voted Green in 2010. I liked Ed Miliband but I thought his team was a little too far to the right, and he was dragged there."

On 12 September, Bryce rejoined Labour. When asked the reason he's emphatic: "Jeremy Corbyn is a great man who has the right ideas for the country."

He doesn't see Corbyn as a dangerous radical. "The only place he really went on a limb," he says, "was with his views on nuclear disarmament, where I agree with him completely."

So what does Labour have to say to win back Scots, and, more specifically, people like him?

"Jeremy has said that austerity is a choice ‚Äì that resonates with people. If Labour make that message clear it can only be a good thing.

"If we get behind this movement it could really change the UK for the better."

http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/jan/13/jeremy-corbyn-effect-members-explain-why-joined-labour?CMP=Share_iOSApp_Other

status_message:
Why I joined: 'The Conservatives focus so much of their attention on what's beneficial to them. I don't feel like Corbyn would operate in that way':

"At 25, Laura Fisher is one of the older members of Young Labour (the age range for the group is 16-26).

According to a YouGov poll, young people were most likely to select Jeremy Corbyn as their favoured choice in the run-up to the Labour leadership election, and thousands of them crowded into halls to hear him speak. The ranks of Young Labour swelled in areas where the group was almost defunct.

A charity worker living in Tooting, south London, Fisher was one of the many young people who became enamoured of Corbyn in 2015, joining the party in June after supporting Labour for the first time at the general election. She did more than just cast her vote in favour of Corbyn, she also worked on a phone bank, attempting to persuade constituency Labour party members to vote for him, and went out door-knocking.

"I've come close to meeting him but getting through the crowds of people was too difficult," she says. "He reminds me of those teachers in school who were really cool and you really liked and didn't want to annoy them because they'd tell you they were disappointed with you. I did convince one person on the phone to vote for him, which was the greatest moment."

A key reason for Fisher's involvement in Corbyn's Labour party is the anti-austerity stance. She has seen close friends and family struggle with the benefit cuts and the bedroom tax.

"My cousin is going to university soon and her mum is being forced to look for new accommodation. It's ridiculous that she's going to be penalised because her daughter is going to be away getting an education," she says.

Fisher, who grew up in Lincolnshire, does not come from a political family. She explains that her politics have been influenced by a combination of studying the subject at A-level and her personal experiences. Her mother, who lives in York with her grandfather, came close to being flooded this Christmas which, she says, reminded her of why she dislikes the Conservatives.

"You saw people's lives and livelihoods completely ruined. If you drove out of my mum's house there was this whole stretch of road which was a basically a pond. The Conservatives focus so much of their attention on what's beneficial to them. I don't feel like Corbyn would operate in that way."

Fisher finds the idea that Corbyn's politics are a return to the 1970s and 80s, as has been argued by some commentators, to be a naive line of argument. She feels "old white men" in Tooting were using her age against her when they employed this rhetoric.

"Corbyn would not have got elected if he was saying things that were rooted in the 70s and 80s, because he couldn't possibly have engaged people who were my age or even younger. Actually I think he's more rooted in Labour origins which have been lost over time," she says. "If he is going back it's only in a positive way."

http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/jan/13/jeremy-corbyn-effect-members-explain-why-joined-labour?CMP=Share_AndroidApp_Facebook

status_message:
Momentum prepare to elect first national committee

via LabourList:

"Momentum will elect an interim national committee next month to draw up the group's first "democratic, representative, inclusive and pluralist" constitution and put structures in place to pursue its aim of creating a "democratic, equal and just society."

The committee will include people elected by regional meetings of delegates from verified local Momentum groups and representatives from affiliated trade unions and leftwing groups, such as the Labour Representative Committee. It will also include representatives from under-represented groups, such as BAME, disability, LGBT and women, to ensure balance. All delegates and committee members will have to be Labour Party members.

The committee will consult with Momentum activists to develop a constitution and structure that enables local groups to organise effectively in their communities; encourages trade union participation at local, regional and national level; and ensures the group is financially sustainable. It is then expected to devolve itself in six month and be replaced by a new committee elected through its new structures.

James Schneider, a spokesperson for the group, told LabourList: "Momentum is excited about the forthcoming formation of our first National Committee. It represents our next stage in creating an inclusive, participatory and effective organisation involving a wide range of stakeholders, including trade unions.""

More on this:

http://labourlist.org/2016/01/momentum-prepare-to-elect-first-national-committee/
link_name: Momentum prepare to elect first national committee | LabourList

"Attempts at further talks through the reconciliation agency ACAS have broken down with no final agreement being reached. The government has continued to follow the same rhetoric that it always has and are continuing to fail to address the genuine concerns being raised by junior doctors across the country.

"The new contract is not fair on junior doctors, taking contracts back to the dangerous days of the 1980s and early 1990s, and is not safe for patients.

"The removal of contractual safeguards will lead to overworked, exhausted doctors with morale at an even lower point than it currently is. It will disadvantage doctors who wish to take time off to undertake essential medical research or start a family.

"Ultimately this could all lead to an even greater recruitment crisis than that which is currently facing the NHS.

"We aren't politicians. We aren't going to manipulate statistics or trot out line after line of spin. At the end of the day the implementation of this contract would very likely cause a domino effect, leading to much harsher consultant and nursing contracts.

"This is the first step down a path that could irrevocably damage the NHS, which is one of the greatest institutions in this country.

"This is a fight to save our NHS."

Read more: http://www.plymouthherald.co.uk/Derriford-Hospital-says-patient-safety-risk/story-28468410-detail/story.html#ixzz3wn4u2Omx

The NHS is under threat. The government's assault on junior doctors, nurses, midwives and allied health professionals is an attack on patients' safety and our most cherished national institution - the NHS.

SUPPORT STUDENT NURSES, MIDWIVES AND ALLIED HEALTH PROFESSIONALS

Proposed changes to NHS student funding could shackle student nurses, midwives and allied health professionals with ¬£65,000 of debt. Trainee nurses already work at least 37.5 hours per week as part of their training on top of their other learning commitments. They can't take on a part-time job as well. Their bursaries are an investment in our NHS, an investment in the health of the nation.

The student nurses, midwives, and allied health professionals are fighting back to protect their profession and our NHS. We must stand with them.

If you can, please join their protest at 12 noon tomorrow, Saturday 9 January. It starts outside St Thomas' Hospital, Westminster Bridge and proceeds to Downing Street. For more information, please click here:

https://m.facebook.com/events/440660962797762/

SUPPORT THE JUNIOR DOCTORS

It's not just the student nurses that the government has in their sites; the junior doctors are in the Tory crosshairs. The government is trying to force through a contract that not only undermines the pay and conditions of the junior doctors but threatens patient care. The junior doctors have been left with no alternative but to strike to protect our NHS. They are fighting for our NHS and deserve our support.

On Tuesday 12 September, the junior doctors will start their industrial action across England. Please show solidarity with the junior doctors as they fight to protect our NHS and join them on their pickets. There will be pickets at every main hospital in England. For a map and more information about events happening near you, please see the British Medical Association's dedicated microsite:

http://oneprofession.bma.org.uk/

Our NHS is under threat. Our nation's health workers are fighting back to defend our health and the future of the NHS. Momentum is proud to stand in solidarity with those on the frontline fighting for all of us. Please show them your support.

In solidarity,

#TeamMomentum

status_message:
Shocking stuff. It's time to tackle inequality and obscene incomes:

"Today (Tuesday 5 January) is 'Fatcat Tuesday', the day on which the amount of money made by Britain's top executives will surpass the average UK worker's earnings for the entire year.

The most recent figures for pay released by the chief executives of the biggest 100 companies on the London Stock Exchange put the average pay for these lucky few at just over ¬£4.7 million.

Lobbyists for the City and big business (the CEOs themselves rarely explain why they deserve or need such enormous sums of money) protest that they have difficult jobs and work long hours (unlike teachers or nurses, presumably).

But even if we make the generous assumption that executives work 12 hour days, take less than 10 days annual leave a year and work three out of every four weekends, this still equates to hourly pay of around ¬£1,200 per hour. Enough to surpass the ¬£27,200 earned by the average UK worker last year by early evening today (Tuesday) assuming they returned to work on Monday 4 Jan."

http://highpaycentre.org/blog/fatcat-tuesday-executive-pay-has-already-overtaken-your-earnings-for-the-en

#FatCatTuesday

status_message:
Happy new year! We hope that you have had an enjoyable and relaxing festive period and start to 2016. 

Unfortunately, we are not being wished a happy new year by the Tories. Rail fares are set to rise by a further 1.1%. Shadow transport secretary, Lilian Greenwood, has said that the hikes amount to a "truly staggering" rise of ¬£2000 in cash terms since 2010. 

Over the last five years rail fares have risen nearly three times faster than average wages. Commuters will be paying an average of 25% more for rail season tickets since David Cameron took office. Despite the high cost, our trains are often late, overcrowded and understaffed.

British passengers continue to pay much higher fares than passengers on publicly-owned railways in Europe. Jeremy Corbyn has restated his commitment to delivering an affordable railway under public ownership that puts people before profit. Read more about it here.

Join us to protest against the #RailRipOff at stations around the UK on Monday 4 January 2016. Find the nearest protest to you below. All you need to do is turn up as other activists will be there with leaflets and information for you to distribute to passengers. Please make sure to post updates and photos on social media using the hashtags #RailRipOff and #Momentum. 

(Please visit Action for Rail for the list of regularly updated actions.)

Roland Singer-Kingsmith, 27, Social Entrepreneur Start-Up Manager
 
"I joined Momentum after spending my summer campaigning for Jeremy Corbyn to become Leader of the Labour Party. I'd never met so many like-minded young people in one place before. For the first time in my life, I felt like we had a say in our future. There was so much energy and enthusiasm in the campaign that we needed to find a way to harness it.
 
Momentum gives me a place to explore new ideas and a platform to express myself. It makes me feel hopeful that we can change things for the better so that we don't end up worse off than our parents. Since joining Momentum I've discovered a whole community of people I never knew existed who share my beliefs and want to make a difference to society. I have never felt this inspired or excited by politics before. Momentum makes everything possible again."

#iamMomentum

status_message:
Jeremy Corbyn's New Year message: 

"I'd like to wish everybody a Happy New Year.

There's been a great spirit during the Christmas period: of families coming together and communities supporting each other, helping out neighbours, helping the homeless, helping out victims of floods in so many parts of the country.

It's that spirit of community and solidarity we need to bring into the heart of our politics and the way our country is run.

I was elected Leader of the Labour Party in September on a mandate for change.

During these last three months, we've challenged this Government ‚Äì and defeated them: on Working Tax Credits, cuts to the police service, and running the prison service in Saudi Arabia.

We will have to challenge them even more next year ‚Äì on their damaging cuts to public services, and their lack of investment in our economy and our people.

But we will also offer a real alternative: a politics that gives people a say in the decisions that affect them, and an economy based on long-term investment, instead of self-defeating austerity.

We want to build an economy fit for the 21st century.

2016 will be the start of a journey to elect a Labour government in 2020 that will do just that: a government that will deliver a fairer, more prosperous society that we can all enjoy ‚Äì a society that works for all, not just the few."

http://labourlist.org/2015/12/we-will-have-to-challenge-them-even-more-next-year-jeremy-corbyns-new-year-message/
link_name: "We will have to challenge them even more next year" ‚Äì Jeremy Corbyn's New Year message | LabourList

status_message:
"A society that works for all not just the few."

Jeremy's New year message for us all.

https://m.facebook.com/story.php?story_fbid=10153866031613872&id=330250343871

Thanks for all your support for Momentum so far, lets keep on building on the successes of 2015 in the year ahead.

#HappyNewYear

"Media coverage implying the party is now a dysfunctional wreck struggles to understand why Britons are still flocking to join Corbyn's Labour. 
 
"We've increased membership to nearly 400,000, we have the biggest, most active membership ever in my lifetime."
 
He's proud that "our campaign for the leadership did bring a lot of people into politics who have never been involved before," and reveals he had been knocking on doors with new members that morning. 
 
That's how he sees the role of the much-maligned Momentum group: "It could be a way of bringing in a lot of people. That's got to be a good thing.
 
"If the Labour Party is going to expand it's got to bring in people who weren't in it before. You cannot recruit only from your own membership!"

http://www.morningstaronline.co.uk/a-f97d-Jeremy-Corbyn-The-Big-Interview#.VoGmFezfWnM

"Cornwall has seen a huge surge in membership since Jeremy Corbyn became leader, with new branches springing up across the county.

Constituency parties in South East Cornwall, North Cornwall and St Austell-Newquay all report a large increase in support due both to the 'Corbyn effect', and people who left over Tony Blair's support for the Iraq war, now returning to the fold.

North Cornwall has seen a fourfold increase in membership since the general election and the election of Jeremy Corbyn as leader, and it now stands at over 400.

Some are former members, and the invasion of Iraq was a common theme as to why they left, said constituency party chair Adrian Jones."

http://www.cornishguardian.co.uk/Corbyn-effect-sees-surge-Cornwall-Labour-support/story-28419403-detail/story.html
link_name: Corbyn effect sees surge in Cornwall Labour support

status_message:
Great piece by Danny Dorling, author of 'Inequality and 1%": Creating a more equal society will require understanding and generosity, hope, perseverance, but above all kindness.

"Because the UK government hid and delayed the publication of the statistics, academic researchers in England have been forced to use data passed to the European Statistical Office. That data shows that George Osborne mislead parliament in his March 2015 claim when he said that people were better-off than they had been in 2010. Data collected across the whole of the UK actually revealed that living standards had fallen for all but the very richest. Increasing numbers of people have been reporting falling behind with their rent and that they are struggling to pay fuel bills. Almost half the population cannot now afford to immediately repair or replace their fridge or cooker if it breaks down. "Only the very richest (those who could make ends meet very easily) saw no perceived fall in their living standards."

Living in a society that tolerates gross wealth and income inequalities makes it hard to empathize with a wide range of other people. The very rich may ignore you in the same way that you sometimes don't notice the person sweeping the street as you walk by. Or the very rich try not to notice you ‚Äì just as you might have learnt to try not to notice the people sleeping rough in the entrance to the tube or train or bus station. You are as far down, and your life as frightening to the very rich, as the thought of being roofless will be to you."

http://www.democraticaudit.com/?p=18347
link_name: Creating a more equal society will require understanding and generosity, hope, perseverance, but...

status_message:

In an interview with the Morning Star, the Labour leader said Momentum could attract a lot of new people into the party and that this would be "a good thing". Labour could not expand if it just focused on existing members, he said."

status_message:
Seasons Greetings and End of Year Reflections from Momentum.

As Christmas is upon us, we'd like to wish you a happy, healthy and peaceful festive period. 

It has certainly been an exciting and unforgettable year. In less than three months, Momentum has exploded on to the political scene. Thousands of people have attended local meetings and events, engaged through social media or got stuck in to campaigns. But this is just the beginning. There is a lot of work to be done in 2016 to ensure that Momentum continues to develop into a sustainable and democratic organisation with increased participation from the grassroots. As 2015 draws to a close, we'd like to take this opportunity to reflect on what we have achieved, outline our intentions for 2016 and express our sincere thanks to you for being part of this movement. 
 
Momentum launched shortly after Jeremy's victory, with the first priority being to capture the energy and enthusiasm which his campaign sparked. Within 24 hours, Momentum had over 12,000 likes on Facebook. All around the UK, Momentum supporters started to organise meetings and gatherings in their local areas, bringing together the young and old, seasoned Labour Party activists, trade unionists, community organisers along with people who had never been involved in politics before. 

This explosion of energy meant that Momentum could begin running national campaigns in support of Jeremy in his first few months of leadership. In just two months, thousands of Momentum volunteers have been involved in numerous campaigns and activities, such as: 

- Democracy SOS. Momentum's first campaign was a mass voter registration drive to lessen the impact of government changes that could see up to two million people drop off the electoral register. 150,000 leaflets were distributed by Momentum activists at events all around the UK.
- No Work Penalty. As part of the successful campaign against George Osborne's tax credit cuts, Momentum collected 'Dear George' messages about how people would be personally affected. These were watched, 'liked' and shared by tens of thousands of people on social media.
- Oldham by-election. Momentum helped mobilise people from across the UK, including organising coaches from five cities to transport activists to canvass for a Labour win in the Oldham West and Royton by-election. Jim McMahon won the seat with an increased share of the vote and thanked Momentum for the support. Hopefully, this will be the first of many election victories for the Corbyn-led Labour Party.
- Don't Bomb Syria. Over 30,000 supporters used the Momentum lobby tool to email their MPs asking them to vote against the bombing in Syria ‚Äì as two-thirds of Labour MPs were persuaded to do. 
- Justice for Climate and Jobs. Momentum helped mobilise supporters to join the largest worldwide environmental demonstration in the run up to the Paris Conference.

On Monday 4 January, Momentum supporters all around the UK will be calling for the railways to be brought back into public ownership to end the #RailFareRipOff. Look out for the email in the next few days for details of the events closest to you.

In addition to the national campaigns, there have been lots of inspiring stories from the local groups: from voter registration drives at football matches in Brighton, to organising campaigning workshops in Gateshead and Blaydon. Momentum's greatest asset is the wealth of knowledge, experience and energy of its grassroots supporters. Share your best practice with us at celebrate@peoplesmomentum.com. We'll be sharing your stories within the network in a monthly newsletter in the new year.

While Momentum has successfully achieved its initial short term goal of capturing the energy and enthusiasm of Jeremy's campaign, there is still work to be done to ensure that it meets its longer term aim of developing into a democratic, transparent and participatory organisation. 

When Momentum was launched, the website stated, "As it grows, Momentum will develop democratic governance structures at every level of the network." This will be the top priority for early 2016. We will continue to establish regional coordinating networks, made up of two representatives from local groups, at least one of whom must be a woman. In order to move towards a democratic governance structure at a national level, a National Committee will meet in January 2016. Its initial composition is to be decided by the Launch Reference Group (Clive Lewis MP, Rebecca Long-Bailey MP, Richard Burgon MP, Kate Osamor MP, Jon Lansman and Cllr. Sam Tarry), and full details will be published on the website. 

In order to reflect the diversity of the movement and its grassroots nature, the National Committee will be made up of two representatives from Scotland, Wales and each of the nine English regions, two from each national trade union and representatives of established Labour left organisations. The committee will be gender balanced and will include BAME and disability representation. Initial representation from regions and nations and equalities groups will be based on consultation as prescribed by the reference group, but will be elected within six months.

The National Committee will perform the following functions:
- Engage with supporters to listen to what groups need to be able to organise effectively at a local level.
- In consultation with local groups and supporters, create a democratic, representative structure which facilitates local, regional and national coordination.
- Ensure that Momentum has the capacity to hold free and fair elections for positions on the National Committee.
- Clarify a membership and affiliation structure, and encourage trade union participation at local and regional as well as national level.
- Secure a viable pathway for Momentum to become a financially sustainable organisation.
- Ensure all the necessary organisational processes and procedures are in place (for instance, verification for local groups and complaints procedures).

Full details of the National Committee will be published on the website. Momentum supporters will receive regular updates on the process, and every effort will be made to engage grassroots supporters in the decision-making processes. We are confident that this process will ensure that Momentum will become a sustainable organisation which will be able to facilitate a grassroots movement for real progressive change in our communities. 

As Jeremy outlines in his endorsement of Momentum, 2015 has been a remarkable year. But this is just the beginning. Thank you for your continued support and for being part of Momentum.  

With festive greetings,

Team Momentum

She wasn't a trade union leader in the official sense, but Jayaben Desai made a huge contribution to our movement's history. It's so important to remember our past, to learn the lessons and draw strength. #Momentum

Puru Miah, 37, Small Business Owner

"As a father of two, I want my children to have the same chances that I had: access to public healthcare and education, free at the point of use, and to have access to social housing. These social virtues and public goods that we took for granted are now being whittled away, to an extent that I can now see a future where my children will have less opportunities that my generation had.
 
As a small business owner, I am sick and tired of the uneven playing field, where multinational corporations pay less taxes proportionately than small businesses like myself. I was inspired by Jeremy Corbyn's call to look after small business owners such as myself through a just and transparent tax system.
 
I see Momentum as a vehicle to change the narrative and the direction our society is heading, and revive the idea of a virtue-lead politics for the common good. This is done on a local level, addressing local concerns, by challenging social cleansing and preserving communal amenities. Nationally, we should be challenging dogmas of the status quo and participating in national campaigns such as voter registration and tax justice.
 
Momentum resurrects the ideal of individuals coming together, inspired by values and ideas to change society for the good. Each small act of collective social good, hopefully creates a virtuous cycle, leading to a transformation of society."

#iamMomentum

Paul Routledge in the Mirror: 

"Nasty middle-aged men in cushy jobs on gold-plated pensions telling hard-working people retirement can wait

There is something uniquely nasty about middle-aged men, in cushy jobs, sitting on gold-plated pensions, telling hard-working people they cannot look forward to retirement.

Life expectancy may be rising, but not for everyone at the same rate. Those in manual jobs age much faster than Tory MPs, who ripen slowly in their clubs.

Do we really want people coming up to 70 driving buses, trains and lorries? Will you be happy with worn-out nurses and doctors?

Indeed, would you be happy being one yourself?"

http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/george-osborne-raises-retirement-age-2891308#ICID=sharebar_twitter
link_name: Nasty middle-aged men in cushy jobs on gold-plated pensions telling hard-working people...

status_message:
Many people have been quick to jump on Momentum as a return to some sort of factional politics of the 1980s. In fact, many of our supporters weren't even born in the 1980s, and most of those who were aren't looking backwards for their politics but forward to a new politics: 

"...in history events rarely quite replicate themselves. For a start, however acute Labour's fractures are today they pale in comparison with the early 1980s, when rival factions tore into each other with gusto, virulence and venom.

...Further, the late-1970s and early-1980s was a period of severe and unprecedented polarisation which featured rival, solidly-structured blocs of left and right releasing salvos at each other with little regard for the party's popular standing. This simple binary distinction does not begin to do justice to the complexities, subtleties and nuances of modern Labour politics."

#anewkindofpolitics 

http://www.independent.co.uk/voices/is-momentum-a-return-to-the-old-days-of-labour-s-militant-tendency-a6782621.html
link_name: Is Momentum a return to the old days of Labour's militant tendency?

status_message:
Niroshan Sirisena, 35, Teacher/Musician
 
"My best mate from uni was phonebanking during the leadership campaign and invited me down to the Unite HQ. Walking in, I saw not only him but a work colleague and thought immediately - "I've arrived". My interest kept rising from then.
 
What with a heady mix of government cuts to FE colleges and Teresa May picking on international students to look "tough on immigration" caused me to take redundancy back in September and a window opened for me to link up with Momentum.
 
Now I run Momentum Arts, so as a lover of the arts, I get to expand the organisation in this way. The people I've met and keep meeting are wonderful and vibrant and this is what Momentum is about for me. Positivity trumps negativity any day of the week and we have it in abundance.
 
I believe that this movement is something new to the UK and in that way, it can create history. Asides from the obvious 2020 election victory, I want to see Momentum as the vanguard of positive social change that the UK has been crying out for ever since I was born and for long before that too. We will be and are challenged at every turn by our detractors but if we were unable to rise to those challenges, then we wouldn't be here now. Let's keep the Momentum going."

#iamMomentum
The Jeremy Corbyn for PM page have been collecting grassroots reaction to Jeremy Corbyn's first 100 days. If you're on Twitter, you can join in by using the hashtag #Jez100.

100 Days of Jeremy 

Fantastic review of Jeremy's 1st 100 days by Matthew Willgress in the Morning Star, with welcome mentions for Momentum and Momentum Arts:

"Momentum, which is doing so much great work to harness the energy of the summer's Jeremy4Leader campaign, will also be vital here. 
 
This has already been shown both by its contribution ‚Äî praised by Jim McMahon himself ‚Äî to Labour's campaign in Oldham West and Royton, and its prominent support for, and role in bringing thousands of people into, campaigning on issues such as voter registration, opposing tax credits cuts and opposing the bombing of Syria. 
 
The launch of initiatives such as Momentum Arts show the amazing potential for building a real, broad-based movement for change that will greatly benefit the Labour Party itself."

http://morningstaronline.co.uk/a-5164-100-days-of-Jeremy-Now-lets-build-the-momentum-for-a-Labour-victory#.VnfoK-JvC7B

status_message:
Lauren Johns, 34, Publican
 
"After the last general election I decided I had to become more active if I wanted to see a real change in this country. So many people up and down the country are feeling downhearted and helpless about the current political situation, so it's amazing to find a tangible means to turning this negativity into a positive force for change.  
 
I want to feel empowered and energised, and to be given the means to go out and give hope to the rest of the community by showing them that change can come about if we are proactive and united."

#iamMomentum

"Globally there are more refugees today fleeing horror than at any time since the Second World War.

These are lives that are being held back, young people who are not getting the opportunities they should.

We should always be asking ourselves ‚Äì all of us, not just politicians ‚Äì whether we could do more for others."

- Jeremy Corbyn

status_message:
Solomon Hughes in the Morning Star:

"Critics argue Momentum will allow "outside influences on Labour," because the organisation is happy to talk to non-Labour leftwingers and campaigners.
 
Momentum accepts it needs to get this relationship right ‚Äî to make sure only Labour members are involved in decision-making, even if non-aligned people come to their meetings.
 
But this also not a new problem. Progress takes money from a variety of business groups, and invites them to its meetings. In the past couple of years Progress has taken money from the British Venture Capital Association (lobbyists for private equity), the Advertising Association, Hitachi, TalkTalk, Santander and two lobbying companies ‚Äî Bellenden Public Affairs and Lexington Communications. 
 
In most cases these corporations and lobbyists were paying for meetings organised with Progress inside the Labour conference. How's that for outside influence."

http://www.morningstaronline.co.uk/a-a4a5-Momentums-here-to-stay#.VnWloVSLTIU

Santiago, 23, Builder
 
"My father is a Chilean refugee, and some of my earliest memories are from the picket we held outside where Pinochet was under house arrest in 1998. Across those 503 days there was always one MP who was fully committed, who supported our cause and who became the standard by which I judged all other politicians, and that was Jeremy Corbyn. Momentum is my chance to repay him in kind.
 
I want Momentum to speak for the youth in the UK. For too long the young have been paying for the mistakes of previous generations with little to show in the way of political representation or engagement. Momentum needs to be a movement which allows the young in our society, which have been marginalised by politics, that they can make a positive political change both locally and nationally."

#iamMomentum

"We have to be a voice for people that would not otherwise be heard." - Diane Abbott at the Momentum Arts Xmas Fundraiser in Brixton last night. 

#Momentum

Linda Heiden, 64, IT Training Specialist 

"Volunteering with a local foodbank, every week I meet local people devastated by unemployment, benefit delays, and insufficiently funded NHS and social services.  I joined Momentum for the same reasons I joined Labour. Jeremy Corbyn's overwhelming mandate to lead Labour gives us a real opportunity to re-energise Labour and help it rebuild a more equitable society.
 
I want to see Momentum and Labour re-establish democracy within party politics and revive political participation in this country.  We need to de-mystify the political process, and what it takes to bring about real change, and energise people with the understanding that their participation will make a real difference."

#iamMomentum

status_message:
"The impact of Tory austerity policies will be laid bare this Christmas as millions of cash-strapped Brits are unable to afford the celebrations.

According to a study by YouGov, just over two million adults will not spend any money on Christmas because of financial worries.

Another fifth of UK adults will use credit to fund their seasonal celebrations with an overdraft, credit card, loan or payday loan.

YouGov, which was ¬≠commissioned to do the research by employee benefit loan provider Salary Finance, said 54% of adults admitted financial worries had stopped them going out with friends or taking holidays."

http://www.mirror.co.uk/money/brutal-tory-cuts-leave-2-7026350#ICID=sharebar_twitter

status_message:
Samira, 32, Growth at a startup

"I've lived in Brixton for almost 7 years now. My life is most definitely here.  I figured it was time to get out and about in the community so I could get to know some of my neighbours? The local chapter's a great way to do that. So many worthwhile things to get involved with right at your doorstep! Inspiring people to do them with. I feel so fortunate.
 
Momentum? This chat ‚Äì 'to the Left'; 'To the 'Right' may as well be left to Tinder frankly. The words mean little to someone (like me) with no history of activism. All jargon aside ‚Äì I wanted a chance to meet real people talking real local issues in a way that I could relate. Maybe even affect a little change I could actually see through? Momentum creates that space for me. I just rocked up one day and got stuck in. Welcomed in spite of being a rookie ‚Äì just being interested made me eligible."

#iamMomentum

Good report from the South West. Just one little point, though. When journalists says "much maligned" - what they mean, of course, is "much maligned by the press". In the real world, we're hardly maligned at all...

"South West Labour party supporters are calling on MPs to "stop sneering and get behind their leader", as members of the much maligned Momentum network set up shop in towns across the region.

Dubbed a "mob", a "rabble" and a "faction" by senior party figures, the group argues its only aim is to promote the policies of elected leader Jeremy Corbyn and encourage MPs to give him their support."

It also claims deselection of local politicians "is not a priority" for members, and that all they want is to secure decent homes and income for families, and to push for an end to conflict.

Read more: http://www.westernmorningnews.co.uk/Labour-gains-Momentum-South-West-does-mean-party/story-28348544-detail/story.html#ixzz3u9LzgEv4 
Follow us: @WMNNews on Twitter | westernmorningnews on Facebook
link_name: Labour gains Momentum in the South West - but what does it mean for the party?

Excellent interview via Share Radio, where Momentum organiser Emma Rees talks about the rise of Momentum and the shift to a new kind of politics:

"Momentum is the successor organisation to the campaign that elected Jeremy Corbyn as leader of the party. Over the summer, people from across the party were overwhelmed and amazed by the amount of energy and enthusiasm that was sparked during the leadership contest. After a second defeat in May, I think this is exactly what the party needs. It needs to be energised. People need to be asking questions. A greater number of people need to be involved in the democratic process of decision making and I think Momentum is putting forward a positive, outward facing opportunity for people to get involved in politics. Politics isn't just something that goes on in Westminster, by people wearing suits in closed rooms. It's actually something which is rooted in communities, where people are coming together, having their voices heard and engaging in positive campaigning."

https://audioboom.com/boos/3912196-share-politics-with-colin_bloom-talking-to-emma-rees-from-campaign-group-peoplesmomentum-giving-the-left-wing-take-on-the-oldham-west-and-royton-by-election

status_message:
Diane Abbott with a great article in the Huffington Post on how Oldham showed that Labour gets results when it has a strengthened message and a united, campaigning party behind it: 

"The whole Labour family came to Oldham in the course of the campaign: the leader of the Scottish Labour Kezia Dugdale; Members of Parliament; councillors and activists from all over the country. There were also four coach loads of supporters from Momentum, who Jim McMahon thanked for their positive contribution.

London based commentators and MPs took pleasure in claiming that the by-election was a "referendum" on Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn. They said confidently that the majority would drop or we could even lose. Well, if it was a referendum on the new leader, it was one he won handsomely. Not only did we win in Oldham, but we won with an increased share of the vote.

The combination of an excellent local candidate and Labour's clear campaign messages led to this result. As Jeremy Corbyn put it, Jim McMahon "ran a great campaign, focusing on bringing jobs to Oldham and giving every child the best opportunities" and the result was "a clear demonstration that Labour is the party working people trust.""

http://m.huffpost.com/uk/entry/8771750?utm_hp_ref=uk&ncid=tweetlnkushpmg00000067

#Momentum
link_name: Labour Can Look Forward to Moving Forward in 2016

status_message:
Now. Hang on a second, because it's not often we say this...

But a brilliant article on Momentum. Thank you, George Woods:

"The reason for all this outpouring of distortion, lies and insults is simple. Momentum is founded on an enthusiasm, felt by hundreds of thousands of people, for a new and genuine left and a rejection of the failed Westminster consensus. It therefore has the potential to pose one of the most serious threats to the British establishment it has ever experienced.

...It is in the interests of Labour's right to confine political debate and the expression of political ideas to parliament, where the left is heavily outnumbered. Momentum provides the vehicle by which the will of the mass membership can be voiced and brought to bear."

Great campaign initiative from the TUC: it would be great if Momentum supporters and local groups could get involved in this:

"The campaign against the trade union bill is at a critical stage. The parliamentary process has moved into the House of Lords, where we have our best chances of defeating it or getting changes pushed through.

But this means ensuring the bill remains in the public eye as much as possible. We need to remind politicians and journalists alike of the vital role unions and union members play in our society and economy.

In February (from the 8th to 14th) we'll be staging a special week of action against the trade union bill throughout England and Wales.  A week that takes the message to more and more people, union members or not, that this bill is bad for our country.

When I visit workplaces throughout the UK, I'm always amazed by the great work being done by union reps to train, educate and look after their colleagues.

Over the last decade alone trade union learning centres have provided courses for over two million learners and helped develop over 30,000 learning reps. Government research from 2007 estimated union reps prevent up to 13,000 accidents a year, and by providing a voice for the workforce, reduce conflict and staff turnover, saving hundreds of millions of pounds.

Improving the lives of workers and communities is what unions are about.

Now is the time to share with others the great work unions and reps do where you work and live. We want to know why you heartunions.

heartunions is a chance to showcase the difference that unions make in your area. If you know of a union rep, course or programme that you think needs celebrating then we want to hear from you.

Wherever you work, be it a hospital, factory or call centre, please get involved, and get in touch with your stories.

Loads of events are being planned for the week. On Tuesday the 9th, the TUC we'll be hosting the biggest ever workplace meeting, linking branches across the country to highlight the vital work unions do in workplaces of all types. On Thursday the 11th, we'll be taking the message out into our communities, and calling on you to help raise the profile of trade unions where you live, and recruit more members to our movement.

All the key information about the week of action will be at heartunions.org.  We'll keep adding to it in the coming weeks so that it will have everything you need to take part.

Let's show the government that threatening trade unions has no place in a modern democracy. Only through coming together and showing our united strength will we be able defend the right to strike and organise together."

#heartunions

http://strongerunions.org/2015/12/09/if-you-heartunions-join-our-week-of-action-against-the-trade-union-bill/#.VmgkzSc2rhw.twitter
link_name: If you #heartunions join our week of action against the trade union bill

status_message:
A little dose of reality, from Charlie Cooper at the Independent: 

"For many of Momentum's supporters, the anger directed at it has been met with a mix of bemusement and weary frustration. 

"I am really surprised by the negative press we've received," says Samira Raj, a 31-year-old employee at a social enterprise who helped set up Momentum's Lambeth branch a month ago. 

"Nobody's talking about deselections. We know party infighting is bad for Labour. Most just want to meet people like them and find something that contributes, one day a week, or once a fortnight."

Her account of the group's first two meetings ‚Äì "we split people up into workshop groups, use flipcharts and Post-its to get people to think about issues that are of interest to them that they'd want to work on" ‚Äì certainly doesn't sound like the actions of a group plotting to end the careers of Labour MPs."

http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/momentum-meeting-the-grassroots-political-movement-that-grew-out-of-jeremy-corbyn-s-leadership-a6764156.html
link_name: Meeting the political movement that grew out of Corbyn's leadership campaign

status_message:
Message from one of our volunteers, Rebecca - who is working hard on getting feedback from Momentum groups all over the country. Please help her out if you can, using the email celebratemomentum@gmail.com:

"Hello!

First of all a big thank you for setting up the Momentum Facebook pages round the country. The first two months of Momentum have seen us grow to over ninety local groups with many thousands of supporters and this is down to you and your fellow campaigners who have worked so hard.

As we grow Momentum into the force for social change that we all know it can be, we want to collect evidence of all the great things that are happening under the Momentum banner up and down the country. Many of you are doing a great job of posting on the Momentum Facebook page but I am equally sure that some brilliant things are happening that we don't know about!

It would be really great to know about all the things you have done so far - we will then produce a monthly Newsletter highlighting some of the great work around the country. This will give us a chance to celebrate each others achievements and hopefully inspire each other to try some new and greater things!

To help you keep track of quantitative data, (how many meetings, how many people attended etc) I am attaching a spreadsheet you can use. Please try and keep this up to date so that you have evidence of what you and your group have done. 

There is a questionnaire which we'd like you to fill in. Please email celebratemomentum@gmail.com and we'll send you a copy. This is an opportunity for you to share your successes and also things you have learned or that haven't worked so well. Do also feel free to send us photographs, quotes from members of the public, anything that will really give a picture of how things are going.

I would be really really grateful if I could have your questionnaire by end of Frday the 11th December. This would mean that we can get a Newsletter out before Christmas.

I can't wait to find out what you've all been up to!

Thanks,
Rebecca
Momentum Team"

It has always been our intention to be an outward facing group. That's entirely in keeping with the Corbyn leadership campaign over the summer, which reached out to people who had become disillusioned with mainstream politics and the lack of a coherent alternative on the left.

Momentum sprang out of a desire to help empower people previously not politicised, to encourage those people to engage in debate and to organise on issues which affect them in their communities. So we think that it's right for Momentum to be seeking to work with coalitions and campaigning groups outside the Labour Party, nationally and locally. 

What we will not allow, however, and we don't think our supporters will accept, is for our grassroots network to be used as a vehicle for other groups to push their party agendas, which have for decades been set against the Labour Party and those members who have worked hard to get us to this position. 

http://gu.com/p/4eq2z?CMP=Share_iOSApp_Other
link_name: Corbyn's Momentum group moves to block influence of hard-left parties
