status_message:
A fairly decent write up of Momentum's role from the Spectator of all places. Sebastian Payne interviewed Momentum organiser Emma Rees up in Oldham last Saturday: 

"The question that still puzzled me is why does Momentum exist as a separate organisation from the Labour party? There are the traditional party structures, which offer plenty of opportunities for campaigning ‚Äî regardless of whether you support Corbyn or not. I spoke to Emma Rees, one of the Momentum organisers for the Oldham campaign day about what the group is doing. Rees said Saturday was 'a real show of strength and solidarity'. Despite the 'absolutely abysmal weather', Momentum did similar things to regular Labour activists: leafleting, posting letters and making tea.

So what is the point of Momentum if it is doing the same things as Labour? 'Momentum is about providing an additional platform for people to get involved and to participate in politics at a local level with the idea of strengthening the Labour party and working towards a Labour victory in 2020 and all the other elections,' Rees said. 'The vast majority of Momentum supporters are active members of their local Labour parties and many Momentum supporters are people who have also newly joined the party'.

Like McDonnell, Rees denied that Momentum is trying to be a party within Labour ‚Äî insisting the group only exists to help. 'The experience on the ground really doesn't speak to that. I think you have consider that Momentum has come out of the back of a leadership campaign that was incredibly positive and it involved lots of people ‚Äì there were 16,000 people that volunteered during Jeremy's leadership campaign and Momentum is continuation that'."

http://blogs.new.spectator.co.uk/2015/12/behind-the-scenes-with-momentum-what-are-they-up-to/
link_name: Behind the scenes with Momentum: what are they up to? - Spectator Blogs

status_message: Maybe we should start a hashtag? #SaySomethingNiceAboutMomentum
Don't forget that we have a pretty lively Twitter account as well. We can always do with your support on there, so make sure you are following Momentum at @PeoplesMomentum

Momentum organiser Adam Klug on Sky News' Murnaghan programme earlier today, answering questions about Momentum's role and some of the criticism that has come our way:

Murnaghan: "You know the charge. You must have heard it often by now, that you are in some way, shape of form (online in particular) the Praetorian Guard, to police, protect and punish those that disagree with your views.

Adam: I think that's a misunderstanding of what Momentum are doing, and I think if you meet anyone who's been involved in Momentum, or go to any Momentum events, there's a positive, inclusive atmosphere whereby people are having their voice heard. For example, on the Syria situation, Momentum provided a tool whereby supporters could lobby their MPs if they felt inclined to do so - and over 30,000 people did so. If a very, very small number of people behaved in a manner...trolling...bullying or harassing, I and Momentum would absolutely condemn that 100%"

John McDonnell's 'Comment is Free' piece this morning:

"The media has seized on the lobbying tactics of some who clearly haven't got it yet about our new politics. There is no place in political life for threats or abuse and we will not tolerate them. At the same time those that want to make mischief by misreporting or misrepresenting organisations and events do us no favours either."

http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/dec/05/john-mcdonnell-jeremy-corbyn-labour-force-progressive-change?CMP=Share_iOSApp_Other
link_name: Labour can be the most powerful force for progressive change in generations

status_message:
Wow. We've just hit 30,000 likes, which is fantastic. Thank you all so much for your support - and your patience while we get more hands on deck to run our social media and online communications. It's incredible to see so many positive meetings, actions and campaigns going on all over the country. We do appreciate all the effort that has gone into that. Please keep sending us photos and reports of anything you're up to (via info@peoplesmomentum.com) and remember to keep inviting people to 'like' this page and get involved in Momentum. 

Yours,

#TeamMomentum

The last week has been a rollercoaster for Momentum: we have proved ourselves effective at a national and local level; we have organised huge resistance against the bombing of Syria; we've helped towards a magnificent victory in Oldham and we've seen the continued growth of our vibrant network of groups and organisers. At the same time, we've experienced the most vicious attack from some of the media - and even some within our own party have taken to the press and airwaves to dismiss us. But we will keep our cool and carry on patiently building and developing Momentum in a bottom up way - and giving a voice to thousands of activists. We are going nowhere. We've got a lot of work to do, after all. Hope you can join us. #Momentum

A good discussion on Newsnight last night about Momentum, the Syria vote and Oldham, with James Schneider speaking about the role of Momentum in organising some of the opposition to the vote in favour of bombing Syria (from 11.40 onwards):

http://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/episode/b06r30zs/newsnight-04122015

Lies, distortions and misconceptions about Momentum and the lobbying of MPs:

"Following the Syria debate on Wednesday and the prior lobbying and demonstrations, media descriptions of the abuse and bullying tactics directed at MPs reached a crescendo. Thursday's Daily Mail, for example, under a double-page headline "hard-left hate mob target MPs", carried a picture purporting to show them outside the home of Stella Creasy, MP for Walthamstow with the caption "Menacing: protesters against air-strikes marching last night outside the home of pro-war MP". The Daily Mirror reported that "Hundreds, including vicars and imams, marched on Stella Creasy's  constituency base". As the Guardian reported this morning, many other media outlets not to mention social media ran with the story.

It is perhaps not surprising in this context that on the BBC Today programme Friday morning, Tom Watson warned that any Labour members who joined an anti-war protest outside the home of the Labour MP Stella Creasy should be thrown out of the party. Except that there was no protest outside her home. Stella Creasy confirmed that the protest had not gone past her home at all.

Tom Watson's comments were reasonably measured ("They look like a bit of a rabble to me but I don't think they are particularly a problem for the Labour party") but his comments unwittingly contributed to the false image which is being created of Momentum. 

....There are many factors that appear to have contributed to distorted coverage, misrepresentation and downright lies including:

- agents provocateurs on social media, hiding behind fake identities, who may be Tories or perhaps even Labour members engaged in 'black ops';

- hostile or opportunistic members of other parties like Nancy Taafe of the Socialist Party who stood against Stella Creasy in May (winning 394 votes for TUSC, good for them but, at less than 1%, an utterly pathetic vote for anyone who lives in the real world) but goes on BBC Daily Politics to demand her deselection;

- exaggerated claims by hard right Labour MPs determined to discredit Momentum and Jeremy Corbyn.

However, there undoubtedly are also some people, probably a small number, who think of themselves as being supportive of Jeremy Corbyn and against war in Syria who are guilty of inappropriate behaviour towards MPs ‚Äì using inappropriate language or photos, abuse, intimidation and even bullying. Many will not be members of Momentum or the Labour Party"

http://www.leftfutures.org/2015/12/lies-distortions-and-misconceptions-about-momentum-and-the-lobbying-of-mps/
link_name: Lies, distortions and misconceptions about Momentum and the lobbying of MPs | Left Futures

status_message:
Clive Lewis on Oldham:

"With bated breath, many political commentators waited for an upset. Would a shock result shake the Labour party? Critical articles and interviews had been lined up, about the future of Labour under Jeremy Corbyn, after a predicted narrow, pyrrhic victory for his party or even a surprise Ukip win in the Oldham West and Royton byelection. Even the relatively supportive Daily Mirror had assumed the worst in its print edition, with an overnight article headlined "Dark night of the polls for Jeremy".

So, yes, they did get an upset. But it certainly wasn't the one they were expecting. Labour won the first byelection of Corbyn's leadership with an increased 62% share of the vote. Second-placed Ukip, who spent the month-long campaign being talked up, received just 23%. Oldham gave Labour a big win.

When you look at the facts and not the fevered speculation, you can see Labour had a strong local candidate in Jim McMahon. It also ran a well-organised campaign that gathered support from all wings of the party."

http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/dec/05/oldham-jeremy-corbyn-labour-byelection
link_name: The Oldham result shows how wrong it is to write off Jeremy Corbyn | Clive Lewis

status_message:
Oldham was very much a collective effort - and it's incredible how effective we can be when we work together. Good report on Labourlist:

"The Labour by-election machine kicked into force. Activists came from all over the country, and from all wings of the party, and were met by some of the best organisers in the business."

http://labourlist.org/2015/12/the-oldham-west-by-election-what-did-we-learn/

Hugely significant result in Oldham last night, with Labour winning an overwhelming majority - 62% of the share of the vote. The relationship which we developed with Jim McMahon and his team shows what can be achieved by a collective, inclusive approach to our politics - using the knowledge of local party activists alongside the energy of those from outside the area. It's given us a model to work with and develop for the future. Thanks to everyone who helped out. #WeBackedJim

Amazing result for Jim McMahon in Oldham West and Royton, with Labour increasing its share of the vote by 7.5% and taking a massive 62.2%. In his acceptance speech, Jim made a special point of thanking the thousands of volunteers who had travelled to Oldham to help out in the campaign. Momentum are proud to have played a part. We met so many good people up in Oldham and were welcomed by local Labour activists and supporters alike. What a fantastic night for Labour! 

#WeBackedJim
#Momentum

An important counterbalance to the way this story was reported in the press - from Sue Wheat. There are important lessons here:

"I just want to set the record straight for anyone reading or listening to the news about Walthamstow and Stella Creasy, which as far as I can tell is totally untrue. 

On Tuesday a local resident Sophie Bolt and Rev Steven Saxby organised a family vigil, which myself and others helped to publicise quickly on social media. No one asked me to do it, I just did it. 

It was a beautiful, calm meet-up of for anyone who wanted to show our MP Stella Creasy that we wanted her to vote NO on air strikes in Syria. We met at the Queen's Road mosque with candles in jam jars and walked quietly to Stella's Labour office on Orford Road, where there were speeches by religious and community leaders. 

It was a beautiful, community, inspiring family event of people trying to make their voices heard against the airstrikes and trying to influence Stella, even though we knew she was in Westminster. 

We took post-it notes and thought it would be powerful to write messages of peace and stick them on the office window. It looked beautiful and powerful. 

The next day we realised someone had put up a Facebook post with a picture of the start of the vigil, which was outside the mosque. You can see the mosque on the right if you zoom in, but mostly it's just the houses next to it. He claimed we were outside Stella's house and said something incendiary about her not having children to worry about. (His exact post was: 'outside [her] house... apparently she has still to make up her mind ‚Äì and she has no children to upset'.) He managed to get some police in the pic which made it look like a demo and it was dark and blurry. In fact the very low police presence were very helpful and friendly throughout."

Read on here:

http://www.redpepper.org.uk/we-marched-for-peace-not-to-bully-stella-creasy/
link_name: We marched for peace ‚Äì not to 'bully' Stella Creasy | Red Pepper

status_message:
Remember where we were 6 months ago and take strength.

Video by Yannis Mendez

Statement on the Syria vote and its aftermath:

"Momentum is disappointed that Parliament voted for Syrian airstrikes last night. We do not believe that David Cameron made the case that bombs will defeat Daesh or improve the lives and security of Syrians, the UK or our allies, and we fear that they may have the opposite effect.

Nevertheless, we are pleased that the majority of Labour MPs and the shadow cabinet did oppose David Cameron's proposal, reflecting the policy of the party conference and the wishes of its members. We also respect and acknowledge the right of all MPs to vote as they have done.

Members of the Labour Party and the public have a right to be heard. Momentum is proud that we assisted over 30,000 people to email their MP asking them not to vote for bombing. We believe these messages from the public helped convince some of the 153 Labour and 72 non-Labour MPs who voted against bombing to do so. It can never be a threat to express your views to your elected representative.

Momentum strongly disapproves of anyone who engages in abusive behaviour towards MPs or anyone else, and threatening or bullying, whether they are outside the Labour Party (as most are) or inside it. We specifically asked our supporters to emulate Jeremy Corbyn, and to keep their messages about the issues and to refrain from any personal attacks.

Momentum is not a threat to MPs who voted for bombing. We have made clear that we will not campaign for the deselection of any MP and will not permit any local Momentum groups to do so. The selection of candidates is entirely a matter for local party members and rightly so."

Polling Stations are now open in the Oldham West and Royton by-election. If you are based in Oldham and you can spare a couple hours to help out, there's loads that can be done to help in terms of getting the vote out. Call in at the Campaign Offices:

Old Humdinger Pub

Oldham
OL9 6JR 

Good luck Jim.

#IbackJim

Undoubtedly people will feel worried by the vote in Parliament last night and our major concern must be for the people of Syria - civilians, already living in chaos, now caught up in an even more terrifying situation. No doubt some of us will feel demoralised too - and that's when we need encouragement and solidarity from our fellow activists and supporters. This is from one of our Momentum's local organisers:

"We are on the brink of yet more war, but the last couple of days have been incredibly positive in so many ways.  Jeremy is winning, Cameron is losing and Labour MPs are coming round.  Nobody said this was going to be easy.  We are trying to change politics, trying to positively realign the Labour party.  This is going to be a long haul and we are on the side of the angels."

Momentum at the #DontVoteToBombSyria demonstration tonight. Solidarity and thanks to those activist, members and supporters who have campaigned so hard to raise the issues around the Syrian intervention and engaged positively with their representatives. 

#Democracy

Some of the Labour MPs who are tonight voting against the bombing in Syria #DontBombSyria (2 of 3)
Some of the Labour MPs who are tonight voting against the bombing in Syria. #DontBombSyria (1 of 3)

Excellent video blog by Myles Dyer. Well worth a watch...

#DontBombSyria

At 6pm this evening, Momentum will be joining thousands of demonstrators gathering in Parliament Square, London, against the bombing in Syria. Look out for us and join us under the banner. #DontBombSyria. 
Contact your MP: http://writetomp.peoplesmomentum.com

Our position is quite clear:
Just two months ago in Brighton, members at the Labour party conference, agreed four conditions that would have to be satisfied before military action could be supported. None of them are yet satisfied. 
- Clear and unambiguous authorisation from the United Nations ‚Äì but resolution 2249 carried last week does not invoke Chapter VII of the UN charter authorising the use of force and does not provide a legal basis for military action by the UK.
- A comprehensive EU-wide plan to provide humanitarian assistance to the consequent increase in the number of refugees ‚Äì but in fact, the EU refugee plan is unravelling and the approach to refugees is increasingly fragmented.
- That bombing is exclusively directed at military targets directly associated with ISIL ‚Äì but there is no guarantee that the population of areas currently controlled by ISIL would be protected.
- That any military action is subordinated to international diplomatic efforts, including the main regional powers, to end the Syrian civil war ‚Äì but unfortunately the shooting down of a Russian plane by Turkey on top of differing approaches to the Assad regime and continuing ethno-religious conflict make a broadly-based, sovereign Syrian government that could retake territory currently controlled by ISIL a diminishing prospect.

Tonight, MPs will decide whether to back David Cameron's plan to bomb in Syria. Increasing numbers of MPs are deciding against the proposed air strikes. It's still not too late to contact your MP (it only takes 2 minutes): 
http://writetomp.peoplesmomentum.com
#DontBombSyria

"Let not history repeat itself, Don't Bomb Syria" - Imran Hussain MP. 

#DontBombSyria

Momentum organiser, Adam Klug, addresses thousands protesting the government's proposal to bomb Syria.

#DontBombSyria

Video by Yannis Mendez

There's still time to email your MP to let them know how you feel about bombing in Syria. Over 20,000 have - and it's having a effect. Please do so now, if you haven't already:

http://writetomp.peoplesmomentum.com/

#DontBombSyria

Momentum will be joining the thousands of demonstrators gathering in Parliament Square, London this evening against the bombing in Syria. Our position is quite clear:

In Brighton two months ago our party conference agreed four conditions that would have to be satisfied before military action could be supported. None of them are yet satisfied:

- Clear and unambiguous authorisation from the United Nations ‚Äì but resolution 2249 carried last week does not invoke Chapter VII of the UN charter authorising the use of force and does not provide a legal basis for military action by the UK.

- A comprehensive EU-wide plan to provide humanitarian assistance to the consequent increase in the number of refugees ‚Äì but in fact, the EU refugee plan is unravelling and the approach to refugees is increasingly fragmented.

- That bombing is exclusively directed at military targets directly associated with ISIL ‚Äì but there is no guarantee that the population of areas currently controlled by ISIL would be protected.

- That any military action is subordinated to international diplomatic efforts, including the main regional powers, to end the Syrian civil war ‚Äì but unfortunately the shooting down of a Russian plane by Turkey on top of differing approaches to the Assad regime and continuing ethno-religious conflict make a broadly-based, sovereign Syrian government that could retake territory currently controlled by ISIL a diminishing prospect.

So we'll be in Parliament Square at 6pm, with the Momentum banner, to show #solidarity with the #DontVoteToBombSyria protest. Look out for us and join us under the banner.

Today at noon, the All African Women's Group and Black Women's Rape Action Project will be lobbying MPs and demonstrating in Parliament Square against the Immigration Bill. Find out more here: https://www.facebook.com/events/1638409113079373/
and show them some support either in person or via social media.

Momentum went to Oldham on Saturday and made an impact...

We had a fantastic day on Saturday. We'd like to thank everyone who made us so welcome, especially to the local Labour Party activists. See here for the report on Labourlist:

http://labourlist.org/2015/11/mcmahon-gains-momentum-in-oldham/

The candidate Jim McMahon was pretty pleased too, saying that he was "overwhelmed" by the support he'd had from Momentum at the post-canvassing social. 

If you get a chance to get to Oldham West and Royton for some campaigning between now and Thursday, please make every effort. This is a vital by-election both for the town, the party and the leadership. 

#IbackJim

A decision will soon be made whether the UK will bomb in Syria.

Whilst it is clear that the brutality of ISIL and the Assad regime must be stopped, David Cameron lacks a comprehensive strategic plan that will bring about a much needed peaceful solution and make life better for the Syrian people and increase security for the UK.

Please lobby your MP here and urge them to vote against bombing Syria.

Contact your MP if you haven't already - it takes five minutes: 

http://writetomp.peoplesmomentum.com/

Oldham West by-election: Jeremy Corbyn activists join campaign to save Labour candidate at risk of losing to UKIP

"Sandra is one of 150 activists put on the ground in Oldham East and Royton this weekend by Momentum, the grassroots network formed out of last summer's "Corbyn for Leader" campaign. Coaches from London, Birmingham, Bradford, Leeds and Sheffield have been organised by Momentum, and the Labour Party mothership has another 300 volunteers arriving from around the country.

Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell arrived on Saturday and has been on the doorstep with McMahon since. Have any voters raised McDonnell's Little Red Book incident, I ask Andrew Gwynne MP, who is organising Labour's by-election campaign. "Not one," he says. "It's not much of an issue for Oldham."

This looks suspiciously like something approaching Labour Party unity."

http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/oldham-west-by-election-jeremy-corbyn-activists-join-campaign-to-save-labour-candidate-at-risk-of-a6753811.html

status_message: Jim McMahon, the candidate for Oldham West and Royton, describes how he's been overwhelmed by the support that he has received from Momentum. He goes on to say that while there are many who seek to divide us, we shouldn't be diverted by that when in reality we're here to campaign for and represent the many, many people who have been marginalised, attacked and punished by this Tory government. Hear, hear.

Yesterday, we developed this online app for supporters to email their MPs and oppose bombing in Syria. By mid morning today, 12,000 people had used it to say #DontBombSyria. That's a stunning response - thank you. 

Let's double this number. Let's treble it. Share this with all your friends, let them know how important it is: 

http://writetomp.peoplesmomentum.com/

Brilliant Momentum social to end a fantastic day of campaigning in a wet Oldham West & Royton. Great to be joined by John McDonnell & Jim McMahon. A day when we united and focused on our real political opponents. Thanks to everyone who turned out today. You're all stars! 

#Momentum
#IbackJim
Thanks, Jim.

It's been a fantastic day in Oldham. The response on the doorstep has been great, with support for Labour's policies on investment rather than cuts, on housing and the NHS. A massive sense that people understood that the credit tax victory was down to strong leadership and grassroots pressure - and it has done lots of good for the party. Great to see so many Labour activists working together to get Jim McMahon elected. Now off to our Social with John McDonnell. If you're in Oldham, come along and warm up with a curry:

https://www.facebook.com/events/1617824795135115/

#IbackJim

After a hard day's campaigning in the pouring rain, please come along to our social - a curry, with a few words from John McDonnell, the Shadow Chancellor. We'd welcome anyone who has been out canvassing for Jim today. Come along to the Eastern Pavillion Banqueting Hall and dry off, have a bit to eat, relax and chat.

status_message:
Around 150 Momentum activists have travelled via coach, train and car to Oldham today to canvass for the Labour candidate Jim McMahon. They have joined hundreds of fellow Labour supporters and local party activists. It's currently tipping it down in Oldham, but we are carrying on, talking to people on the doorstep and handing out leaflets outlining the party's positive programme for the people of Oldham - for jobs and investment. The response has been fantastic. Well done everyone for their efforts today. 

#IbackJim

Despite the inevitable drizzle, Oldham is buzzing with Labour Party canvassers backing Jim McMahon, including Momentum coaches from London, Birmingham, Bradford, Sheffield and Leeds. Great atmosphere. This message from Momentum organiser Lita Hallyburton:

"Just canvassed Oldham. The place is buzzing with Momentum & Labour canvassers around the UK and massive voter support for Labour
Good to hear Tory voters tell us they'll now vote Labour because of tax credit cuts and reversal by Labour."

Jeremy Corbyn and the Labour Party want to know your views on military intervention in Syria. Please let them know what you think here:

http://www.labour.org.uk/page/s/syria-consultation

If you're on your way to Oldham on one of the #Momentum coaches, or just arriving, please tag us in on any pics or messages on Twitter by mentioning @peoplesmomentum and we'll try to share. 

#IbackJim

DONATE TO MOMENTUM

Let's develop the energy and enthusiasm of the Jeremy's campaign to enrich our democracy and build a better Labour Party.

Throughout the Labour leadership campaign, Jeremy often spoke about building a social movement to work for a more democratic, equal and decent society. Now is the time to make this a reality.

How will Momentum do this?

- Organise events, rallies, meet ups and policy consultations to encourage mass mobilisation for a more democratic, equal and decent society.
- Encourage those inspired by Jeremy Corbyn's campaign to get involved with the Labour Party, and to take its radical new message into their communities and workplaces. 
- Assist members in making their voice heard in Labour Party debates.
- Help people to build new and support existing organisations that can make concrete improvements now to people's lives. 

Through these actions, we aim to demonstrate on a micro level how collective action and Labour values can transform our society for the better.

Just like Jeremy's leadership campaign, Momentum will not receive large corporate funding. We are the People's Movement. Therefore, Momentum will rely on many generous donations from ordinary people, just like you. Please help our grassroots network to grow and reach out to as many people as possible.

Together, we can create the more democratic, equal and decent society we all deserve:

https://momentum.nationbuilder.com/donate

The truth is, we had this one in reserve. This, ladies and gentlemen, is Peter Oborne's very own #DearGeorge video message. As many of you will know, Peter is a well know Conservative Party supporter, commentator and newspaper columnist. Say it quietly, but he's even been known to write for the Daily Mail. Nevertheless Peter was outraged by the Tories' #WorkPenalty - a testament to the sheer foolishness of this policy and wanted to record this video for Momentum. This is what he said:

"I'm terribly upset and worried by the work penalty - your changes to tax credits, which seem to me to invidiously penalise working poor people. You've done a lot for the rich, it's time you looked after the working poor." 

So, it's a case of #NoWorkPenalty - at least in name, but as many people have pointed out, not only has George Osborne already found other ways to channel these brutal cuts (into housing benefit cuts, slashing Universal Credit or cutting grants to student nurses, for example), but there is a wider package of cuts which are already devastating communities up and down the country - and that pain will simply continue and intensify. So we've decided not to abandon our #DearGeorge campaign. We'll continue it, but widen the remit, explaining that Austerity Isn't Working - and asking people to personalise the cuts with videos and messages in that theme. Look out for more details soon. 

It isn't "job done", but a small win on the way to much bigger ones. But one good thing: we've got the #Momentum

On November 29 thousands of people will march through London for climate, justice and jobs on the eve of the international climate change talks in Paris. 

Floods, typhoons and droughts are already impacting many millions of people, both here and abroad. This humanitarian crisis affects those who have done least to create the problem the most, and left unchecked would affect us all.

But since May the Tories have systematically dismantled some of the most important environment policies- from blocking wind power, cutting support for solar and ending programmes to insulate cold homes. Instead they are going all out for fossil fuels.

We're marching to say: 

‚óè No to dirty energy!

‚óè Yes to renewables!

‚óè Climate jobs now!

‚óè Justice for people!

Momentum will be marching with the Labour Party bloc ‚Äì join us by the momentum banner at MEETING POINT J ON PARK LANE 

A map and more info is here: http://bit.ly/1S4hioZ 

All over the world people are already putting into practice real solutions: public renewable energy, green infrastructure, millions of new, unionised clean jobs. But it needs to happen faster, at scale and with people at its centre.

With such solutions already in flow, we can leave the age of fossil fuels behind. Some choices we can each make on our own. But some, we as a society must make together.

Hope is with people who are already way ahead of those governments who lack the political will to act, and ahead of those corporate interests who are blocking the changes we need.

Together, we are more powerful than they could possibly imagine. Whatever happens in the Paris climate talks, we can, and we will, build the future from here. A more just, more equitable and better world for us all.

- Students
- People in temporary or shared housing
- People who are new to the country.

Great story from Birmingham, about how "reluctant leader" Rachael Harris has galvanised people who had been involved in the Corbyn campaign over the summer into establishing Momentum Birmingham: 

"I spoke to student and Birmingham resident Rachael Harris, the founder of Birmingham Momentum. I first met her over the summer; she was one of the hardest workers in my phone banking team for the Jeremy Corbyn for Labour Leader campaign, often working from home due to the limited hours we had at the Unite Union offices.

In launching the Birmingham Momentum group, Harris has taken on a leadership role, as well as a great deal of responsibility. She doesn't see herself as a natural leader, stressing, "I put myself forward because nobody else seemed to."

I point out that people often say the same of Corbyn: that he accepted he had to run for leadership in order for his values to be represented, rather than out of a desire for power and prestige. While she is the leader, she says she wants, "everybody to take an important and active role and for everybody to feel equally valued", echoing the ethos of Corbyn's leadership of the Labour party."

Will you join us in Oldham West and Royton next Saturday (28th November) to ensure that the late Michael Meacher's seat remains in Labour hands and isn't lost to UKIP?

On Thursday 3 December, the people of Oldham West and Royton will elect their new MP. Michael Meacher was a member of parliament for 45 years, representing Oldham West and then Oldham West and Royton, championing the Labour values of fairness, equality and social justice. Now it's time to ensure that Oldham West and Royton remains a Labour seat and that Jim McMahon, the leader of Oldham Council and Labour's candidate, is elected to serve the constituency.

Over the summer, we proved how powerful we can be when we come together around a common aim. It's time to prove it again. This is the first election during Jeremy's leadership and UKIP is the next biggest contender. It is crucial that we demonstrate that Jeremy's Labour Party is serious about winning elections and delivering the more democratic, equal and decent society we all deserve.

Next Saturday, 28th November, Momentum supporters from around the country will head to Oldham West and Royton to show grassroots support for the Labour Party by canvassing for Jim McMahon's victory over UKIP.

Can you help to cover the travel costs? We want to demonstrate the strength of our support for Jeremy's Labour Party by helping as many volunteers as possible to travel to Oldham West and Royton to canvass for Labour and secure a victory for Jim McMahon.

I can chip in to cover travel costs:

https://momentum.nationbuilder.com/donate?utm_campaign=oldham_elects&utm_medium=email&utm_source=momentum

What will we be doing?

We will help coordinate travel as much as possible so that Momentum supporters can travel together, either by coaches from big cities or by putting you in touch with others in your area who are also travelling at the same time.

Momentum supporters will meet up in the morning and head to the Labour Party office in Oldham to join the team.

We'll spend the day canvassing with the Labour Party
Early evening, we'll have a social gathering so that we can meet each other and relax after a good day's canvassing.

I want to campaign for Labour in Oldham West and Royton:

http://momentum.nationbuilder.com/oldham_west_survey?utm_campaign=oldham_elects&utm_medium=email&utm_source=momentum

The Labour Party are hard at work and campaigning every day. Can you campaign for Labour on another day, especially polling day, Thursday 3 December? The Labour Campaign Centre is at 227 Middleton Road, Chadderton, Oldham, OL9 6LR and is open from 9.30am ‚Äì 7pm. Scheduled campaign sessions start at 10am, 1.30pm, 3.30pm and 5.30pm. status_message:
Democracy SOS campaign

Changes to the electoral system mean almost two million people are about to drop off the electoral register, without realising it.
Democracy SOS is an urgent voter registration campaign by Momentum.

The facts

-An estimated 1.9million people are set to drop off the electoral register because of the government's introduction of 'individual electoral registration'.
- In the past, one person could register on everyone's behalf, government changes mean that each individual needs to register themselves. Many won't.
- Another 8 million people are already missing from the register.
- That's almost 1 in 5 adults without the vote. That's not democracy
.
Who is this most likely to affect?

- Young people (only 25% of 17-year-olds are on the register)
- Students
- People in temporary or shared housing
- People who are new to the country

Why it matters

- This is important not only because we have hugely important elections coming up in May 2016 in Scotland, London, Wales, and many English councils, but also because it will have a significant effect on the 2020 general election by reducing the representation of poorer areas.
-Before the next general election, the Boundary Commission will redraw constituency boundaries. The Commission will do this based on who is on the electoral register on 1 December this year.
- Areas where more people fail to register will get fewer seats. Labour will lose seats and the Tories will gain, which is why they are doing it.

Momentum is calling on people to organise events, rallies and stalls to encourage people to register to vote. We are working alongside local Labour Party activists and others - so check out if there's an event near you. If you are organising a local voter registration drive feel free to add it to our map:

http://democracy-sos.peoplesmomentum.com/

And register to vote here: 

https://www.gov.uk/register-to-vote

Get yourself a #DemocracySOS Twibbon and spread the word about this massively important campaign: 

Be heard, be counted! Democracy under threat!

Spread awareness about the changes to the electoral system on the 1st of December 2015 which could result in almost two million people dropping off the electoral register, without realising it. 

Democracy SOS is an urgent voter registration campaign by Momentum to re-register those who are being disenfranchised. 

http://democracy-sos.peoplesmomentum.com/

http://twibbon.com/Support/dont-lose-your-vote

 #DearGeorge & #NoWorkPenalty

George Osborne wants to inflict a Work Penalty on three million households. Through cuts to tax credits, the Tories plan to take an average of ¬£1300 per year away from these working families.

The government's plans have provoked outrage and uproar across the land. Even the comment pages of the Financial Times called the cuts a "crime and a blunder". Labour MPs stood up and voted against this Work Penalty in Parliament (read the party's six reasons why here). The House of Lords refused to vote through the legislation in the face of threats that the government would appoint 100 new unelected Lords to force through the Work Penalty.

On 25 November, Osborne will set out his response to this opposition in his Autumn Statement in Parliament. We have to keep the pressure up and fight against this unjust Work Penalty. To do so, more people need to hear from those affected by the policy. Michelle Dorrell's personal contribution on Question Time did so much more to explain the cruelty and dishonesty of the Work Penalty than abstract figures. These are working people's lives that this government is choosing to make worse. 

We must also mobilise in the streets against this needless, callous policy that will push 200,000 children into poverty. Momentum is proud to support the People's Assembly Against Austerity's series of actions across the country in the lead up to the Autumn Statement. Please join us at an action near you.

Andrew Gilligan's "investigation" into Momentum in the Sunday Telegraph of Sunday 8 November contains a number of inaccuracies and innuendo about Momentum. It misrepresents Momentum's handling of data as possibly illegal, through quoting unnamed sources.

The article first introduces Momentum's data management with the following paragraph:

"Momentum has harvested thousands of confidential personal records of Labour members, including their private emails and telephone numbers, and is already using them to operate phonebanks, it can be disclosed. The tactic has caused a major row, with Momentum's opponents claiming it is illegal under data protection laws."

The suggestion that Momentum has done anything improper is false.

The legal entity that holds and manages Momentum's data is Momentum Campaign Ltd. This company was previously called Jeremy Corbyn Campaign 2015 (Supporters) Limited which, during the Labour Leadership campaign, operated the Corbyn's campaign's website and managed its data. 

The only data that Momentum holds is data obtained with the express and active permission of the individuals concerned ("explicit consent", as the Data Protection Act 1998 puts it). The campaign website featured a privacy policy which, among other things, stated that the campaign was: 

"collecting this data for use in Jeremy's campaign and to build a lasting network of support and debate around the ideas it inspires. It will be used to help us provide you with information to match your interests. We may also use it to alert you of activities you may be interested in and events happening in your area now and in the future."

---

Later in the article, Gilligan quotes an unnamed councillor in Leeds who calls Momentum's contacting of local members and constituency officials "illegal".

"Mr Benn opposes Mr Corbyn's policies on the EU and Trident. Moderate activists in Leeds told the Telegraph that Momentum had already started lobbying members and constituency officials using private contact details supplied to the Labour Party. 'There will be complaints about this,' said one councillor. 'It is illegal and a serious breach of privacy.' "

Momentum has not lobbied members of Leeds Central Constituency Labour Party (CLP) on the EU, Trident or indeed any other issue. No specific emails have been sent to supporters of Momentum in Leeds Central nor indeed elsewhere in Leeds. Supporters of Momentum in Leeds have received three emails: two making national announcements sent to all supporters, and one sent to supporters in Yorkshire and the Humber informing them of local group development and details of a voter registration drives.

The contact details of our supporters in Leeds, as elsewhere, were gained through the explicit consent of those individuals themselves during or after the leadership campaign.

Momentum did email some constituency parties (CLPs) to inform them of the group's Democracy SOS voter registration campaign and to offer support to any voter registration activities CLPs were planning. The contact details of CLP secretaries were either in the public domain or supplied to us by supporters in those constituencies. The email to secretaries was not "lobbying" but information about our activities and an offer to support their activities on the vital issue of voter registration. 

The contact details of CLPs' secretaries were processed fairly and lawfully. CLP secretaries were contacted to further the legitimate interest of Momentum in working more closely with CLPs to encourage voter registration. It is absurd to suggest that groups of Labour Party members like Momentum cannot contact Constituency Labour Parties in relation to campaigns by Labour Party members in those constituencies. CLP secretaries would reasonably expect to be contacted in relation to such activities.

---

The article later quotes another anonymous source who claims Momentum's data handling is illegal.

"Party sources said Mr Lansman is locked in dispute with Labour officials over the ownership of this personal information, including hundreds of thousands of telephone numbers, emails and addresses, given by Labour to the Corbyn campaign so it could canvass during the leadership election.

"Data protection law is clear," said one source. "You cannot pass personal information given to one organisation, the Labour Party, for one purpose to a completely different organisation, Momentum, for a different purpose."

However, Momentum has already conducted at least one full phone-banking session, on October 12, using the "illegal" information. It says it is entitled to hold it as the official "successor" to the Corbyn campaign. A spokesman for the Data Protection Registrar said no complaint had yet been received, but confirmed that Momentum was not registered to hold personal information, as the law requires."

Momentum is not "locked in dispute" with Labour officials over its data. Momentum was asked to clarify its data handling and it has done so.

Contrary to the suggestion by the unnamed source, Momentum has not used Labour Party data supplied to Jeremy Corbyn for the purpose of the leadership campaign. The only information retained by Jeremy Corbyn Campaign 2015 (Supporters) Limited (now Momentum Campaign Ltd) following the end of the leadership campaign is a fresh dataset obtained through the explicit consent of the data subjects.  The campaign's privacy policy expressly distinguished between data supplied by the Party and data shared voluntarily with the campaign. It has been reported that other campaigns pursued similar privacy policies, with other campaigns' data now available to Labour First.

Indeed, no complaint has been received by the Data Protection Registrar, although Gilligan suggests, without providing evidence, that one may be forthcoming by adding "yet".

Momentum Campaign Ltd is registered with the Information Commissioner's office and has been since the beginning of the Leadership campaign. The original application to the ICO was made under the company's former name, Jeremy Corbyn Campaign 2015 (Supporters) Limited. The identity of the data controller has not changed during this period. We have spoken to the ICO who have confirmed that the change of company name to Momentum Campaign Ltd does not require a new entry on the register.

Remember the date: the 1st of December - on that date, up to 1.9 million people are due to drop off the electoral register because of individualised voter registration:

This matters for two major reasons - not only because we have hugely important elections coming up in May 2016 in Scotland, London, Wales, and many English councils, but also because it will have a significant effect on the 2020 general election by reducing the representation of poorer areas.

Before the next general election, the Boundary Commission will redraw constituency boundaries. The Commission will do this based on who is on the electoral register on 1 December this year.

Areas where more people fail to register will get fewer seats. Labour will lose seats and the Tories will gain, which is why they are doing it.

Momentum will be campaigning hard to raise awareness of this and to register people via street stalls and events. Please let us know if you have anything going on locally - and add your event to the map below:

"Legislation is currently passing through parliament amounts to one of the worst attacks on working women in a generation. The Trade Union Bill...will deliberately curtail the ability of any worker to fight for equal pay, fair treatment and against discrimination and harassment. It could move the cause of women's rights back decades.

Large parts of it apply to everyone - heavily policed pickets, strikes being broken by hiring agency staff, and attacks on union finances, both political and otherwise. But the nastiest legislation is reserved for those working in "important" public services. Workers in these sectors will see the ways they pay union fees stopped. The time they can spend negotiating with employers will be restricted. And to go on strike they will have to achieve levels of votes far above the level received by most governments.

TUC data reveals that almost three quarters of the union members affected by those most oppressive rules are women."

The Tories will be desperate to save their #WorkPenalty in some other form having been initially defeated over the cuts to tax credits by the House of Lords and a high profile campaign to highlight their damaging impact. But we'll be there to expose the scam and out on the streets to campaign against the Work Penalty: 

"Somewhere deep inside the Treasury building on London's Whitehall, there's a gang of Tory advisers working around the clock with just one aim: pull George Osborne out of the fire on Tax Credits.

The Chancellor thought he got away with it this Summer, when he announced cuts to Social Security.

However, Government attempts to re-brand Tax Credits for working families as welfare 'bribes' has backfired spectacularly, with even Tories demanding a u-turn on cuts that will take ¬£1,300 away from 3 million households.

According to leaks out of Iain Duncan Smith's DWP, the latest wheeze being considered by the Treasury is to bury the cuts within the black-box of Universal Credit.

When this new system comes in, it will roll up multiple measures that support people in work, like Tax Credits, so the Chancellor thinks he can try and hide his tax credit cuts by confusing people.

Leaving aside the question of whether Universal Credit, which has seen its costs rise by ¬£3bn and slipped years behind schedule, will ever be properly rolled out - this plan would be a total con.

It will still create a work penalty for families, but simply push the cuts a little further down the line."

http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/george-osborne-wont-away-new-6783448

status_message:
Emma Rees, a Momentum organiser based in London, explains why Momentum supported yesterday's #GrantsNotDebt demo and the importance of our #DemocracySOS campaign to students and young people. Get involved here:

http://democracy-sos.peoplesmomentum.com/

Diane Abbott MP: What made Jeremy Corbyn's campaign in the summer so exciting is that it involved people in politics who never thought they could be involved. Now, our job is to build on that momentum.

Thousands of students and their allies marched through central London yesterday to call for free education, voicing opposition to Tory cuts and tuition fees. Momentum, the grassroots network arising out of the Jeremy Corbyn for Labour Leader campaign, attended the demonstration to express solidarity with students struggling for a more equal, democratic and decent society.

Momentum's first national campaign, Democracy SOS, targets the scandal of an estimated 1.9 million people dropping off the electoral register following government changes to electoral registration. Students are disproportionately affected, as their university or college are no longer able to register on their behalf. Tory plans to insist that boundary changes for the 2020 general election are calculated on the basis of this reduced electoral roll as it stands on 1 December 2015 compound the iniquity. Poorer and student areas will receive less representation than richer areas as the Boundary Commission will be forced to assume that those who have dropped off the electoral register do not exist.

At today's demonstration, which was organised by the National Campaign against Fees and Cuts, Momentum helped students register to vote. The group also distributed leaflets raising awareness of the changes to voter registration and the need to get registered before the end of November. 

Adam Klug, a Momentum organiser, explained, "Lots of people don't know if they'll drop off the register or not. If in any doubt, you can do it from your computer or smartphone in five minutes at www.gov.uk/register-to-vote. All you need is your name, address, date of birth and National Insurance number."

After pledging to register to vote, Jas Odusanya, a 19 year-old student of International Development Kings College London said "I didn't realise I that I could drop off the register due to the individual voter registration. I didn't have my National Insurance number with me and had to rush off to a lecture, but will make sure I register myself when I get home and will spread the word to other students. This is a really important issue. It's vital that more people know about it."

The Labour Party's leadership supported today's action for free education. Jeremy Corbyn, the party's new leader, has expressed strong support for education as a right, not a privilege and John McDonnell, the shadow chancellor, addressed the rally. McDonnell said, "Education is a basic human right. It is not something to be bought and sold. This generation will teach the Tories that we will not stand by and allow them to destroy your futures."

After McDonnell's speech, Momentum, alongside student Labour activists, signed up new members to the Labour Party, whose membership has doubled in the last six months in a wave of enthusiasm brought on by the Party's leadership election and Jeremy Corbyn's victory in it.

Poppy Camus, a 21 year-old student of European Studies at Kings College London said, "Since Jeremy Corbyn came into power, I suddenly feel that joining the Labour Party may be a way I can make positive change and express myself politically."

Emma Rees, a Momentum organiser, explained the importance of the day for the organisation, "Students and young people have been some of the worst hit by austerity over the last five years and now student areas are likely to receive less representation in Parliament. We must stand with students to protect their rights and demand free education, open to all. John McDonnell's speech demonstrated how the Labour Party is becoming the natural home for a considerable number in the student movement and we are delighted to see so many joining the Party."

Shelly Asquith, Vice President Welfare, the National Union of Students, and Momentum supporter said, "The student movement is a leading progressive force in the UK. That's why it's so crucial that we keep up our fight for the fairer society we want to live in and get registered to stop the Tory attack on democracy through changes to voter registration. I am delighted that Labour's leadership, and its supporters in Momentum, were here today standing shoulder to shoulder with us."

Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell spoke at the #GrantsNotDebt demonstration today - and he had this to say:

"I'm here in solidarity with this demonstration. 

Education is not a product, a commodity to be bought and sold. 

For generations now, one generation had handed the baton onto the next, to try to ensure that the next generation has a better quality of life than the last. This government is betraying you and future generations. We need to oppose it and I'm here in solidarity with that opposition.

Let me say this, your voice needs to be heard. This will be a peaceful demonstration. Stay safe and make sure the politicians know that we're not going to stand for this anymore. Education is a basic human right. It is not something to be bought and sold. This generation will teach the Tories that we will not stand by and allow them to destroy your futures. 

Solidarity. Solidarity"

#Momentum
Momentum @ #GrantsNotDebt

Although he couldn't be there in person today, Jeremy Corbyn made a point of sending this #solidarity message to those demonstrating today against the ending of grants and the privatisation and commercialisation of higher education: 

"Congratulations on your demonstration today.
 
I opposed the imposition of fees, and each increase, and I opposed the removal of maintenance grants ‚Äì as did many others ‚Äì and now we have an opportunity to change course, and to change Labour into a force that represents students' desire for free and accessible education.

Switching back to a loan in place of a maintenance grant will push the poorest students into higher levels of debt. 

We must also look again at restoring EMA and increasing college places, so all young people have the opportunity to go to further education and, if they wish, on to higher education too.

There are no student fees in Scotland, Germany and twelve other European countries, I want to bring all UK students into line with that sensible approach.

We all benefit from education, collectively as a society, not just as individuals. 

Keep protesting, keep campaigning for justice. Education is a right, not a privilege."

I opposed the imposition of fees, and each increase, and I opposed the removal of maintenance grants ‚Äì as did many others ‚Äì and now we have an opportunity to change course, and to change Labour into a force that represents students' desire for free and accessible education.

Today, we're launching our #DemocracySOS campaign with a day of action. This is what it's about:

An estimated 1.9million people are set to drop off the electoral register because of the government's introduction of 'individual electoral registration'.

In the past, one person could register on everyone's behalf, government changes mean that each individual needs to register themselves. Many won't.

Another 8 million people are already missing from the register. That's almost 1 in 5 adults without the vote. That's not democracy.

Who is this most likely to affect?

- Young people (only 25% of 17 year-olds are on the register)
- Students
- People in temporary or shared housing
- People who are new to the country

Hastily imposed changes to the electoral registration system means millions of people face being removed from the political process. We must not let that happen, says Alison Whyte on the Open Democracy website:

"On October 24, a nationwide voter registration campaign will be launched by Momentum, the movement born out of the surge in support for Jeremy Corbyn.

The campaign ‚Äì Democracy SOS ‚Äì will kick off with a day of action, with organisers engaging people in university campuses and town centres, handing out information about the importance of voting and how to register.

They say there is a serious risk that one in every five people in the UK could drop off the electoral register and be disenfranchised on December 1, missing out on a raft of crucial elections in 2016. 

Previously, under the 'head of household' system, one person in each house could register anyone at that address who was eligible to vote, and universities could register students by their halls of residence. This is no longer the case. Now every student has to register individually, not always a priority for students who are under so many other pressures."

https://opendemocracy.net/uk/alison-whyte/democracy-sos-stop-electoral-register-cull

Momentum announces its first national campaign - Democracy SOS

On Saturday 24 October, activists around the country will kick off Momentum's national voter registration campaign with a coordinated day of action.

Momentum, the new grassroots network arising out of the Jeremy Corbyn for Labour leader campaign, has announced its first national campaign, Democracy SOS.

Changes to the electoral registration system brought forward by the Conservative government mean that an estimated 1.9 million people will drop off the electoral register on 1 December 2015. Another 8 million are not on the register at all. That's almost 1 in 5 adults without the vote. 

With critical elections due in May next year in London, Scotland, Wales, Bristol, and English councils, it is crucial that as many as possible of these potential 10 million unregistered claim their vote and their voice.

Due to planned boundary changes, people not on the electoral register by 1 December will not be counted when the Boundary Commission redraws constituency boundaries. As a result, groups most likely to not be on the electoral roll could be further under-represented at the 2020 general election.

And who is this most likely to affect?
- Young people (only 25% of 17-year-olds are on the register)
- Students
- People in temporary housing
- People who live in shared housing
- People who for whom English is not their first language

In other words, it's about to get even worse for people who are already underrepresented. Poorer areas could have relatively fewer MPs than richer areas.

Momentum, supported by the Transport Salaried Staffs' Association (TSSA), will launch Democracy SOS, its voter registration campaign, on Saturday 24 October. Local Momentum groups all across the country will be hitting the streets to tell people about the changes and giving them information to assist them in registering. Momentum groups will, where possible, work alongside local, regional and national Labour Party efforts, as well as other interested unions and organisations, on the national day of action and in subsequent local efforts.

Explaining the choice of Democracy SOS as Momentum's first national campaign, Emma Rees, one of the organisers of Democracy SOS, said:

"Jeremy Corbyn's campaign for Labour Leader put forward a new kind of politics, a politics that engaged with those shut out from the political system, promising more participatory democracy. Claiming your right to vote is a major step in politicisation, to further action at community and national level. And so, we thought that Democracy SOS was a natural choice as Momentum's first national campaign." 

Welcoming the launch of Democracy SOS, Clive Lewis MP said:

"It is estimated that almost 2 million adults could drop off the electoral register after 1 December. In a democratic society, we absolutely have to take strong, proactive steps to prevent this from happening. I wholly support efforts of Democracy SOS."

Sam Tarry, TSSA National Political Officer, sees the Democracy SOS campaign in the context of the broader government policies. He explained:

"Democracy is under assault from the Tories - first they came for the charities and NGO's, with the 'gagging Act', then they came for the Trade Unions with their anti-worker, pro fat-cat Trade Union Bill, and now; they are coming for you.

The Tories want to gerrymander the electoral boundaries - taking away millions of working people across Britain's chance to be counted. It's a blatant, anti-democratic stitch-up designed to keep them in power for as long as possible.

TSSA is proud to support this labour movement campaign to ensure that the missing millions are counted. Over the next few weeks we will work in communities across the country - going out and talking to people face to face, to ensure every citizen's voice is heard and will count. Join our movement - it's time to stand up and be counted".

#DemocracySOS

We're opposing it, just as much as we're opposing the Government's whole economic austerity agenda."

Code of Ethics for Momentum Members and Momentum Groups

Interim Ethical Code for Individuals and Local Groups Associated with Momentum

Individuals and groups using the Momentum name and branding must operate according to the following principles at all times:

‚Ä¢ As the successor to Jeremy Corbyn's Leadership Campaign, Momentum promotes the values that Jeremy popularised during the campaign, of fair, honest debate focused on policies, not personal attacks or harassment. 
‚Ä¢ Momentum is outward-facing. It seeks to reach out across the community and encourages the participation of people who may not have been involved in political activities before. Ensuring the safety and self-expression of everyone is a priority, especially of those who are often marginalised on the basis of their gender, sexuality, ethnicity, race, religion, class, disability and educational or economic status.
‚Ä¢ Groups of individuals may form local Momentum Groups to share ideas, organise and participate in activities at their local level which demonstrate how 'Labour values' and collective effort can make a positive social and/or environmental impact. These groups must be democratic in their nature and be organised around a spirit of collaboration, inclusion and respect.
‚Ä¢ As the successor to Jeremy Corbyn's Leadership Campaign, Momentum promotes the communication of progressive ideas for political change, such as: opposition to austerity, the promotion of equality and participatory democracy. These are the values for which Jeremy Corbyn was elected.
‚Ä¢ Momentum is wholly committed to working for progressive political change through methods which are inclusive, participatory and non-violent.
‚Ä¢ Momentum seeks to build a social movement in support of the aims of the Labour movement and a fairer and more decent society. Momentum is committed to supporting the Labour Party winning elections and entering government in 2020 and seeks positive and productive engagement with local Labour Party branches.

Individuals and/or groups who do not adhere to the above principles will not be considered to be part of, or associated with, Momentum. Please note that Momentum is its embryonic stage as a network organisation. Our Code of Conduct is likely to develop further along with the governance structures of our organisation.

What the Corbyn campaign did next: meet Momentum

James Schneider writes on the launch of Momentum, the grassroots network building on the Jeremy Corbyn for Labour leader campaign

They are organising events, rallies, meet-ups and policy consultations to encourage mass mobilisation for a more democratic, equal and decent society. Wherever possible, these actions will be done in coordination with the existing organisations that work for these same ends."

http://www.redpepper.org.uk/what-the-corbyn-campaign-did-next-meet-momentum/

status_message: A reminder of what the Institute for Fiscal Studies said about the tax credit changes introduced by this Government. Only 26% of losses through cuts to benefits and tax credits will be made up by the so called "national living wage". As Owen Jones said last night, we should expose these cuts for what they are - a Work Penalty. They will drive many more people into desperate poverty and further devastate communities up and down the country. It's time to get organised. #Momentum

The last verse of Ben Okri's 'A New Dream of Politics' (inspired by Jeremy Corbyn) seems appropriate to us here at Momentum:

"We dream of a new politics
That will renew the world
Under their weary suspicious gaze.
There's always a new way,
A better way that's not been tried before."

The whole poem is wonderful - read it here: 

http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/oct/12/ben-okri-politics-poem-jeremy-corbyn

Photograph: Murdo Macleod

Owen Jones on the tax credit cuts: 

"This needs to be called the Work Penalty...which is working people having their wages slashed. We've got to have protests in towns and cities across the country. I think this has to be the big, big campaign now, because what I think it will do is not just undermine the Tories narrative, the story about the Tories being the party of working people, but millions of people who vote Conservative or UKIP are going to be angry about this. They're going to go 'hang on a minute, the Government go on about these people (often in quite a patronising way), hard working Britons doing the right thing...and now they're going to kick them in the teeth?'"

New hashtag? #WorkPenalty

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wrbu6NFazfU
link_name: The Conservative tax credit cuts are a work penalty | Owen Jones talks

The Institute for Fiscal Studies (IFS) say that the overall tax credit changes leave people on low incomes significantly worse off - and the national "living wage" doesn't begin to compensate for those losses. Carl Emmerson, IFS deputy director said:

"One can easily pick examples of some families who are currently receiving tax credits who will be better off, but one can also pick examples of individuals who will lose quite considerably. On average our analysis shows that tax, tax credit and benefit reforms planned for this parliament will leave households worse off and that the new National Living Wage will only provide partial compensation."

http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/david-cameron-is-still-wrong-about-tax-credit-cuts-the-institute-for-fiscal-studies-says-a6681951.html

status_message:
Shelly Asquith: What is Momentum? It means not waiting until we're in Government to get things done

"The Corbyn campaign for Labour's leadership excited and inspired so many people because at its heart contained the promise of democracy. Now we have to deliver on that promise of participatory democracy. Corbyn has already announced that Labour's policy making is going to be much more open, using new technologies and the public's skills and knowledge. Shadow Communities Secretary John Trickett is due to launch a series of Citizen's Assemblies. Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell has encouraged people to begin participatory, democratic budgeting where they can in their communities and workplaces. This is the work of building real democracy outside Westminster. That work starts now.

To deliver on this promise of participatory, the Corbyn campaign has today transformed into the Momentum movement. Momentum is a network for people inside and outside the Labour Party to organise and build a mass, democratic movement for progressive change."

http://labourlist.org/2015/10/what-is-momentum-it-means-not-waiting-until-were-in-government-to-get-things-done/
link_name: What is Momentum? It means not waiting until we're in Government to get things done | LabourList

status_message:
From Jeremy Corbyn: 

"Now, more than ever, we need to unite and continue to build our movement to change our politics and to win together in 2020. We need us to put our values, the people's values, back into politics. To do this, we need to keep up the momentum we have built over the last four months."

- Jeremy Corbyn

Thank you! Firstly, for the response to the launch yesterday (exactly 24 hours ago). Over 13,000 people have 'liked' Momentum on Facebook and 8,000 plus now follow @peoplesmomentum on Twitter. In a day, that's simply superb - and beyond even our expectations. But more than that, it's the positivity with which Momentum has been received which has bowled us over. So thanks to all of you for your enthusiasm, your ideas and your energy. If we can harness that, we're onto a winner.

From Jim Waterson at BuzzFeed:

"In the short term the organisation hopes to host meetings, events, and rallies for people engaged by Corbyn's politics. Members of Momentum, which is being run by an interim committee of volunteers, believe their activist model could then provide the basis for a new form of politics if Corbyn wins the 2020 general election.

"We'd hope to demonstrate through getting organised we can get good outcomes," a spokesperson for the campaign told BuzzFeed News. "By helping people to get organised and using the principles of collective co-operation and solidarity we hope to show ‚Äì on a micro scale ‚Äì how Labour if they got into government could transform the county and society on a massive scale."

It will also form organisations along geographic lines or on issues that will enable the left-wing movement to "deliver things now" with the Conservatives set to remain in government for another four years. One of the first proposals is to create a Momentum-aligned campaign group for the rights of private-sector tenants which would provide legal advice and help people get back their deposits."

http://www.buzzfeed.com/jimwaterson/jeremy-corbyns-campaign-team-launch#.rbWl9qNg00
link_name: Jeremy Corbyn's Team Launch Ongoing Activist Campaign

status_message:
Message from the Shadow Chancellor:

"We need the campaign's momentum to continue to transform our democracy and our way of doing politics. We are part of this wider social movement, running an economy in the interests of all."

The #PeoplesChancellor 

By the way, if you haven't followed us on Twitter, the handle for Momentum is @peoplesmomentum  

#Momentum

Nice write up in the Guardian:

"Volunteer activists in Jeremy Corbyn's leadership campaign are to try to harness the campaign's energy by setting up a new social movement to back his ideas and politics.

The campaign entitled Momentum launched on Thursday and has the approval of the Labour leader as well as John McDonnell, the shadow chancellor and campaign manager for Corbyn.

The group, being set up four weeks after Corbyn won the leadership, is designed as a grassroots network to create "a mass movement for change, for real progressive change in every town and city".

Momentum is describing itself as the successor to the Jeremy Corbyn for Labour Leader campaign, but it is independent of the Labour party's leadership. It will work both inside the Labour party and organise in broader civil society."

I think it's safe to say we have #momentum.
link_name: Jeremy Corbyn leadership campaign gives rise to new social movement

In the meantime, if you click on the drop down menu above (on the right with ...), you can share the page on your own timeline, which is almost as good. 

Thanks to all of you for this support.

Clive Lewis MP, in the New Statesman, outlining the need for Momentum as the next step in our transformation of politics:

"Be under no illusion - the powerful, the exploiters, the excessively wealthy will not pull their punches. By standing up to them, both Jeremy and the Labour Party will face an unparalleled assault that will make what happened to Ed Miliband pale into insignificance.

That's why the need for a social movement to work for a more democratic, equal and decent society inside and outside the Labour Party couldn't be greater. One that can help make the political space necessary for the new ideas we so badly need.The array of vested interests confronting us cannot be taken on by one man or even a single political party in Westminster. Instead, we need a bigger, broader, deeper alliance that can confront such powerful, vested interests.

That's why today, four weeks after ballots closed in the Labour leadership election; I'm so very pleased to announce the launch of Momentum."

http://www.newstatesman.com/politics/elections/2015/10/meet-momentum-next-step-transformation-our-politics

#Momentum
link_name: Meet Momentum: the next step in the transformation of our politics

status_message:
Momentum: this will be our grassroots network; join in, get involved, help build it. 

Filmed by Yannis Mendez
Edited by James Kenny

www.PeoplesMomentum.com
Twitter: @peoplesmomentum    
Facebook: www.facebook.com/PeoplesMomentum

Welcome to the Momentum Facebook page. 

Something wonderful happened this summer. After years of being told that there is no alternative to austerity, hundreds of thousands of people stood up for a new kind of politics and agreed with Jeremy Corbyn that austerity is a political choice not a necessity.

A quarter of a million people made Jeremy Corbyn Labour's Leader. And now Labour's conference has given its resounding backing to Jeremy and his Shadow Chancellor, John McDonnell, to turn Labour into an anti-austerity party of hope and bold alternatives.

We have begun to change the Labour Party but we still have to show how we can change the country. Throughout the campaign, Jeremy spoke about building a social movement to work for a more democratic, equal and decent society. Now is the time to make this a reality! 

Momentum will be our grassroots network to continue the work we have begun:

-To organise in every town, city and village to create a mass movement for real, progressive change.

-To transform Labour into a more democratic party with the policies and collective will to make that change in government.

- To bring together individuals and groups in our communities and workplaces to campaign and organise on the issues that matter to us.

Momentum will be your network; please help build it. But right now, as we begin to organise new events and campaigns, and to launch Momentum online, we need you to help us spread the word about these plans.

Begin by inviting all your Facebook friends to 'like' this page.
